title: The garden, the basket and the stand
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
The garden, the basket and the stand

 July 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1120
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Our mother always loved planting a garden each year. Her last one was in the spring of 1997.It was a part of her life, and she excelled at all phases of the country garden, from planting, to hoeing, to picking and processing the vegetables.
Mom was busy planting her large garden before school let out, and I can swear that by the time the school bus door shut for the summer, it was time to start hoeing and picking.
Each year, the baskets used to put the picked vegetables in to bring up to the water hose area to rinse down had to be brought out and cleaned. We had a small trailer hooked to the tractor to carry the supplies down and fresh veggies back.
That was always a comical act, as we pushed and shoved each other out of the way to get to drive first.
Those baskets were used for many years and came from the basket-making factory in the next small town. We had two sizes — one was the small basket perfect for tomatoes, peppers, squash and other small vegetables. Then we had the bushel basket that was great for large stuff, like sweet potatoes, beets, potatoes and more.
Now, the stand. I know you want to know just what a "stand" is.
Our family never had a produce stand, as we used most of our garden vegetables. When we would have an excessive amount of vegetables, they were shared with other family members and the older folks who could no longer garden due to health.
Nothing went to waste on the farm — it was shared and given away.
The stands back in the day were on back country roads in front of farmhouses or in our small town in front of the post office or the gas station.
The kids would get excited when a car pulled up. You can bet the veggies were pulled fresh each morning.
Today the roadside stands are like small stores, selling everything from sweet smelling soaps to fancy lunch linens and "homemade" jams, jellies and relishes. I still love the old family stands with grandma's veggies and the youngsters getting excited to get a customer.
Lets prepare some of these great farm-fresh foods with garden produce.
BISHOPVILLE FRIED GREEN TOMATOES
4 large green or slightly under-ripe tomatoes, 1/4 cup fine dry unseasoned bread crumbs, 1/2 cup flour, 1 tsp seasoning salt, 1/2 tsp ground black pepper, 1/4 tsp thyme leaves, 1/8 tsp ground red pepper, 1 egg beaten with 1 tbsp water, butter.
Wash tomatoes and remove stems. Cut each tomato in three thick slices. Combine bread crumbs with the next five ingredients. Mix well. Dip tomato slices in egg mixture, then roll in crumb mixture. Sauté in melted butter over medium heat, turning once to lightly brown both sides. Serve hot. Makes 12 slices.
TOMATO PIE
Pastry dough for single crust 9-inch pie (a package of pre-made dough works well), 6 ripe tomatoes (peeled and cut in 1/2 inch thick slices), 1/2 cup firmly packed brown sugar, salt and pepper to taste, pinch ground mace, 1 cup dried bread crumbs, 1 tbsp fresh lemon juice, 1/4 cup butter, 1 egg beaten with 1 tbsp water.
Prepare pastry dough, wrap and chill (or leave pre-made packages in the refrigerator). Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Butter the bottom of a 9-inch pie pan. Make a layer of tomato slices in pan and sprinkle with some of the sugar, salt, pepper, mace and bread crumbs. Continue making layers as described, ending with bread crumbs. Sprinkle on lemon juice and dot with butter. Roll out pastry dough (or remove 1 piece from the package), transfer to pan and flute edges. Brush the top with egg-water mixture. Bake for 30 to 35 minutes or until nicely browned. Serves 6 to 8.
HONEY BAKED SQUASH
2 medium squash (about 1 pound each), 1/4 cup honey, 1 tbsp lemon juice, 1/4 tsp allspice.
Cut each squash in half lengthwise; discard seeds and membrane. Combine honey, lemon juice, and allspice. Spoon into squash shells. Place squash in an 11-by-7-inch baking dish. Cover dish and bake at 350 degrees for 1 hour and 10 minutes, basting occasionally with the honey mixture. Uncover the dish and bake for an additional 5 minutes or until squash is tender.
STUFFED PEPPERS
1lb ground beef, 6 medium bell peppers (can use any color of peppers), 2 tsps garlic powder, 1 can French-fried onions, 1 can tomato soup with an added 1 1/2 tablespoons italian seasoning, 1 1/2 cups cooked rice, 1/3 cup grated parmesan cheese.
Heat oven to 375 degrees. Grease a 2-quart baking dish. Slice tops off of peppers and remove seeds and membranes. Blanch peppers in boiling water if desired. Set peppers in a prepared dish. Cook beef and garlic powder until beef is browned. Drain. In a medium bowl, stir together half of the French onions. Add rest of ingredients, mix well. Evenly spoon mixture into peppers. Cover with foil. Bake for 20 minutes or until the peppers are tender and the filling is hot. Remove cover; top with remaining onions and bake for 10 minutes more.
ZUCCHINI AND YELLOW SQUASH CASSEROLE
1 tbsp coconut oil or olive oil, 1 large onion (sliced), 3 tomatoes (sliced), 2 yellow squash (sliced), 2 zucchini (sliced), ¼ cup panko bread crumbs, ¼ cup parmesan cheese, 1 tsp of Ms Dash seasoning or thyme, 2 cloves garlic, salt and pepper to taste.
Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Grease the bottom of a 13-by-9-inch glass baking dish with the coconut or olive oil. Place the sliced onion on the bottom of the dish. Layer the zucchini, yellow squash and tomato in 3 rows. In a separate bowl, combine in other ingredients. Sprinkle the panko mixture over top of the veggies. Bake for 30 minutes.
SUMMER SWEET CORN SKILLET
4 tbsps butter, 4 ears sweet corn (kernels sliced from cobs), 3 green onions (chopped), 2 cloves garlic (pressed or minced), salt and pepper, 8 medium-sized basil leaves (chopped).
Add butter to a large skillet over medium-high heat. Once melted, add sweet corn kernels, green onions and garlic, then season with lots of salt and pepper and saute until kernels are crisp-tender, 4 to 5 minutes. Add chopped basil then stir to combine and serve.
This last one has been a staple lunch for as long as I can remember.
TOMATO MAYO PEPPER ON WHITE BREAD
1 good ripe tomato that is getting soft but not spoiling, your favorite mayo (I prefer Helmans) and Schmidt white sandwich bread (or your favorite bread).
Slice the tomato in thick slices, then set aside. Take your bread and slather the mayo on two pieces. I like to sprinkle the pepper right onto the mayo so it sticks. Then add your slices and go to town. A great summer snack to get you through until supper time.

title: Corn fields, corn cribs and corn recipes
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Corn fields, corn cribs and corn recipes

 July 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1351
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Riding the country roads throughout the Eastern Shore brings back so many memories of the past.The cornfields of today have not changed — the beautiful green rows of corn stalks slightly moving in the hot breeze. But how these fields were planted and will be harvested has changed.
Those modern, expensive, air-conditioned tractors with radios make life easier on 90-to-100-degree days. But the farmer's workday is still not easy — exposed to all kinds of environments, no guarantee of a successful harvest, seeds and chemical prices skyrocketing, getting farm workers is almost impossible. Yet that farmer keeps going and praying he has a good crop this year.
As we turn onto West Line Road, some of the corn fields are there — not many, but still a few. The memories begin to surface as I see where the barn once stood.
This barn housed the cows, and the second floor, known as the hayloft, held the hay. Many funny stories linger in that memory (another column for another day).
Behind the barn were the hog pens, where a lot of the corn was eaten, and the corn stalks made clean bedding.
The corn crib is a slender shed and had a roof, wooden floor, latched door and slatted walls that allowed air and light to help keep the corn from molding. The corn in here had some husks on them, but by fall they had dried. We would peel off the dried husks and throw them onto the ground in the pig pen, then hand shelled the corn into the hog trough.
In those days, the older kids watched the younger kids when the parents had to attend events without their children. One day my parents left my older sister to watch us.
My sister was an "undercover smoker." We were not allowed to smoke, but she did whenever and wherever no adults were around.
As soon as the car pulled out of the driveway, she got her "smokes" out and went outside, taking my brother with her, and they proceeded to "puff."
Suddenly my parents' car pulled in the driveway. Apparently, they had forgotten something.
Well, my brother and sister shoved their lit cigarettes in the slats of the corn crib, which sparked a fire, and smoke soon billowed. My mom came out of the house, smelled smoke, ran in her "dress clothes" to get the water turned on for the hose while screaming for my dad to get out and help.
My brother never smoked again, but my sister smoked "undercover" for many more years.
A few tips for buying corn at your local produce stands this year:
Don't buy pre-shucked corn, as it starts getting starchy once the stalk is off.Examine the silk. Older corn silk will look brown/black and dried out. Fresh corn on the cob will have silk that's a lighter color.Look for husks that are bright green, and avoid husks that are brown, bruised or dried-out looking.Hold each ear of corn to find the heavier ones, which are juicier.
Enjoy today's corn recipes.
STEAMED CORN6 ears corn (husked), 2 tbsps granulated sugar, 1 tbsp lemon juice, 1 tsp salt.
Fill a pot full of water and bring it to boil. Stir in the sugar, lemon juice, and salt. Place the corn into the boiling water. Let the water return to a boil. Once boiling again, cover with a lid and turn off the heat. Cook the corn for 8-10 minutes or until tender.
SWEET CORN RELISH10 fresh ears of sweet yellow corn (husks and silk removed, slice kernels off the cob with a sharp knife), 2 large red bell peppers (cored and finely chopped), 2 large green bell peppers (cored and finely chopped), 8 ribs celery (finely chopped), 1 large yellow or sweet onion (finely chopped), 4 cups apple cider vinegar, 2 cups sugar, 1 tbsp ground mustard, 3 tsps salt.
Combine all the ingredients in a pot and bring to a boil, stirring until the sugar is dissolved. Reduce the heat to medium and simmer uncovered for about 20 minutes until the vegetables are tender. Ladle the relish into hot sterilized jars and seal with lids. Process the jars in a water bath for 10 minutes. Keep stored in a dark, cool place. Will keep at least one year. Once opened, store in the fridge for up to two months. Makes approximately 8 pints. Wait a week or two before eating the relish to allow time for the vinegar to mellow out. Use it on hamburgers, hot dogs, sandwiches, fish, serve it with roasted chicken or mix with tomatoes/onions/cilantro for a Summer salad.
CORN PUDDING RECIPE5 large eggs, ⅓ cup butter (melted and slightly cooled), ¼ cup white sugar, ½ cup milk, ¼ cup cornstarch,1 ½ cups steamed or cooked corn or 1 can of kernel corn, 2 (14.75 ounce) cans cream-style corn.
Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Grease a 2-quart casserole dish. Whisk eggs lightly in a large bowl. Add milk, melted butter, sugar, and cornstarch; whisk until well combined. Stir in drained corn and cream-style corn until fully blended. Pour mixture into the prepared casserole dish. Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown, about 1 hour.
CORN FRITTERS3 cups oil for frying, 1 cup sifted all-purpose flour, 1 tsp baking powder, ½ tsp salt, ¼ tsp white sugar, 1 large egg (lightly beaten), ½ cup milk, 1 tbsp shortening (melted), 1 12-ounce can whole kernel corn (drained).
Heat oil in a heavy pot or deep fryer to 365 degrees. Combine flour, baking powder, salt and sugar in a medium bowl. Beat egg, milk and melted shortening together in a small bowl. Stir egg mixture into flour mixture. Stir in corn. Working in batches, drop fritter batter by spoonful into the hot oil. Fry until golden. Remove fritters with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels.
BARBECUE GRILLED "CORN RIBS"BBQ Seasoning Blend: 2 tbsps chili powder, 1 tsp smoked paprika, 1 tsp packed light brown sugar, 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper, salt.
BBQ Sauce: 1 cup ketchup, 1 cup apple cider vinegar,1 /4 cup yellow mustard, 3 tbsps packed light brown sugar, 1/2 tsp hot sauce, salt.
Corn Ribs: 4 ears corn (shucked), Canola or vegetable oil (for the grill grates), 1 scallion (thinly sliced).
For the BBQ seasoning blend: Stir to combine the chili powder, smoked paprika, brown sugar, cayenne pepper and 1 tsp salt in a small bowl.
For the BBQ sauce: Whisk together the ketchup, apple cider vinegar, mustard, brown sugar, hot sauce, 1 tsp salt and 1 tbsp of the BBQ seasoning blend in a small saucepan over medium-high heat. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to medium and simmer until the sauce has reduced and thickened, 10 to 12 minutes.
For the corn ribs: Using a large chef's knife and a large steady cutting board, cut off the ends of the corn cobs to make them flat. Using your hands, break the cobs in half crosswise. Stand a cob on one flat end and carefully and slowly cut down through the core, rocking the knife back and forth if necessary, to split the cob in half lengthwise. Repeat with all the cobs. Lay a split corn cob on its flat side on the cutting board and cut lengthwise through the cob, pressing down and rocking the knife back and forth if necessary, to make 2 long corn ribs. Repeat with the remaining cob halves. (You should have 32 ribs total.) Place on a rimmed baking sheet and set aside.
Prepare a grill for medium-high heat and lightly oil the grates. Sprinkle the corn ribs with 1 tablespoon of the seasoning blend. Brush the ribs with 1/2 cup BBQ sauce. Place the corn, cut-side down, on the grill and close the lid. Cook until the cut edges are beginning to char and caramelize, about 8 minutes. Flip the ribs to the second cut side, close the grill lid and cook until the edges are caramelized and the corn kernels are crisp-tender, another 6 to 8 minutes. Transfer the corn to a platter. Brush with more sauce and season with a pinch of the BBQ seasoning blend (reserve the remaining blend for another use). Sprinkle the scallions and serve with the remaining BBQ sauce.

title: Annual challenge urges folks to eat local veggies
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Annual challenge urges folks to eat local veggies

 July 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 489
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Put down your prepackaged and processed foods, start your "endives" and head out for some locally made foods as the 16th annual Buy Local Challenge gets underway.The Southern Maryland Agricultural Commission, a division of the Tri-County Council for Southern Maryland, invites Marylanders to support, celebrate and shop everything Maryland grown, harvested, produced, hand-crafted and homemade by area farms, producers, artisans and farm-hosted fun.
The St. Mary's County commissioners presented a proclamation July 16 recognizing the event.
"Agriculture is our life and this time of year is really special to us as people and to the commissions we serve on because it gives us a really good opportunity to connect local producers to local consumers," Southern Maryland Agricultural Development Commission Chairperson Mary Wood said, referring to herself and husband Joe, who serves on the Agriculture and Seafood Advisory Council.
St. Mary's Economic Development Agriculture and Seafood Division Manager Priscilla Leitch added that the annual challenge offers "a lot of opportunities to buy local in St. Mary's County," and added that the county's economic development department sponsors three farmers markets in the county — The Barns at Newmarket in Mechanicsville, The California Farmer's Market in the BAE parking lot, and the Home Grown Farm Market in Lexington Park.
Leitch added there are also lots of farm stands as well as the Loveville produce auction, which are "great opportunities to buy local for Buy Local Challenge Week and throughout the year."
The annual event, which is a state initiative where individuals are encouraged to eat at least one locally grown item every day of the week, runs July 19 to 28.
Southern Maryland Agriculture Development Commission Director Shelby Watson-Hampton said agriculture is still the state's No. 1 industry, which she said "is very evident here in St. Mary's County and across Southern Maryland."
The challenge wraps up with a family-friendly Buy Local Challenge Celebration from 5 to 8 p.m. Monday, July 29, at Serenity Farms in Benedict.
The event will feature up to 50 vendors offering farm-raised meats and dairy products, fruits and veggies, flowers, local oysters, baked goods, jams and pickles, honey, farm made soaps and scents. Visitors can also discover creative local arts and crafts, and artisanal beverages from wineries, distilleries and breweries.
There will also be local food trucks, a hospitality tent, live entertainment by Chaptico Songworks, an oyster tasting experience, door prizes, carriage rides with the Suttler Post Farm Clydesdales, pony rides, a petting farm and face painting.
Admission is $5 for ages 7 and older and includes an ice-filled insulated tote bag.
"We have found over the years on our own farm that there is a growing interest in our community of local consumers to not only have locally produced agricultural food products," Wood said, "but to get to know the farmers that grow them. The Buy Local week is a really good time to make that happen."
For more information on the Buy Local Challenge or to purchase tickets for the celebration event, go to buylocalchallenge.com.

title: Best in show: 4-H kids work hard to raise, ready animals for fair
author: Lilly Howard Special to the Whig
content:
Best in show: 4-H kids work hard to raise, ready animals for fair

 July 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lilly Howard Special to the Whig | Section: News 
 
 747
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FAIR HILL — In the months leading up to the Cecil County Fair, 4-H members can be found working hard, raising and training their animals to get them ready for the fair.At the fair, the animals are one of the main attractions, housed in the fairgrounds' barns in between the various competitions and showings that take place throughout fair week.
Tails and Trails 4-H club worked together this year to try something new: raising and showing 100 meat chickens.
"They eat and drink a whole lot more than you would ever imagine at this point. We bought a bag of feed yesterday and we are almost out of it," 4-H member Katilyn Carter said.
Carter, 16, is showing meat goats, meat chickens, and doing herdsmen with her pony. Herdsmen entails keeping your animal at the fair all week, ensuring they are fed, watered, healthy and clean, with a corresponding informational board to educate the public and judges about your animal.
To prepare her meat chickens, Carter washes them two to three days before the show to ensure they have a natural oily shine. This paid off, as her chickens won first and second place ribbons at the fair over the weekend.
"It's going to sound really funny, but you actually blow dry them. You want them to be really fluffy…You just want them to look like little chunk balls of fluff and meat," said Carter about preparing her chickens for show day.
In showmanship competitions, you must be very knowledgeable about your animal in order to show the judges that you put in the work to be successful, according to Carter. The 4-H member must present their animal to the best of their ability, demonstrating cleanliness and knowledge on what they eat, their parts, their breed and more, said former 4-H member and long-time judge Carolyn Lawrence.
For meat goats, who are bred and raised to become a meal on someone's plate, the 4-H members start working with them once they are born in January or March. A few weeks later, once they're weaned from their mothers they start training them to walk with a halter and lead line, taking them on mile long walks several times a week, according to Libby Kondracki, Tails and Trails leader.
When it comes to show day at the fair, Carter washes her goat in the morning and covers him to ensure he stays clean white. Since they're raised for meat, she then blow dries the animals to get them looking as fluffy as possible. According to county fair regulations, no baby powder, artificial coloring, or adhesives like hairspray can be used on the animals.
"The power in fitting your animal, and knowing how to fit your animal and showing your animal to make it to where you know you're showing this animal the best you can to its fullest potential. You really have to work with your goat," Carter said.
Before the fair, members get together at least twice a week and meet up as a show team and prepare together. Many of the 4-H parent leaders were 4-H members themselves when they were growing up. And many current members plan to stay involved after they age out at 18 years old to continue to give back to the community that helped shape them.
"I really love teaching them," said Carter about helping teach younger 4-H'ers. "Because they're going to be, you know, when I'm done in two more years, they're going to be the ones that are taking over. So you really want them to be the mentor you kids that you were to them."
Although many 4-H members compete against each other at the Cecil County Fair, they are all a team at the end of the day.
"When one wins, we all win," said Carter.
In addition to the camaraderie 4-H supplies, it also helps educate the public about the livestock they often consume.
Thanks to being involved in the Rising Sun 4-H Club for the past four years, Mason Gentry enjoys educating the public about his animals and their purposes. For example, he explained the importance of knowing that a Heifer is a female cow who has not been bred yet, a cow is a female cow who has been bred and had a calf, and a Steer is a male cow that's been castrated and is meant for beef.
"The goal of the fair is to educate the public about agriculture, give them an opportunity to see where the food comes from," said Mark Barczewki, 4-H Barn Stompers club leader.

title: Farm family brings Emily’s Produce 'full circle' in its 25th year
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Farm family brings Emily’s Produce 'full circle' in its 25th year

 July 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 580
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Kelly Jackson feels that everything is coming "full circle" for Emily's Produce, a family farm business that she and her husband, Paul, started 25 years ago.Their oldest daughter, Emily Wright, the namesake of the business, grew up around the farm every day as a child. Her parents, Paul and Kelly Jackson, opened a produce tent in 1999, hoping to teach their newborn daughter about the family farm's tradition.
Wright and her younger brother, Kyle Jackson, are seventh generation farmers.
When Wright went off to college at Delaware Valley University and secured a degree in agribusiness, her parents didn't pressure her to return to the family farm.
"A lot of other farm families are forced, the kids have to come back and work," Wright said. "But she made us go try things that really made us want to come back instead of just having to come back."
Wright greatly appreciated that freedom of choice. She worked at the Department of Natural Resources after college, soon realizing that an office job wasn't a fit. She "needed to be outside, hands in the dirt."
"There's nothing like working with your family," Wright said. She committed last year to working full-time at Emily's Produce.
Wright and her brother work in tandem, with Wright "on the scene" in the farm store and handling social media, while Kyle is "behind the scenes," she said. Emily's Produce has around 100 acres of fruits and vegetables and about 800 additional acres, which Kyle, currently a student at the University of Maryland, and his father work on, mainly as grain farmers.
Open six days a week on Church Creek Road, Emily's Produce is a haven for customers who want to shop local and farm-to-table.
In addition to the locally-grown produce, the business has homemade baked goods and desserts, a deli kitchen and a flower field. It offers a "U-Pick" season, where customers can pick their own strawberries, blackberries, blueberries, pumpkins and flowers when the fields and patches are in season.
Wright, who got married last year, recently discovered the popularity of the farm's wildflower patch for weddings. Her wedding flowers were all from the farm, and with around 50 varieties, it's been a hit with wedding vendors.
"It's that keeping your finger on the pulse of what people want," Kelly Jackson said. "I don't think maybe 10 years ago, people wanted wildflowers … for their wedding. But now it's whimsical, it's cool … and it supports local farmers."
Two-and-a-half decades later, the farm stand has grown "organically," Jackson said, from its humble beginnings as a small tent on the side of the road. And in the landmark 25th year, the seventh generation is taking leadership in operating the business.
Jackson is excited for what Kyle will bring to the farm as he enters his junior year in college, studying agricultural business and management.
"We've never been able to grow tree fruit, just because of the geography and the land and the soil," she said. "Now that he's involved and he's studying agriculture, we're relying on him to be the consultation to us, the voice of what's new. I think whatever is new, Kyle will be a part of."
The involvement from both Kyle and Emily has been a relief and joy to Kelly and Paul Jackson, the mother said. She admitted she was worried her children might not return to continue the family tradition, though that didn't change her perspective on giving them the space and time to explore for themselves.
"We're doing our happy dance this year," Kelly Jackson said.

title: Queen Anne's moves 11 parcels toward ag conservancy
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's moves 11 parcels toward ag conservancy

 August 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 432
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Queen Anne's County Commissioners approved 11 new easement applicants to be submitted for Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation Foundation (MALPF) Board of Trustees approval and appraisal during a public hearing July 23.The Queen Anne's County Agricultural Preservation Advisory Board gave favorable recommendations to the county commissioners and a public hearing was held in submission of 11 new Agricultural Preservation Easement property applications.
The Queen Anne's County Soil Conservation District submitted a total of 16 applications for funding, five of which have already had public hearings, according to Donna Landis-Smith, Soil Conservation specialist.
Sixiteen property applications totaling 2,572 acres are being submitted for FY 25-26 funding, she said.
Due to low budgets, Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation Foundation (MALPF) Board of Trustees voted to combine two fiscal years of funding and the Soil Conservancy will not be taking any preservation applications in 2025, Landis-Smith said.
If one single year cycle was done, the state initial allocation would only be about $500,000, she said, "And we're not going to do much with that."
This year the soil conservation district budget started at $1.7 million and with the combined budget, the FY26 projected budget looks to be about $1.4 million, she said.
Projecting appraisal values and asking prices, with the $1.4 million budget and state match, the soil conservation estimates four or five of the farms will be preserved, she said.
The properties will be appraised in the fall of 2025, with offers expected no earlier than 2026, Landis-Smith said.
Landis-Smith noted the QAC County Commissioners have "progressively and consistently" pledged $1.3 million of county money from the agricultural transfer tax, solar fees, and personal property tax.
The QAC Soil Conservation is expected to return to the QAC County Commissioners in January seeking funding.
Landis-Smith also noted goals put out by the federal government and state governors to have 30 percent of the agricultural land in the United States to be preserved by 2030 and 40 percent of agricultural land preserved by 2040.
Due to consistent dedication to land conservation, the county is currently a whopping 16 years ahead of federal agricultural conservation mandates, she said.
Through the 10 farm easements funded last year, the county was able to preserve 1,254 acres, according to Landis-Smith and the county's total agricultural land preservation now exceeds 90,000 acres.
"We are now at 43 percent of our county's agricultural land…We've made tremendous strides," she said.
Land preservation is a voluntary program, Landis-Smith said, and for property owners looking for tax benefits, not necessarily the income, the county can assist with facilitated donated easement.
"We will guide them in the right direction," she said.
More information about Queen Anne's Soil Conservation can be found at qac.org.

The QAC Soil Conservation is expected to return to the QAC County Commissioners in January seeking funding.
Landis-Smith also noted goals put out by the federal government and state governors to have 30 percent of the agricultural land in the United States to be preserved by 2030 and 40 percent of agricultural land preserved by 2040.
Due to consistent dedication to land conservation, the county is currently a whopping 16 years ahead of federal agricultural conservation mandates, she said.
Through the 10 farm easements funded last year, the county was able to preserve 1,254 acres, according to Landis-Smith and the county's total agricultural land preservation now exceeds 90,000 acres.
"We are now at 43 percent of our county's agricultural land…We've made tremendous strides," she said.
Land preservation is a voluntary program, Landis-Smith said, and for property owners looking for tax benefits, not necessarily the income, the county can assist with facilitated donated easement.
"We will guide them in the right direction," she said.
More information about Queen Anne's Soil Conservation can be found at qac.org.

title: How sweet it is: MD Food Bank hosts sweet corn gleaning
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
How sweet it is: MD Food Bank hosts sweet corn gleaning

 August 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 428
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Blazing through the summer heat, volunteers are taking to fields to collect harvests and ensure a community bounty for fellow Marylanders through the Maryland Farm to Food Bank Program.Recently, sweet corn gleanings at Mason Farms in Centreville brought in eight bins of corn and multiple volunteers over the course of two days in July, showcasing the value of hard work, community and the origin of food as it makes its way to the table.
One out of three Marylanders are now facing food insecurity, according to Amy Cawley, Farm to Food Bank manager, who has been coordinating this program with local farmers for many years, and noted this has been the highest rate of food insecurity in her 12 years with the food bank.
"Food insecurity is a 24/7 issue," she said.
Gleaning is a true community partnership that entails farmers donating unharvested crops and volunteers dutifully collecting to ensure fresh produce for food banks, Cawley said.
Cultivating a good relationship with farmers statewide, the Maryland Food Bank works with about 50 farms per year, many of which are located on the Eastern Shore due to its agricultural center location, she said.
Produce collected through the gleanings is mainly distributed from the food bank's Salisbury Eastern Shore location in addition to other food pantries, according to Cawley.
Peak gleaning time is July through Labor Day with a variety of produce collected including sweet corn, peaches and tomatoes, she said.
The food bank has three avenues for acquiring produce; gleaning, donations and purchasing and unfortunately, purchasing is the most common, Cawley said.
With price increases, the food bank now has to work harder than ever to stretch a dollar and any amount of assistance, whether volunteer service or monetary donation, is tremendously appreciated.
"No matter how big or small," she said.
Gleaning is an excellent educational opportunity for all ages to discover the manner of where their food is grown and harvested, according to Cawley.
"I love it when families come out, it is educational for everyone," she said.
Gleaning shifts are typically an hour or two at the maximum. No experience is necessary and there is no age limit to gleaning, but children under the age of 16 must be accompanied by an adult.
Gleaning event announcements are often short notice and volunteers can sign up to receive notifications through the volunteer section of the Maryland Food Bank website.
Understanding gleaning field work isn't for everyone, volunteers are also encouraged to lend a hand at community food pantry locations.
"Gleaning is just a small way you can help," Cawley said.
More information including ways to give can be found at www.mdfoodbank.org.

title: 64th Thresherman Show puts history on display
author: Tom McCall
content:
64th Thresherman Show puts history on display

 August 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 348
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — History, sweat and steam combined at the 64th annual Eastern Shore Threshermen Show, which featured wheat threshing demonstrations, steam engines and a parade of antique tractors.On Saturday, families wandered around eating freshly churned ice cream and funnel cakes as church groups sat beneath tents.
Trisha L. Todd, president of the Eastern Shore Thresherman and Collectors Association, said, "We are trying to preserve our American agricultural heritage through demonstrations. We have equipment and show people how farming was done years ago, bring back by-gone days."
The event is entirely run by volunteers.
Bob Miller, of Nice Farms Creamery, makes fresh ice cream from his own Jersey cows near the fairgrounds. His engine-run ice cream maker was loud, attracting a crowd.
"We like being a part of this because it keeps agricultural heritage alive," Miller said. "This is how the old timers used to make ice cream with their parents. Salt and ice will always work."
History was the main emphasis of the day, as evidenced by several demonstrations and displays.
In another corner of the grounds, Dale Foxwell had everything from cannon, to a military campsie to pistols on display — all from the Civil War era.
"This is a living history display trying to give people a little bit of an idea of some of the firearms used during the war between the states period," Foxwell said.
People interested in mechanics and farm machines were met with an array of vintages and manufacturers, like John Deere and Case. There were dozens of tractors in rows. People took the time to inspect them and talk about each part that made up the whole machine.
There was even Smokey Joe Railroad, one the few steam-powered mini trains left in the country. This 1961-built miniature steam engine ran a loop, tooted its steam whistle and delighted children of all ages.
Todd Kerchner, the train's engineer, said, "I started doing this when I was 12 or 13. Today we will make hundreds of runs. We go all day."
John Geib, who ran the train every other loop, said, "I love the smiles. They love coming back. They hate getting off."

title: Sharing the bounty: Delaware church's garden provides free vegetables to the community
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Sharing the bounty: Delaware church's garden provides free vegetables to the community

 August 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 396
 Words 

 Read News Document

 What started as a pandemic project continues to feed dozens of Newarkers each week during the summer.Every Saturday morning, Grace Church on Paper Mill Road sets up a farm stand and distributes free produce grown in a large garden behind the church.
The vegetables are available free of charge to anyone who stops by, with no income requirements or proof of need required.
"It's a really neat thing that we do," Pastor Andrew Pritchett said. "It gives our church a way to connect with our community in a pretty unique way."
Church members started the garden in spring 2020 as a way to do outreach to the community during the COVID-19 shutdown. Initially, they delivered the veggies to neighborhoods surrounding the church, but that proved to be too labor intensive, so they switched to the weekly farm stand.
Approximately 10 people help plant the garden each year, and a core group of six to eight volunteers maintain it throughout the summer.
The project is led by longtime church member Karen Dunn, who said she learned her gardening skills from her father. She added that she enjoys meeting the people who come to pick up vegetables every week.
"It's really exciting and it's really special," Dunn said. "The main reason we wanted to do it was to reach out to the community, get to know people and let them get to know us. That is really, really neat. We get to pray for people, we get to invite them to the church."
Pritchett said the garden and farm stand are an important resource for the community during a time of rising food prices.
"Is it going to solve everybody's problems? No, but it might solve somebody's problems," he said. "It might get somebody a healthy meal."
Kelly Pritchett, the pastor's wife, said she enjoys getting to know the regular "customers" who stop by every week.
"We're trying to build relationships over time," she said. "Some of them will share about their lives and ask us to maybe pray for someone who is sick or something like that. It's nice to get to build those relationships."
Karen Weber, another longtime church member, also enjoys running the farm stand.
"We just want to bless the community in some way," Weber said. "That's what churches should do."
Grace Church's farm stand, located in the church parking lot at 355 Paper Mill Road, is open every Saturday from 9 a.m. to 11:30 a.m.

title: Giving to the community — teaching the next generation
author: Staff Writer
content:
Giving to the community — teaching the next generation

 August 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 937
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Henry and Beth Covington have a long history in Queen Anne's County. Both of their families arrived in the United States in the 1700's. Eventually, the Covingtons' settled in Queen Anne's County. Beth's ancestors landed on the Eastern Shore of Virginia and migrated to Mississippi.Henry's great-grandfather, also called Henry, was a Methodist minister at three local churches, Burrisville, Starr, and Salem near Church Hill. His son (Henry's grandfather), Edward, was a preacher and tenant farmer. Henry's dad, Henry Sr., preached for a while, but then began a career with New York Life Insurance.
In 1979, Henry Sr. and his wife Kathryn, bought the Peace and Plenty Farm from the Wright family and started farming. Henry Sr. always said there were two things his father approved of during the year other than work and going to church; attending the 4-H fair and riding to Rehoboth Beach for the day! To get there, all nine kids piled in the back of a 6-wheel truck filled with straw! Henry's mother, Kathryn, was raised on the Richard family farm near Templeville, along with her 12 siblings.
Beth was born in Mississippi where her maternal grandparents, the Dilworths, farmed. She moved to Kent Island at the age of 4, when her dad began working for Maryland DNR. Beth's family also had their faith, it was a big part of growing up and they attended church regularly. After graduating from Chesapeake College, Beth attended the University of Maryland Dental School, earning her degree in dental hygiene.
Henry graduated from the University of Delaware with a degree in Plant Science. Spring of his junior year, he attended a semester at Chesapeake College and met Beth. Henry was recruited by some high school friends at Chesapeake to play baseball. At one baseball practice, Henry noticed one of the softball players. She was wearing red shorts and Henry asked one of his teammates "who is that girl in the red shorts?". Henry was told it was Beth, his friend Earl's little sister. Beth mentioned "since she was a couple years younger than her brother, no one noticed her until college!". After the chance meeting at baseball and softball practice, they dated and were married in 1982.
In 1980, Henry started working at Agrico and Crop Production Services, selling fertilizer and Pioneer seed. Henry had his first opportunity to rent a farm on his own from Gladys Cahall. His grandmother was Cahall's Sunday school teacher so she knew Henry's family very well.
Henry enjoyed farming with his dad for many years. After 10 years, Henry became a full time Pioneer sales rep while also farming over 1300 acres. Henry and Beth dreamed of owning their own farm, and in 2001 that dream came true. They bought a farm near Centreville, and named it Broadland. After 30 years, Henry retired from the seed business in 2021. A good friend, Anton Roe now continues the business as a local Pioneer sales rep. Henry and Beth continue to farm.
Henry and Beth have three children; Will, Ben, and Sarah. Will graduated from Washington and Lee University and is now working as a systems engineer for Communications Electronics Systems Integrated. Ben graduated from Iowa State University. He works for the University and John Deere as an agricultural and biosystems engineer. Sarah graduated from the University of Richmond with a degree in Biology. Sarah teaches biology at Queen Anne's County High School.
Beth had worked off the farm as a part-time dental hygienist for 38 years. This allowed her to take care of the kids and help on the farm. Their three kids were actively involved in 4-H, showing pigs, steers, and rabbits, and entering indoor exhibits. Henry was recruited by Paul Gunther to help with the open farm crops at the fair and to assist the Godfreys with open vegetables. Henry and Beth gladly did this for over 30 years.
After the kids had all left home and Beth retired as a dental hygienist, she had time to work on one of her hobbies, quilting. She said, "My grandmother sewed and taught me to sew. I started out making doll clothes and then made clothes for myself, and later, my kids. After the kids left home, I started to quilt". Beth has been generous in her quilting talents, giving quilts as gifts and donating them to people in need.
About the same time Henry started collecting old tractors. His first was a 1958 John Deere 730. The 730 was one of his favorite childhood toys and 1958 was the year in which he was born. At some point Beth mentioned she would like to have a Farmall cub, like the one she remembered Mr. Ernest Porter owning. Henry found a 1960 cub right away (the same year she was born!) Mr. Ernest Porter was a wonderful Christian man who was very dear to both Henry and Beth. Mr. Ernest Porter was a big influence in Henry's life. "He never seemed to get upset" Henry said. He was also a faithful member of Beth's church on Kent Island.
Henry and Beth consider themselves so very blessed to have had all the experiences that come with living in our farming community. They have thoroughly enjoyed supporting and serving others through their church, 4-H, and school activities. Henry said with a smile "people are generally good and giving back to your community keeps our community close". He said "my father never missed a 4-H Fair up until his passing and I feel the same way. The fair is a good way to stay involved and see people…Everyone should give some of their time to their community. That's how we teach the next generation."

title: County Fair animals teach responsibility to students

County Fair animals teach responsibility to students

 August 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 DENTON — Hundreds attended the family-friendly Caroline/Dorchester County Fair last week, where aimals, corn on the cob, and country music filled the Caroline County 4-H Park.There was a small city of inflatables that was filled with delighted children. For older kids, there was a mechanical bull.
The Reger Pavilion had live music. Everything from the old-timey country sound of the Jone's Brothers to the foot stomping Amish Outlaws and '80s-inflected The Reagan Years.
There were lots of competitions to show younger community members' efforts to raise dairy cows, goats, swines, horses, rabbits and beef.
Jody Neal, Caroline County FFA Advisor and ag teacher at Caroline Career and Technology Center had lots of students participating in fair contests.
"I have nine kids showing animals today. I have kids showing sheep, swine, market goats and breed goats," Neal said.
The students raise their animals for a year leading up to the fair. After all that effort, the animals ended up at the livestock auction on Saturday night. This sale funds the students' project for next year. The pork can go back into the school system and is served in the lunch line.
Skyler Blunt, a participant in the swine competition, said it was rewarding to show a year's worth of work.
"I have two Hereford barrows and one Yorkshire gilt," Blunt said. "The best part is the accomplishment that the fair brings you and getting to show people your project for the year."
Emma Boyle, 18, who had just graduated from high school, said, "I am showing two crossbred pigs. I have been doing this since I was five. I love it. This is my last year. My pigs are named Buzz and Woody."
Barbara Carrow, who was announcing the swine show, is co-leader of Pure Country 4-H Club. She has 62 kids in her Caroline County chapter. They showed at least 50 swine at the contest.
"I love working with young people, and I love animals. It teaches them responsibility and how to interact with adults other people. It gives them confidence," Carrow said.
Wandering in the crowd was a princess — the Dairy Princess.
Caroline Kimball of Queen Anne's County High School wears a sash and a tiara.
"I am the Eastern Shore Dairy Princess because I represent the dairy industry. I like educating people about the dairy industry. You can add a dairy product to all three meals of the day. I like chocolate milk after practice. I want to major in animal science," Kimball said.
The judge, Gabe Zepp of Carroll County, picked first, second and third place winners. With every participant, win or lose, he offered instruction on how to improve.
"I want to see these hogs with their heads up at all times. Head placement. I want to see that they are comfortable with a whip. Nice and in control of the hog," Zepp said.
Navonne Owen, 4-H Educator for Caroline County, said, "They have all worked so hard on their projects and this is the time to shine. They are all doing an excellent job. They are resilient and flexible and they are learning so many life skills from the project. It will help them in the future."

title: Fair dedicated to Michael Cohey Sr.
author: DOUG BISHOP Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Fair dedicated to Michael Cohey Sr.

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 462
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Monday evening, Aug. 12, as part of the Queen Anne's County 4-H Fair opening ceremonies, held annually at the 4-H Park in Centreville, lifelong Queen Anne's resident, and past Farm Bureau President Michael Cohey Sr. was recognized and honored to have this year's fair dedicated to him. This year is the 82nd annual Queen Anne's County Fair, which began in 1942, and is ranked as one of the top county fairs in the state of Maryland, running six-days, Monday through Saturday evening.Born and raised on the family farm, just north of Church Hill, Cohey, was presented a plaque by Queen Anne's County Fair Chair Laura Leager, recognizing his lifetime of service to the agricultural community.
Cohey attended and graduated from the former Charlotte Hall Military Academy (on a senatorial scholarship) in St. Mary's County before attending Chesapeake College as a general studies major for two years. Afterward, he farmed with his father, and on his own, first as a dairy farmer, and later transitioning completely to grain farming.
Later, he took a long-time job with Pioneer Hybrid Seed Company where he served as a salesman until retiring two years ago, at the age of 70. He's still an active farmer.
Cohey has served as past president of the Queen Anne's County Farm Bureau.
In 1992, the Cohey family lost their only son, the late Michael Cohey Jr. at the age of 9. Michael Jr. contracted a rare form of childhood cancer. Before the cancer, Michael Jr. would attend the fair with his father, as they manned the Pioneer Seed booth. From his youngest age, Michael Jr. learned to love the fair and made many friends there. He developed a love for rabbits and had hoped to show rabbits when he became a full-fledged 4-H member when he turned 8 years old.
The cancer prevented Michael Jr. from achieving that dream.
Since his death, his father has sponsored two annual 4-H youth awards: sponsoring the rabbit bred and owned class at the county fair and the annual Michael Cohey Jr. Memorial Award to the Clover (under 8 years old) 4-H child who writes the most outstanding 4-H personal experience story each year. Those awards have been presented for 30-plus years to more than 60 children involved in 4-H.
Had Michael Jr. survived the cancer, he would now be 41-years old.
Two-years ago, the father purchased the new rabbit shed that stores all of the supplies and equipment that the county fair rabbit show needs to operate.
The honor of the fair being dedicated to individuals began in 1976 and has been awarded to more than 40 people from the county and many local organizations that have contributed substantially to the farming and welfare of the community. in general. Cohey said, "I am very, very honored to receive this recognition."

title: Digging and cooking sweet potatoes
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Digging and cooking sweet potatoes

 October 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1317
 Words 

 Read News Document

 One of the last large gardening jobs to do when I was young was to dig those sweet potatoes.My parents would gently loosen the soil around the plants and take a peek at the plants whose leaves were slightly yellow and turning back. These were the signs the potatoes were ready to dig. The baskets for storage were already pulled out and waiting for the big day.
My family enjoyed growing sweet potatoes, as once planted they required very little attention and were drought tolerant. They grew in their own space — not sprouting and growing wildly. We ate a lot of both the white potato and the sweet potato, a major staple on the winter dinner table.
The Saturday for digging was chosen, the family notified, the tractor with attached farm wagon readied, and the shed prepared for storage next to the crop of white potatoes already completed.
The pickup trucks lined the lane as family and friends arrived for the digging. After several cups of Ms. Laura's coffee, the crew began working.
My sister and I were assigned the job of "getting the dinner ready." This was not a dinner — it was a small banquet. Mom had made two pots of soup. One was homemade vegetable beef, and the other was lima bean soup. Waiting to be baked were several dozens of homemade biscuits.
I wanted to get outside to help, but oh no, my sister needed help with the dishes. No paper plates or bowls could be found on West Line Road.
Let's enjoy these fresh dug sweet potatoes with some old and new recipes.
SWEET POTATO CHIPS2 large sweet potatoes, 2 tbsp olive oil, 1/4 tsp sea salt.
Preheat the oven to 250 degrees and position the oven rack in the center of the oven. Rinse and dry your sweet potatoes thoroughly and slice them as uniformly thin as possible (1/8 inch thick slices). If you have a mandolin, use it. Otherwise, use a very sharp knife to get these uniformly thin. Know that chips that are too thick in parts won't crisp up all the way. Still delicious, just not "chip" crispiness. Toss slices in a touch of olive oil to lightly coat, then sprinkle with salt.
Lay out in a single layer on a parchment-lined baking sheet and bake for about 1 hour 30 minutes to 1 hour 45 minutes, flipping chips once at halfway point to ensure even cooking. Thickness of slices will impact cooking time. Check at 10-minute intervals during the second hour of cooking to ensure they aren't burning. Remove once crisp and golden brown. Some may feel a little tender in the middle but take them out and let them rest for 10 minutes or so to crisp up before sampling. Serve immediately.
SWEET POTATO PANCAKES1 3/4 cup all-purpose flour, 2 tsp baking powder, 1/2 tsp baking soda, 2 tbsp packed brown sugar, 1 tsp kosher salt, 1 tsp cinnamon, 1/4 tsp ground nutmeg, 1/4 tsp ground ginger, 1 3/4 cup buttermilk, 2 small sweet potatoes (roasted and pureed until smooth), 2 large eggs, 1 tsp pure vanilla extract, butter for cooking and serving.
In a large bowl, whisk together flour, baking powder, baking soda, brown sugar, salt, cinnamon, nutmeg and ginger. In a separate bowl, whisk together buttermilk and sweet potato puree, then add eggs and vanilla. Add wet ingredients to dry ingredients and stir with a wooden spoon until just combined. Melt butter in a large nonstick skillet or griddle over medium heat. When butter is foamy, reduce heat to medium-low and ladle a scant ½ cup pancake batter into the skillet. Cook until bubbles start to form in batter and the pancake is golden underneath, about 3 minutes, then flip and cook the other side until golden, another 3 minutes. Serve with more butter, toasted pecans and maple syrup.
SWEET POTATO CASSEROLE2 lb. sweet potatoes, extra virgin olive oil for drizzling, Kosher salt, 1/2 cup unsalted butter (room temperature) plus more for pan, 1 cup granulated sugar, 2 large eggs (beaten to blend), 1 tsp pure vanilla extract. BROWN SUGAR CRUST: 1/2 cup chopped raw pecans, 1/2 cup packed light brown sugar, 1/4 cup all-purpose flour, 1/2 tsp kosher salt, 2 tbsp unsalted butter (melted).
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees and line a 11-by-7-inch (or 2-quart) baking dish with foil. Rinse and scrub potatoes to dislodge any dirt, then pat dry. Using a fork, poke holes all over the potatoes. Drizzle with oil; season all over with salt. Transfer potatoes to prepared pan and roast, uncovered, until cooked through and flesh is easily pierced with a fork or paring knife, 60 to 65 minutes. Transfer potatoes to a large heatproof bowl. Discard foil and grease pan with butter. Reduce oven temperature to 375 degrees. When potatoes are cool enough to handle, remove skins.
In the large bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the whisk attachment (or in a large bowl, using an electric mixer), beat potatoes and granulated sugar on medium speed until sugar is incorporated and potatoes are mashed. Add butter and beat until incorporated and fluffy, about 2 minutes. Add eggs, vanilla, and 3/4 teaspoon salt and beat until mixture is almost doubled in volume, about 5 minutes. Pour mixture into the prepared pan and spread with a spatula. Bake the casserole until the center is set but slightly jiggly and edges are beginning to brown, about 35 minutes. Let cool slightly.
BROWN SUGAR CRUST: Meanwhile, in a medium bowl, combine pecans, brown sugar, flour, and salt, breaking up any clumps of sugar with your fingers. Drizzle in butter and toss with a fork until combined. Sprinkle brown sugar mixture over potatoes. Continue to bake the casserole until the crust is firm and starts to brown, about 10 minutes more. Let cool for 10 minutes before serving.
SWEET POTATO BISCUITS9 ounces all-purpose flour, 1 tbsp baking powder, 2 tsp kosher salt, 1/2 tsp baking soda, 4 ounces cold unsalted butter cut into 1/2-inch cubes, 9 ounces sweet potato purée from one large sweet potato, 3 ounces milk.
Adjust oven rack to lower-middle position and preheat to 400 degrees. Sift flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt into a medium bowl, then whisk until well combined (this may take up to 1 minute). Add the butter, toss to break up the pieces, and smash each cube flat. Continue smashing and rubbing until the butter has mostly disappeared into a floury mix, although a few larger, Cheerio-sized pieces may remain.
This can also be done with 4 or 5 pulses in a food processor, just take care not to overdo it. The prepared mix can be refrigerated up to 3 weeks in an airtight container, then used as directed below. Mash the sweet potato purée and milk together with a fork, or combine with an immersion blender until perfectly smooth. Add to the dry mix in a large bowl, and fold with a flexible spatula until fully absorbed. The dough will seem rather crumbly and dry at first, but keep mixing until it finally comes together. Once the dough forms a rough ball, turn out onto a lightly floured surface. With your bare hands, gently pat the dough into a squarish shape about 1/2-inch thick, then fold in half; repeat twice more for a total of 3 folds, using only enough flour to keep your hands from sticking.
Finish by patting the dough to a thickness of 3/4 inch. If needed, dust away any excess flour, then cut into 1 3/4-inch rounds and arrange in a 10-inch cast iron skillet. Gather scraps into a ball, pat and fold a single time, then cut as many more biscuits as you can. The final round of scraps can be gathered and shaped into a single biscuit by hand. Bake until the biscuits are well-risen and golden brown, about 25 minutes (or longer if cut thicker than 3/4-inch). Let the biscuits cool about 5 minutes to help set their crumb, then serve.

title: Schillinger farm family honored as QA 'Cooperator of the Year'
author: DOUG BISHOP Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Schillinger farm family honored as QA 'Cooperator of the Year'

 October 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 508
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — On Sept. 26, the annual Queen Anne's Soil Conservation District hosted its banquet to honor the top farm in the county, recognized as the "Cooperator of the Year." This year's honoree was the James D. Schillinger family, owners of Schillinger Farm Inc., located in the northeastern portion of Centreville.The award goes to a Queen Anne's County farm that is not only very successful in producing a profitable agriculture venture, but also practices a variety of sound environmental methods that help conserve the farm lands from a number of hazards. Those practices are preventing soil erosion through sediment run-offs, wetland creation, grassed waterways, riparian herbaceous cover, nutrient management, soil and water conservation planning, cover crops, no-till, and minimal tillage.
Schillinger Farm has saved 137 tons of soil — 6,475 pounds of nitrogen reduction and 342 pounds of phosphorus per year.
The banquet began with Conservation District Executive Director Tony Riggi welcoming the nearly 100 guests. The event was hosted at the Centreville American Legion, Jeff Davis Post 18. Riggi introduced Chairman of the Board Steve Freeman, who introduced a number of guests.
A hot meal was provided by volunteers from Post 18.
Following the meal, Conservation District assistant Joe Pippin read the history of the Schillinger Farm family's accomplishments — a long history that began on the western shore. Jimmy's great grandfather bought their home farm from the Baltimore Coal Company in 1881 (Papa John Produce, off of Rt. 97). They grew apples, tobacco and sweet potatoes.
With a huge market for sweet potatoes, they would sell 25,000 boxes of sweet potatoes before Thanksgiving. When Jimmy was a junior in high school, his father went to work for the State Tobacco Authority and told Jimmy it was up to him to run the farm.
"Jimmy began to expand the business by incorporating more variety of vegetables, fruits, flowers and building greenhouses on the farm. They had 36 greenhouse on the farm at one time, and 22,000 hanging baskets of flowers. . . They would sell to grocery stores like Giant Foods, and Grauls Markets," Pippin read.
Jimmy met his wife, Gina, when she came to work on the farm when she was 14. She had many jobs on the farm, including cashier, inventory and logistics, delivery driver, and security guard."
In 1987, the state began to buy some property from the farm to build the new Old Mill High School (in Millersville). It was then, as major developments began to happen in that portion of Anne Arundel County, that the Schillinger's considered moving to Queen Anne's County to continue farming. In 1995, they purchased "the Price Farm" on 301.
Since then, they have purchased a few more farms and switched their farming operation to mainly grain crop rotation of 1,100 acres while still doing some vegetables and 380 flower hanging baskets.
Sons J.D. and Brady Schillinger plan to carry on the farming operation and are currently starting their own beef herd. The Schillinger family has continued to be stewards of the land throughout the years. They are conserving the land and water with practices previously mentioned.

title: Celebrating fall apples
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Celebrating fall apples

 October 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1348
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The 32nd Annual Apple and Scrapple Festival will be held in Bridgeville, Delaware on Oct. 11 and 12. Friday starts at 4 p.m. with opening celebrations, and Saturday begins at 9 a.m. There will be something for everyone — games, rides, food, crafts, displays of old farm equipment and classic cars.The event's name comes from the two agricultural products produced in the area — apples and scrapple. This festival was named in the top 100 events in North America by the American Business Association.
This week I am doing apples and saving our scrapple recipes for my mid-winter "old fashioned hog slaughtering on the farm."
When it comes to apple pie, a Braeburn's flavor sweetens and concentrates during cooking to evoke a hint of spice, which makes it a natural pick for pie. And since Braeburns don't release much liquid during cooking, they won't lead to a runny filling or soggy pie crust.
If you want extra sweetness without the soft texture, choose Gala apples for your pie.
Granny Smiths are typically my go-to apple for baking, so I'll always have them on hand during the fall months. Their tart, citrusy flavor makes them perfect for sweet baked goods, where there's sugar in the recipe. I love using these for homemade caramel apples too.
When I was growing up, the orchards offered already picked or u-pick, and mom liked getting her own. She separated the apples into three categories: some for homemade applesauce, some for fbaking and some to eat fresh. What a wonderful smell filled the air as we canned and baked.
HOMEMADE APPLE PIEDOUBLE PIE CRUST: 2 1/2 cups all-purpose flour, 2 tbsps white granulated sugar, 1 1/2 tsps kosher salt, 1 cup unsalted butter (cold), 3/4 cups very cold water (divided). APPLE PIE FILLING: 1/2 small lemon juiced (about 1 1/2 tbsps), 3-4 whole medium to large apples (peeled, halved, cored and thinly sliced), 1/4 cup all-purpose flour, 1/2 cup light brown sugar, 1 1/2 tsps ground cinnamon, 1 tsp pure vanilla extract or 1/2 tsp vanilla paste, 1/2 tsp kosher salt, 2 tbsps sour cream, 1 large beaten egg (for egg wash).
In a large bowl, mix together the flour, sugar and salt. Using a box grater, grate the cold butter atop the flour mixture. Transfer to the freezer to chill for 10 minutes. Working quickly, and using your hands, break the butter bits into the flour until they're evenly distributed and resemble the size of teeny, small peas. Add 50% of the recommended water and mix. The mixture will be shaggy at this point. From here, add 1 tbsp of water at a time until the dough comes together. Flour your counter and dump the dough onto it. Knead a few times more until it comes together into one cohesive mass. Divide the dough, forming two discs. Wrap the discs in plastic wrap and transfer to the refrigerator to chill for at least 1 hour, ideally overnight.
Add the apple slices to a large bowl. Squeeze in the lemon juice, being sure to catch any seeds. Add the flour, brown sugar, cinnamon, vanilla extract and salt; toss until the apples are evenly coated.
Remove the first disc of dough from the refrigerator and allow it to come to room temperature for about 5 minutes. Liberally flour your work surface and rolling pin. Begin to roll the dough, being sure to rotate it every so often to avoid sticking to a 13-inch round. Wrap the dough around the rolling pin and unroll it over the pie dish. Gently fit the dough into the bottom and up the sides of the pie tin. Trim the dough around the pie tin, leaving about a 1/2-inch overhang. Recombine the scraps and set them aside. We'll use them for the lattice. Transfer the pie shell to the refrigerator while you roll out the second disc.
Remove the second disc from the fridge and repeat the rolling process. Using a knife, cut the dough into 3-inch strips. I cut as many 3-inch strips as I can. Re-roll the scraps you have set aside, too, you'll need all of the pie dough. (If at any time your pie dough becomes too soft, transfer to a cutting board and put in the fridge to chill so it's easier to work with.) Fill your pie shell with the apple filling. Lay out 5 strips of pie dough on top of the filling, leaving about 1/2-inch of space in between them. Lay the remainder of your strips running perpendicular. This will give you a good idea of how it will go. Next, fold back every strip. Start one at the top, running horizontally. and weave it under and over, rotating, each strip running vertically. Repeat this process until you've worked your way through every strip
Trim the edges of the strips, being sure to leave about 1-inch overhang. Going all the way around, tuck the edges under. To make a pronounced crimp, like you see pictured, set your thumb on the outside edge of the crust. With your opposite pointer and thumb fingers, create a v, and push the two together. Repeat this process all the way around the pie crust. Transfer to the freezer to chill for 30 minutes. Meanwhile, preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Brush the entire pie, liberally, with egg wash and sprinkle with turbinado sugar. Transfer the pie to a baking sheet and place in the oven for 20 to 25 minutes, until the edges are just lightly brown. Turn the heat down to 350 degrees F and bake for another 40 to 45 minutes, until the edges and top are deep golden brown. Be sure to check on it intermittently, if at any time the pie crust begins to turn too dark, use foil to cover those areas to stop browning. Allow to stand for at least two hours so it can firm up before slicing the pie. Serve with ice cream or a dollop of whipped cream.
To save some time you make the pie dough ahead. You can freeze it for up to 3 months. To make the pie ahead. You can assemble this entire pie and stick it in the freezer overnight and then bake it off the next day.
Cover lightly with a clean kitchen towel and store on the kitchen counter. I find that the fridge makes the dough soggy because of the moisture.
UPSIDE DOWN APPLE PIE2 cups all-purpose flour, 1/2 tsp salt, 6 tbsps shortening, 2 tbsps cold butter, 5 to 7 tbsps orange juice. FILLING:6 tbsps butter (melted, divided), 1/2 cup packed brown sugar, 1/2 cup chopped pecans, 8 cups thinly sliced peeled tart apples (about 1/8 inch thick), 1 cup sugar, 1/3 cup all-purpose flour, 3/4 tsp ground cinnamon, 1/4 tsp ground nutmeg. GLAZE:1/2 cup confectioners' sugar, 2 to 3 tsps orange juice.
In a large bowl, combine flour and salt; cut in shortening and butter until crumbly. Gradually add orange juice, tossing with a fork until dough forms a ball. Divide dough into two balls. Wrap in plastic; refrigerate for at least 30 minutes. Line a 9-inch deep-dish pie plate with heavy-duty foil, leaving 1-1/2 inches beyond edge; coat the foil with cooking spray. Combine 4 tbsps butter, brown sugar and pecans; spoon into prepared pie plate. In a large bowl, combine the apples, sugar, flour, cinnamon, nutmeg and remaining butter; toss gently. On waxed paper, roll out one ball of pastry to fit the pie plate. Place pastry over nut mixture, pressing firmly against mixture and sides of plate; trim to 1 in. beyond plate edge. Fill with apple mixture. Roll out remaining pastry to fit on top of pie; place over filling. Trim to 1/4 inch beyond plate edge. Fold bottom pastry over top pastry; seal and flute edges. Cut four 1-inch slits in top pastry. Bake at 375 degrees for 50-55 minutes or until the apples are tender and crust is golden brown (cover edges with foil during the last 20 minutes to prevent overbrowning if necessary).Cool for 15 minutes on a wire rack. Invert onto a serving platter; carefully remove foil. Combine glaze ingredients, drizzle over pie.

title: Caroline County landowners offer different perspectives on expanding solar
author: Tom McCall
content:
Caroline County landowners offer different perspectives on expanding solar

 October 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 575
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Converting Caroline County land into solar is a contentious issue.Some landowners see a chance to repurpose their land, add to the tax base and make some money. Others think it is against the rural character of the county.
Dave Tribbet owns farmland in Ridgely. He said he has been approached a couple of times by solar companies, and he has declined their offers.
"If you are taking up farmland, is solar going to feed anybody? I don't like solar. I am an adamant farmer who believes in feeding people," Tribbett said.
But he acknowledges that not all farmers in the county take the same stance on the issue as he does. He said he sees some landowners going for solar, attracted by the stable profits that farming can't always provide.
"A lot of the younger generations that inherited farms, that did not do the work, the backbone of the farm, to really appreciate the farm, and they see the money that is offered them. They are the ones probably jumping in on that," Tribbett said. "There is less risk, and they are guaranteed the pay at the end of the day."
Another farmer, Jim Lewis, sold 200 acres, a part of his farm, to Enel, a multinational corporation, for the Waypost Solar Project. It is near Templeville and Marydel.
Enel claims it will supply carbon-free electricity to 15,000 homes with this project. The company bought land from nine landowners and have 550 panel acres.
"I am not one to say 'everything is for sale,' but at the right price 'everything is for sale.' They offered 1.5 times my land's value. The piece of land was not the best farmland that I farmed. If I can trade one piece of land and walk away with some money, then I essentially doubled the size of the land that I had by doing it," Lewis said.
"If I can make $1,000 an acre with solar, and I can only make $100 growing corn or soy beans, it is back to economics," Lewis said. He later added that because he is making more money off the land, more of his income can be collected in taxes.
Solar relies on the transmission lines in Caroline County, which are used to move the energy. If land is not adjacent to the lines, it isn't as useful to solar companies.
The county government has put a cap of 2,000 acres that are available for solar development. Most of those acres have been developed already.
Decommissioning, the process of dismantling the solar panels and steel posts at the end of their lives, has county leadership worried that solar will leave an eyesore that is hard to get rid of.
Lewis said that solar companies have told him that when 20 years go by, they will take the panels because they are valuable.
"If they leave me a farm that has steel stakes that the panels were on, I can with a mini excavator with a thumb and a roll off can, I can clean up 20 or 30 acres a day and make it back into ag productive land," Lewis said.
But Lewis said he can see the aesthetic downside. And he can see if you are a farmer that rents land, that solar is competition.
"The commissioners shouldn't care about people's private business deals," Lewis said.
At a council meeting Commissioner Larry Porter said, "This is a fight that we better gear up for. I am not going to see this county covered in solar."

 TOLCHESTER — Families gathered at the Kent Ag Center, Tolchester, on Saturday for the fourth annual Touch a Truck/ Ag Fest event.Operators of heavy vehicles, trucks, tractors, bucket machinery and fire engines lend their time to help kids experience what it's like behind the wheel of the rigs.
Children got to sound off airhorns and pretend to drive front-end loaders, thrilled with the experience.
"Children love this stuff," Steve Green said, standing beside his 2008 custom made tanker. As owner of Green's Septic, he and his employee of six years Pete Padley enjoy educating kids on the vehicles each year.
Other than the big trucks, local and state emergency personnel were on site giving demonstrations.
Chief Logan Quinn from the Kent County Office of Emergency Services had lifesaving items on display: cardiac heart equipment, CPR devices and a pediatric response bag.
Chestertown Police Chief Ron Dixon presented some everyday tools they use to assist the public: bolt cutters, pry bars and jumper cables.
"When people see these items, we hope they see we're there for the community," Dixon said.
With a generous crowd scattered throughout the large grounds, it was calm, a good environment to learn, talking to equipment operators.
That calm was momentarily shattered at around 11:30 a.m. when a helicopter from the Maryland State Police was spotted hovering over the grounds. As soon as the chopper touched grass, kids and adults made a beeline to it, excited to get a tour.
"It's an impressive bird," said airline pilot of 25 years John Strigle. As a civilian volunteer he had a wealth of knowledge he shared along with the state police operators.
They answered questions, letting kids sit in the Agusta Westland AW139, creating lots of memories and providing parents with photo opportunities.
Other than vehicles, the various Kent County 4-H clubs manned stations running activities for the public to enjoy. The Kent Fuzzy Tails & Shiny Scales group allowed a chance to pet the rabbits, talk to their owners and participate in a prize-winning activity.
Principal Agent Associate, 4-H Youth Development Kent County, Beth Hill, behind an inventive bike/blender making pumpkin smoothies, said these kinds of events help generate new members.
In addition kids participated in a hay bale toss and Tic Tac Toe with pumpkins, while Matt Jones gave hayrides and various organizations like Rock Hall Dental fielded questions at tables.
Co-organizer Cindy Moore said Touch-a-truck came about to show appreciation to the 4-H clubs who maintained the place year-round.
She thanked everyone for showing up that day.
"We all work together on this," she said.

title: Kent Island Community Garden relocates
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Kent Island Community Garden relocates

 October 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 410
 Words

 A local garden will now find a fresh home in the community as the Queen Anne's County Commissioners approved a lease agreement with Kent Island Community Garden, Inc. for relocation to 210 White Pine Lane in Stevensville Oct. 8.The community garden formerly located in the Harbor View section of Chester used the land next to Galilee Lutheran Church for about ten years, group representative John McKnight said. Following the land sale from the church, the garden had to look for a new home and McKnight reached out to the County Commissioners over the summer for assistance.
Formed in 2015 as the Galilee Community Garden, the Kent Island Community Garden serves the need for a community garden in the Harbor View area of Chester and has since blossomed to include church volunteers, local Master Gardeners, Boy Scout Troop 495 and neighbors of all sorts ready to get their thumbs green.
The community garden also partners with the University of Maryland Extension Master Gardeners Program for educational opportunities.
The garden offers many beds of vegetables, flowers, and a separate herb garden with an irrigation system and compost area.
The Maryland Food Bank cites that one in three Marylanders face hunger. "With several of our gardeners in independent living facilities and one handicapped gardener, we realize how critical it is to establish a new space for our community garden," McKnight said.
Voicing their appreciation for the garden, the county Commissioners approved a $1,500 grant to help the garden blossom at its new location.
The new location's property next to the offices of the Fire Marshal is an ideal location to offer sufficient land for growth along with the necessary utilities as well as close proximity to the Cross-Island Trail, local schools, and the public library.
"It's going to be a great resource for the county," McKnight said.
The Kent Island Community Garden is always looking for new gardeners and civic minded groups to help build garden beds, according to McKnight.
The all inclusive garden stakes claim in having the only handicapped-accessible garden beds in the county, he said.
"We are a diverse and unique group of twenty gardeners and are the only community garden in Queen Anne's County that is open to all, " McKnight said.
Looking ahead, the garden hopes to build a few garden beds before winter sets in and In the spring seeks funds to install a deer fence around the perimeter, he said.
More information about Kent Island Community Garden can be found by contacting McKnight at McKnightJohn143@gmail.com or 202-257-3754.
