title: Fall vegetables for all occasions
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Fall vegetables for all occasions

 November 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1541
 Words 

 Read News Document

 With the cool temperatures arriving, the cook tends to explore the market for seasonal veggies the family likes. The fall menu is quite different from the summer menu.One of my greatest memories from childhood was mom and the neighbor ladies out on the farm cutting those greens by the basket and carrying them up to the outside milk kitchen, where fresh tubs of cold water waited to rinse the greens four to five times.
On a Saturday morning, the ladies came to get the fresh growing greens — Mom enjoyed sharing the abundant supply before the frost hit and destroyed them. Many times, we cut and cooked the greens for the church dinners.
I still cook them like mom, but I buy them at the produce stands and get my seasoning meat from the farmers market — farm girls call it "strip of lean and strip of fat" seasoning meat. You can also use those ham hocks, which are great for bean soup seasoning.
I am going to run out of space before I get to the turnips. Digging the turnips was done by the men on a Saturday morning. Turnips were carried to the storage shed where the sweet potatoes and white potatoes were stored.
I still love a peeled turnip raw, cut into strips and dipped in ranch dressing.
I love cooking year-round, but Sunday dinners, holiday cooking and pot luck meals are my favorite. Today I have a mixture of vegetables that are fall favorites for those upcoming dinners.
WESTLINE ROAD COLLARD GREENS3 tbsp lard or shortening (divided), 1 large onion (chopped), 6 garlic cloves (minced), 1 1/2 pounds smoked ham hocks, 6 cups water, 2 tsp seasoned salt, 1 to 3 tsp crushed red pepper flakes, 1/4 tsp sugar, 1 large bunch collard greens ( coarsely chopped).
In a 6-qt. stockpot, heat 1 tbsp lard over medium heat. Add onion and garlic, cook and stir until tender. Add ham hocks, water, seasoned salt, pepper flakes, and sugar. Bring to a boil. Reduce heat; simmer, uncovered, until meat is tender, 55-60 minutes. Add collard greens and remaining lard. Return to a boil. Reduce heat; simmer, uncovered, until greens are very tender, 55-60 minutes. Remove meat from bones; finely chop and return to pan. Discard bones.
MASHED TURNIPS3 pounds of turnips, 2 ½ cups water, 1 tsp salt, ¼ cup heavy cream, 2 tbsp butter, ½ cup of chopped bacon.
Peel and chop turnips. Place in a pot and cover with equal parts milk and water with salt. Bring to a simmer and cook until soft, 20 to 25 minutes; drain. Puree with heavy cream and butter. Season with chopped bacon. Use a food processor or immersion blender to puree these veggies-they're too hard for a potato masher unless you need the workout.
ROASTED SWEET POTATOES2 pounds sweet potatoes (about 4 medium), 2 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil, 1 tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp salt, black pepper.
Preheat the oven to 450 degrees. Dice the sweet potatoes into 3/4-inch cubes, leaving the skin on. In a large bowl, mix together the sweet potatoes with the olive oil, garlic powder and salt. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper and place the sweet potatoes on top in an even layer. Bake for about 25 minutes, until the cubes are tender and browned on the bottom. Serve warm. Store leftovers refrigerated. Make ahead instructions: Make up to 3 days in advance and reheat in a 350-degree oven.
SWEET POTATO CASSEROLE6 large, sweet potatoes (peeled and cut into chunks), 1 cup white sugar, ½ cup brown sugar, 2 tbsp ground cinnamon, 1 tbsp butter (softened), 1 cup miniature marshmallows or as many as you'd like.
Place sweet potatoes in a large pot and cover with salted water; bring to a boil. Reduce heat to medium-low and simmer until tender, about 20 minutes; drain. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees, grease a deep casserole dish. Mash potatoes with a potato masher in a bowl until no large lumps remain. Stir in both sugars, cinnamon, and butter until well combined, then transfer to the prepared casserole dish. Cover with a layer of miniature marshmallows. Bake in the preheated oven until marshmallows are browned, about 30 minutes.
ROASTED BEETS6 to 8 small or medium red beets, extra-virgin olive oil for drizzling, 1 large navel orange, balsamic vinegar for drizzling, juice of ½ lemon, handful of cooked collard greens, sea salt and freshly ground black pepper.
Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Place each beet on a piece of foil and drizzle generously with olive oil and pinches of sea salt and freshly ground black pepper. Wrap the beets in the foil and roast on a baking sheet for 35 to 60 minutes, or until soft and fork-tender. The time will depend on the size and freshness of the beets. Remove the beets from the oven, remove the foil, and set aside to cool. When they are cool to the touch, peel the skins. I like to hold them under running water and slide the skins off with my hands. Use a citrus peeler to peel long strips around the orange, avoiding the white pith. Grated zest would work here also. Slice ¾ of the orange into segments and reserve the remaining ¼ wedge for squeezing. Slice the beets into 1-inch wedges or chunks and place them in a bowl. Drizzle with olive oil and vinegar, then add the lemon juice, orange juice squeezed from the remaining wedge, and a few pinches of salt and pepper and toss. Chill until ready to serve. Taste before serving and season with more salt (flaky sea salt, if using) and pepper or more vinegar (for more tang), orange, or lemon juice, as desired.
SWEET POTATO SALAD3 large sweet potatoes (peeled and cubed), 1 small red onion (thinly sliced into half moons), 2 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil, salt, freshly ground black pepper, 1/2 cup dried cranberries, 1/2 cup crumbled feta, 1/4 cup freshly chopped parsley. FOR DRESSING: 2 tbsp apple cider vinegar, 1 tbsp Dijon mustard, 1 tbsp honey, 1/2 tsp ground cumin, 1/4 tsp ground paprika, 1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil.
Preheat oven to 400 degrees. On a large rimmed baking sheet, toss sweet potatoes and red onion in oil then season with salt and pepper. Distribute them evenly on a sheet in a single layer. Bake until tender, about 20 minutes. Let cool for 10 minutes then transfer to a large bowl. Meanwhile, make dressing: In a small bowl or in a medium liquid measuring cup, whisk together vinegar, mustard, honey, and spices. Gradually pour in oil, whisking constantly until emulsified. Season with salt and pepper. Toss sweet potatoes with dressing, cranberries, feta and parsley. Serve warm or at room temperature.
SHREDDED BRUSSELS SPROUTS AND KALE SALAD1 pound brussels sprouts (trimmed, loose leaves removed and thinly shredded), 1 bunch kale (stems removed and leaves finely chopped into ribbons), 2 medium apples of your choice (cored and thinly sliced), 1/2 cup dried cranberries, 1/3 cup candied pecans (chopped), 1/4 cup crumbled gorgonzola cheese. FOR DRESSING: 1/4 cup olive oil, 1/3 cup freshly squeezed lemon juice, 1 garlic clove (minced), 1 tsp sugar (can sub honey or maple syrup), 1/8 tsp salt, fresh ground pepper to taste. OPTIONAL: 4 slices cooked turkey bacon (chopped).
In a medium bowl, whisk together olive oil, lemon juice, garlic, sugar and salt. In a separate large bowl, toss together shredded brussels sprouts and kale mixture with your hands. Slowly pour in dressing and use your hands to massage the kale and brussels sprouts for about 5 minutes. Cover and refrigerate for at least one hour or up to overnight to allow for dressing to soak into the kale and Brussels. Once ready to serve, toss in apple slices, dried cranberries and chopped candied pecans. If you'd like you can add in chopped bacon at this point and toss salad again. Finally, garnish with crumbled gorgonzola. Serve immediately. Season with freshly ground black pepper.
CABBAGE ROLLS1 head green cabbage, 1 cup uncooked rice, 1 pound ground pork, ½ pound ground beef, 2 small onions (diced), 3 cloves garlic (minced), ½ tsp dill weed, 3 tbsp fresh parsley (chopped), salt and pepper to taste, 1 can diced tomatoes (14 ounces) with juices, 1 egg, 1 ½ cups + ⅓ cup tomato sauce (divided), 1 can tomato soup.
Boil cabbage leaves for about 2 minutes or until soft. (See note below for removing leaves). Set aside to cool. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Cook rice according to package directions but reduce cooking time by 5 minutes so the rice is slightly underdone. Set aside. Cook pork, beef, onions, garlic and seasonings in a pan until no pink remains. Drain any fat. Add in rice, diced tomatoes and ⅓ cup of tomato sauce. Stir in egg. Mix remaining tomato sauce and tomato soup in a bowl. Spread a very thin layer of the tomato sauce mixture in a 9-by-13-inch pan. Remove or thin and thick stem on cabbage leaves. Lay the cabbage leaf flat and add ¼ to 1/3 cup filling to the center of the leaf. Fold in the sides and roll the cabbage up. Place seam side down in the pan. Repeat with remaining cabbage. Pour sauce over the cabbage and cover tightly with foil. Bake for 75-90 minutes. Let cool for 15 minutes before serving.

title: Harvest Breakfast explores agritourism
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Harvest Breakfast explores agritourism

 November 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 493
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Celebrating the harvest and exploring avenues to support local farms, Queen Anne's County held its annual 35th annual Harvest Breakfast at Chesapeake College Nov. 15.Local farmers business leaders shared in community breakfast as they heard incentives put forth to enhance agritourism opportunities in the area and support local farmers.
Noting farmers as essential to the Queen Anne's County quality of life, local partnerships including economic development and Maryland extension are pursuing ways to bring in agritourism and support to provide additional revenues to farmers.
"Agriculture in many ways is the backbone of American character and American community and it certainly is in our region…When you have a farming community, you have a hardworking community," according to David Harper Chesapeake College Vice President for Workforce and Academic Programs.
Farming is an industry that also requires a sophisticated and diverse skillset from plant, animal and soil science, to complex machinery and Chesapeake College is proud to be one of the few community colleges with an agricultural program associates degree, Harper said.
Through collaboration with the Queen Anne's County Economic Tourism Development, the Planning and Zoning Department, the Maryland University Extension spearheaded a study called Agritourism Economic and Land Use to explore expansion opportunities for agritourism, better understand the business side and land use.
Mary Burkholder, principal of BAE Urban Economics led the study's research and presented key findings and preliminary recommendations.
The purpose of the study was to look at agritourism as a whole, identify other county initiatives and where agritourism is headed in the future as well as policies and initiatives to enhance opportunities for agritourism, according to Burkholder.
"The mission is to help sustain agriculture and agritourism is a good vehicle for that, " she said.
According to the Census of Agriculture, within the county are 505 farms and with over 162,000 acres, Queen Anne's County has one of the largest percentages of agriculture acreage in Maryland, Burkholder said.
While farm sizes are decreasing, according to the 2022 census, the number of farms in the county is increasing, she said. Grains and oilseeds are also the most common type of farm, according to the census.
The US Department of Agriculture did not do much census reporting about agritourism until 2017, Burkholder said.
Visitor spending in the county is strong and sites that draw an amount of tourists are primarily waterfront and officials are seeking to connect attractions and agritourism.
"Tourism is in a good place in Queen Anne's County," she said.
An important focus of the study also looked at local wineries, craft breweries and distilleries and what can be done to expand production and events.
The study looked at counties of Frederick, Carroll and Worcester, where agritourism is a large established focus.
Some initiatives of the plan include establishing definitions of agritourism and reflecting trends such as farm to table dinners in zoning subdivision regulation codes, Burkholder said.
The agritourism study is still ongoing and a final report is expected to be presented at a later date.
More information about the Maryland Extension can be found at extension.umd.edu/home.

title: Talbot county council approves report to prioritize preserving farmland
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Talbot county council approves report to prioritize preserving farmland

 November 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 241
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Tuesday evening, the Talbot County Council unanimously approved a report for the Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation Foundation program, a program to prioritize preserving prime farmland.The program is in its 44 year of permanently preserving prime farmland through the acquisition and retirement of development rights, continuing a longstanding commitment to the sustainable production of food and fiber.
The county has about 13,900 acres of prime agricultural land preserved through the MALDF program, plus an additional 25,000 acres of valuable natural resources and agricultural land preserved through other conservation easement programs.
Administrative recommendations through the years have worked to maintain a strong local economy while supporting environmental and other important objectives.
MALPF receives state funding by a combination of general revenue funds and a portion of the real estate transfer tax fees retained by Talbot County. This year, MALPF accepted 16 applications from Talbot County that will be reviewed for possible easements in the county's fiscal year 2025 budget.
The report was presented by Eliza Deflaux, planner for the Talbot County Department of planning and zoning, with the purpose answering any questions and of receiving approval of the county council to accept the recertification report.
Prior to the report being approved, Talbot County Council vice president Pete Lesher emphasized the need for the county to preserve farmland.
"I know that Talbot County is falling behind Queen Anne's County in agricultural land preservation, and this is important work and we need to do more," Lesher said.

title: Caroline County Christmas tree farm perseveres through drought
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Caroline County Christmas tree farm perseveres through drought

 December 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 860
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Cawley Family Farm has been in operation since 1996. It has never seen a season in which the heat killed as many Christmas trees as it did this year.Owner and operator Charlie Cawley, his business and his family are overcoming one of the worst droughts in recent memory. Around 300 mature trees across 15 acres were lost this year. Many of them have visibly brown needles, showing damage from the summer's heat.
"I've never lost mature trees like this," Cawley said.
To add insult to injury, Cawley said, the heat took out around 1,700 new seedlings, even those on drip irrigation. Those losses will have a longer-term impact.
"Seven, eight years from now, I could run into a problem," Cawley said, "unless I can pick it back up."
However, the family farm isn't going anywhere as the Christmas season nears. In fact, it's full steam ahead for the Cawley Family Farm, welcoming customers as one of the few full-tilt Christmas tree farms in the region.
OVERCOMING DROUGHTLocated just west of Denton and the Choptank River, Cawley Family Farm is a go-to for Caroline County residents and people up and down the Eastern Shore looking for a Christmas tree.
While this year's drought is certainly going to take a financial toll on the farm, there's no indication of it for customers picking out a tree. The Cawleys opened for tree sales in November and will continue through the weekends leading up to Christmas.
The heat wave — which saw extended bouts of triple-digit temperatures that "fried" many trees — is just a part of farming, Charlie Cawley said.
"Sooner or later, you're going to hit one of these," he said. "It's bound to happen."
The heat didn't affect trees in just one specific area; instead, damaged trees are fairly spread out across the farm. Cawley said they're working with a pathologist to look at some of the affected ones.
The enormous loss of seedlings, though, will have an effect for years to come. The longtime farmer said accounting for this year's deficit will be as simple as planting more than normal moving forward.
"You got to plant extra, that's all," Cawley said. "To answer your question, we just got to plant 10%, 20% extra."
A variety of trees, from Canaan, to Douglas, to Concolor firs, will still be available to customers this holiday season. The operation includes pre-cut Fraser fir trees, an entire process itself inside of a building on the farm. Fraser firs are especially popular and in demand, Cawley said, since they can't be grown due to the soil.
He added that people have come from as far as Princess Anne to get a tree. The Cawleys provided especially large trees for the Town of Denton this year and the Town of Berlin in the past.
Charlie and his daughter, Amy, an integral part of managing the Denton farm, recognize the importance of creating an experience for families and kids. Parents are not just picking out their trees, but children are taking photos, running around outside and learning about a real farm.
"The best part is about to happen this weekend when the families come, and we put a smile on their face with their tree," said Amy Cawley.
'A 12-YEAR DEAL'Families in the area have limited options for farms where they can cut their own trees. The Cawley farm is the only listed member of the Maryland Christmas Tree Farm Association located in Caroline, Dorchester or Talbot counties.
Joncie Underwood, the national director for the state association and a vice president of the National Christmas Tree Association, said the soil in the area limits Christmas tree farmers.
"On the Shore, I would say it's always been one here and there," said Underwood, who works at her family's Pine Valley Christmas Trees farm in Elkton, "primarily because of the soil. It's not easy to grow trees on sandy soil."
Underwood added that profitability is possible, but it largely depends on the soil and having a large, reliable customer base nearby. Charlie Cawley said while he isn't losing money, profit is certainly not the reason why he does the job.
"There's just nobody doing it any more," Cawley said. "It's not that financially profitable. I'm making money, some money."
"There's a lot of work to a tree," he continued. "A lot of people don't understand that. That's a 12-year deal. It took me … about eight, 10 years to realize you weren't going to make much money."
Instead, Cawley emphasized the chance to pass down the farming tradition to his children and grandchildren. It's a "family affair," he said, with he and his wife managing the operation, their two sons and one daughter pitching in, the grandkids chipping in to make wreaths, and the two family dogs greeting customers as they arrive.
The combination of the job's hard but rewarding work, along with that family involvement, is why Charlie Cawley has stuck to being a Christmas tree farmer.
"It grows on you. Just like a tree grows on you, the business grows on you," Cawley said. "The smell of the tree kind of hooked me back in the beginning.
"I farm, I like to see things grow. It's kind of neat that my grandkids are here helping. It's a family deal."

title: 'Fascinating' sika deer thrive in Dorchester County but cause concerns for farmers
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
'Fascinating' sika deer thrive in Dorchester County but cause concerns for farmers

 December 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 890
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DORCHESTER COUNTY — In the wetlands of the Eastern Shore, thousands of sika deer have acclimated to the region's climate since the 1900s. While the species offers a sense of local pride and peculiarity, many local farmers hold frustrations with sika's impact on crops.Sika deer are native to Japan and a highly sought species, with most of the state's population located in Dorchester County.
The Maryland Department of Natural Resources doesn't consider the species invasive, but rather exotic.
Jonathan Trudeau, who works in the Department of Natural Resources' Wildlife & Heritage Service, describes sika as an "elusive" species that are popular with both hunters and the general public.
"It's a unique species. It's a unique opportunity," said Trudeau, who is the service's game and mammal section leader. "It's essentially the East Coast equivalent of going on an elk hunt. It's something that not a lot of people get to do. It's a challenging hunt."
Farmers in Dorchester County, however, have voiced their concerns over the sika population, particularly in recent years. Trudeau said sika contribute more to crop damage in the county than white-tailed deer.
Todd Eberspacher, a fifth-generation farmer in Linkwood, said the issue has been "out of control" over the last 10 to 15 years. He and his father grow corn, wheat and soybeans.
"We've been in this area a long time," Eberspacher said. "My father and I have seen deer damage. Deer damage was an issue as long as I can remember, but not to the extent as what it is now."
CROP CONCERNSEberspacher recalls a time when his neighbor "had around $70,000 worth of damage she lost on one of her farms" due to sika deer eating the crops. He says while white-tailed deer graze on crops, it's "not nearly to the extent of sika deer."
The Wildlife & Heritage Service offers deer management permits for agricultural producers in order to mitigate crop damage, even outside of typical hunting seasons.
Eberspacher, however, said the permits don't solve the crux of the problem, which comes at night.
According to Trudeau, sika deer prefer wetlands and marshy areas during the day, but dry land and agricultural areas at night. The nocturnal nature of the deer is what has hurt the Eberspachers.
"Something that farmers need are nighttime permits," Eberspacher said. "We're issued crop damage permits, but they're only valid and you're only able to use them from … a half-hour prior to sunrise and a half-hour after sunset."
Eberspacher added that this year's rise in the cost for an out-of-state license to hunt sika, from $25 to $200, has only worsened the crop damage stemming from the species. While the Department of Natural Resources enforces those costs, changes came from legislators at the state level, not the department nor its Wildlife & Heritage Service.
"The state's got our hands tied," Eberspacher said. "We're not able to address the issue."
Trudeau says hunters do make an annual impact on the sika deer population. In a report released by the Department of Natural Resources Friday, 961 sika deer were harvested in Dorchester County during the recent two-week firearms season.
Conversations with state officials haven't led to any solutions so far, Eberspacher says.
"The state of Maryland sees sika deer as a chance to bring revenue to the state," he said. "They don't care about the farmers. We've met with different legislators, they've (come) out, they've looked at the fields at nighttime, they've seen the several deer. And then it goes nowhere."
'FASCINATING' SPECIESAs the farming community seeks relief for crops, many others are amazed by the uniqueness of sika deer and how the species has neatly fit into Maryland's Eastern Shore.
"We get a lot of questions about it," Trudeau said. "We have a lot of stakeholders who are very interested in the species, whether it be for hunting purposes, if they're an ag producer or even just the general public that finds it fascinating."
Brought to the region by a wealthy resident in the early 1900s, the sika deer population modestly grew from a count that started in the single digits. Despite slow growth, the numbers soared by the 1990s, Trudeau says.
The population size is well off, with an estimated 19,000 across the state. Sika deer are prized possessions for hunters — some even travel from the other end of the country, Trudeau said.
"Today, it's a very, very popular game species," he said. "And to be honest, it drives some of the economics in that area, especially during the hunting season."
Trudeau notes that compared to white-tailed deer, sika deer are smaller and rounder in size, standing at only a few feet tall. They also have a darker coat than white-tailed deer.
The two-week firearms report shows the 961 sika deer harvested in Dorchester County outpace 905 white-tailed deer. But the two deer species don't negatively compete with one another, according to Trudeau.
Wetlands areas are "subpar" habitats for white-tailed deer, he said. Sika deer, meanwhile, create "pockets" in those wetlands, though overlapping with the white-tailed deer on the outer edges.
Since sika deer typically don't have twins or reproduce as much as white-tailed deer, Trudeau says Maryland's healthy sika deer population is something to truly appreciate.
"Maryland's really one of the only places that you can find this species free range outside of its native range," Trudeau said. "So it's a very, very unique species, and it's very unique that we have a population that is actually doing very, very well."

title: Bird flu discovered in Caroline County commercial operation
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Bird flu discovered in Caroline County commercial operation

 January 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 785
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — State laboratory testing has detected a case of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza in Caroline County following routine sampling of a broiler operation and investigation by the Maryland Department of Agriculture.This marks the first case of H5N1 at a Maryland commercial poultry operation since 2023 and the third commercial operation in the Delmarva region in the last 30 days, with the disease found in two Kent County, Delaware flocks.
The disease was also discovered among wild populations of geese in Dorchester County earlier this week.
State officials have quarantined all affected premises, and birds on the properties are being or have been depopulated to prevent the spread of the disease, the MDA said in a release. Birds from affected flocks will not enter the food system.
Confirmation by the U.S. Department of Agriculture's (USDA) National Veterinary Services Laboratory is pending with final results anticipated in the coming days.
"High Pathogenic Avian influenza or HPAI does not affect poultry meat or egg products, which remain healthy and safe to eat and handle," said Maryland Department of Agriculture Secretary Kevin Atticks. "The Maryland Department of Agriculture, local health department, USDA and partner organizations are working diligently to address the situation, including quarantining and testing nearby flocks. We continue to urge commercial growers and backyard flock owners to be on heightened alert for HPAI."
Avian influenza is a highly contagious airborne respiratory virus that spreads easily among birds through nasal and eye secretions, as well as manure.
The virus can be spread in various ways from flock to flock, including by wild birds, through contact with infected poultry, by equipment, and on the clothing and shoes of caretakers, the MDA said. This virus affects poultry, like chickens, ducks and turkeys, along with some wild bird species such as ducks, geese, shorebirds and raptors.
In an interview with The Star Democrat, Delmarva Chicken Association Communications Manager James Fisher said this incident reinforces how important it is that families and farmers raising chickens keep biosecurity practices at the top of mind "at all times."
Fisher said the association has shared "important biosecurity advice" with members and made sure that members are aware of federal and state agriculture resources regarding planning farms and setting biosecurity practices in place.
"We also have a text alert service for our members so we can let them know as soon as a detection has been announced by agriculture officials," he said. "And we've put that in practice with the recent detections."
According to the Maryland Department of Health, the risk of transmission of the disease between birds and the general public is low. Those who work directly with poultry or dairy farms may be more at risk and should follow key biosecurity practices.
The Maryland Department of Agriculture recommends the following steps if HPAI is suspected on personal property, in wild birds or in a commercial operation:Look for signs of illness. Know the warning signs of infectious bird diseases.
Report suspected sick birds at 410-841-5810.Commercial chicken growers and backyard flock owners can email questions about the outbreak to MD.Birdflu@maryland.gov.Key biosecurity practices:Clean and disinfect transportation. Don't walk through or drive trucks, tractors, or equipment in areas where waterfowl or other wildlife feces may be. If you can't avoid this, clean your shoes, vehicle, and equipment thoroughly.Remove loose feed. Don't give wild birds, rodents and insects a free lunch. Remove spilled or uneaten feed right away, and make sure feed storage units are secure and free of holes.Keep visitors to a minimum. Only allow those people who take care of your poultry to come in contact with your birds.Wash your hands before and after coming in contact with live poultry. Wash with soap and water. If using a hand sanitizer, first remove manure, feathers and other materials from your hands because disinfectants will not penetrate organic matter or caked-on dirt.Provide disposable boot covers (preferred) and/or disinfectant footbaths for anyone having contact with your flock. If using a footbath, be sure to remove all droppings, mud or debris from boots and shoes using a long-handled scrub brush before stepping into the disinfectant footbath, and always keep it clean.Change clothes before entering poultry areas and before exiting the property.Visitors should wear protective outer garments or disposable coveralls, boots and headgear when handling birds, and shower or change clothes when leaving the facility.Clean and disinfect tools or equipment before moving them to a new poultry facility. Before allowing vehicles, trucks, tractors, or tools and equipment — including egg flats and cases that have come in contact with birds or their droppings — to exit the property, make sure they are cleaned and disinfected to prevent contaminated equipment from transporting disease. Do not move or reuse items that cannot be cleaned and disinfected.For more information on avian influenza, visit mda.maryland.gov/Pages/AvianFlu.aspx. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Country Cooking: Fresh pork on the farm
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Fresh pork on the farm

 January 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Life 
 
 1716
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A couple of years ago I did a story and recipes about the annual hog slaughtering adventures on the farm and decided to re-run this as one of my favorite memories to share with my readers.As a matter of fact, just a few weeks ago I was asked if I was going to do one this winter — here it is, my friend.
This part of farm life, hog slaughtering, is a dying process as not many of the older farmers are even on farms any more and the younger generation prefers to concentrate on more modern aspects of farming, such as specialty vegetables, fruit trees, pick-your-own and more.
Each year my parents held an two old-fashioned hog killings to fill the smokehouse and freezers with meat, once in November and once in March.
This supply of meat fit perfectly with the previous summer's canned vegetables, jellies, relishes, applesauce and much more, not to mention the shed with potatoes, sweet potatoes, onions and turnips.
It was not a lot of hard work because we all pitched in and my dad had several farm hands helping. Everybody left at the end of the day with full stomachs and a package of sausage, scrapple or seasoning meat.
Today as I ride past the old farm place I get upset looking at and thinking of those days gone by. I can still see the late Mr. Jim Showell ready to hang the meat and the late Mr. Ed Sturgis ready to hang the iron pots over the fire he would make.
Mom would allow her children and grandchildren to "help" with the work, but she had a hand in it all — especially the final taste testing of the sausage and scrapple.
The morning of the slaughter found my sister and I scrubbing down the cutting services, the mixing utensils, the pans to hold scrapple and the trays for both loose sausage and link sausage. In the smokehouse waited the exceptionally clean, sharp meat hooks to hang the hams and shoulders. Finally, there were the cans to hold the fresh pressed lard.
The one job that my mother had every year was sausage maker. Either one of my brothers or nephews would feed the cut-up pork parts into the top of the grinder. My mother sat stretching sheep's intestines for the casing over the tube and working the ground sausage as it fed into the intestines and into a large bowl. This was a job that I later inherited, and since it was the only job that you could actually sit at our hog killings, I didn't mind.
There are many funny stories associated with "hog killing adventures" throughout the years but time will not allow today. In the next few winter months, I will slip them in.
The one I love the most was when the hogs could have gotten me in big trouble but my bus driver, the late Mr. George Hudson, was related to mom, and he was a farmer.
One cold hog killing morning, I was leaving to go to school on the bus, and I begged Mr. Sturgis to cut out the hog brains for my class to study in biology. He did, but he put them in a small brown paper bag.
By the time we got to Stephen Decatur High School the bag broke through as we got off the bus. My friend Nellie saw it first, screamed, hollered "dead," and everyone ran. I tried to explain to our new principal but to no avail. He just didn't understand a country girl's ambition to succeed in biology.
Let's cook some delicious fresh pork.
COUNTRY PORK RIBS3 pounds country style pork ribs (about 8 ribs), 2 tsps smoked salt, ½ tsp black pepper, 2 tsps smoked paprika, 1 tsp dried thyme, ½ tsp cayenne pepper.
Preheat your oven to 325 degrees. Arrange the ribs in a single layer in an ungreased 9-by-13-inch rimmed baking dish. Mix together the dry rub ingredients and sprinkle the rub on top of the ribs. Cover the baking dish tightly with heavy duty foil (or a double layer of regular foil), and bake until the ribs are very tender, about 2 hours. With a slotted spatula, remove the cooked ribs to a broiler-safe, foil-lined, rimmed baking sheet. Either flip them or place them on their side, so that the fat is exposed to the heating element. The goal is to brown it. Switch the oven to broil on high ( 500°F) and set an oven rack 6 inches below the heating element (not directly below).Baste the ribs with the pan juices, then broil them until the fat is browned, 3-4 minutes. Baste the ribs one more time with the pan juices and serve.
PORK ROAST6-pound boneless pork shoulder, 3 cloves garlic (minced), 2 tsps salt, 2 tsps ground pepper, 1 tbsp chopped fresh sage, 1 tbsp chopped fresh rosemary, 2 large red onions (sliced into 1-inch wedges), olive oil, 1/2 cup reserved pan drippings.
One day before you plan to serve the roast, preheat oven to 300 degrees. Tie roast well with kitchen twine. Rub roast with mix of herbs and garlic and place in oiled roasting pan, Bake in preheated oven, uncovered, for 3 hours. Remove roast from pan and add onions; toss with pan drippings (if there isn't enough fat in the pan, drizzle with a bit of olive oil and toss onions to coat). Place roast on top of onions and return to oven, uncovered, for an additional 4 hours (check pan every hour to be sure the pan drippings don't evaporate — add 2 cups of water if necessary). Remove the roast from the roasting pan and place it in a glass baking dish and allow it to cool before you wrap the dish well with plastic and put it in the fridge overnight. Reserve the onions and pan drippings separately in the fridge overnight too. You should have about 1 1/2 cups of drippings (maybe 1 1/4 after you remove the fat). Add water to the drippings if you don't have enough.
About an hour before you want to serve this yummy roast, preheat your oven to 300 degrees. Remove the twine from the roast and slice into 1/4-inch slices, "Shingle" the slices in a large casserole dish. Pour about 1/2 cup of the reserved pan drippings over the slices, cover with foil, and place in preheated oven for 45 minutes, Season individual servings and serve.
PORK LOIN CHOPSPork loin chop, 2 tbsp paprika, 1 tbsp salt, ½ tbsp ground black pepper, ½ tbsp garlic powder, ½ tbsp onion powder, 1 tsp dry mustard powder, 1 tsp ground sage, ¼ tsp cayenne pepper, ¼ tsp celery salt.
Measure out all of the dry ingredients into a small mixing bowl (or the bowl of a spice grinder). Set aside. Preheat your oven to 375 degrees and lightly grease or spray a baking dish with non-stick cooking spray. Wash and trim your country style pork loin chops as needed, then pat the pork dry using paper towels. Apply the pork seasoning to all sides of the pork chops generously. For about 2 lbs of country style pork loin chops you'd use 2 tbsps of the pork seasoning. Place the seasoned country style pork loin chops into your prepared baking dish in a single layer. Bake in the middle of your oven's center rack for 35-40 minutes, or until the pork reaches a minimum internal temperature of 145 degrees. Remove from the oven and serve immediately for best taste.
PULLED PORK1 3-pound pork shoulder roast, ½ cup beef broth, ⅓ cup apple cider vinegar, ½ chopped yellow onion, 2 tbsps light brown sugar, 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce, 1 tbsp yellow mustard, 1 bottle of your favorite BBQ sauce.
Spread chopped onions on the bottom of the slow cooker. Add pork shoulder and pour in chicken broth, Worcestershire and cider vinegar right on the pork. Add mustard and brown sugar and use your hands to rub it all in the pork. Cover the slow cooker and set on high for 5 hours. Shred pork with 2 forks and pour in BBQ sauce. Don't pour the whole bottle in, just enough to cover the meat according to taste. Cover and cook on high for 1 more hour. Serve on your favorite sandwich rolls or buns.
BACON, BEAN AND POTATO SOUP1 pound dry navy beans, 6 oz bacon, 2 cloves garlic, 1 yellow onion, 3 carrots, 3 ribs celery, 2 pounds potatoes, 6 cups chicken broth, 1 8-oz can tomato sauce, salt and pepper to taste.
The day before you want to serve, place the beans in a large bowl and add enough cool water to cover the beans by 2-3 inches. Let the beans soak in the refrigerator overnight. The next day, cut the bacon into one-inch pieces. Cook the bacon in a large pot over medium heat until brown and crispy. Remove the bacon to a paper towel lined plate and pour off most of the grease, leaving a tbsp or two in the pot. While the bacon is cooking, dice the onion and mince the garlic. Peel and slice the carrots and slice the celery. Sauté the onion, garlic, carrots, and celery in the leftover bacon grease over medium heat until the onions are soft and transparent (about five minutes). Use the moisture from the vegetables to help dissolve the browned bits of bacon from the bottom of the pot. While the vegetables are sautéing, peel the potatoes then cut them into half-inch cubes. Drain the soaked beans in a colander and rinse them briefly. Add the cubed potatoes, rinsed beans and chicken broth to the pot. Cover the pot and bring it up to a boil. Reduce the heat slightly and let the pot boil gently for one hour, or until the beans and potatoes are very soft. Use an immersion blender to purée about half of the soup, leaving some beans and vegetables whole. If you don't have an immersion blender, remove half of the soup from the pot, let it cool slightly, then use a blender or food processor to carefully puree the warm soup. Return the puréed soup to the pot and stir to combine with the rest. Add the tomato sauce and reserved bacon to the soup. Stir and heat until warm. Taste the soup and add salt and pepper if needed. Serve hot.

title: Bird flu could bring financial stress if not contained
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Bird flu could bring financial stress if not contained

 January 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 521
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — If avian flu cases continue to spread on the Eastern Shore, it may bring financial difficulty to the area, officials say.According to to the National Chicken Council in 2024, the chicken industry accounted for as much as $5.46 billion in the state's revenue. Containing this problem and not letting it spread is key to maintaining those numbers.
"So while a handful of farms affected by this doesn't immediately alter those numbers very much, we all don't want to see a situation in which we have dozens of farms affected," said James Fisher, communications manager for Delmarva Chicken Association.
State laboratory tests detected a case of avian influenza in Queen Anne's County on Tuesday, the fourth case found in a commercial operation on the Delmarva Peninsula since Jan. 3. The disease was discovered at a commercial operation in Caroline County on Jan. 10, which was the first documented case in a commercial operation in Maryland this year.
Health and agriculture authorities have put measures in place aiming to curb the spread of the disease, which at this time is believed to have only infected birds.
"State officials have quarantined all affected premises, and birds on the properties are being or have been depopulated to prevent the spread of the disease. Birds from affected flocks will not enter the food system," the Maryland Department of Agriculture said in a press release about the case in Queen Anne's County.
At Tuesday's Caroline County Commissioners meeting, Caroline County Health officer Robin Cahall offered an update on the disease.
Among the main concerns at the Tuesday meeting were the financial trouble the bird flu could bring and the compensation for farmers who lose their flocks.
Federal programs are in place to aid farmers who lose flocks to avian flu.
"The USDA, actually operates a sort of a backstop income program for cases like this," Fisher said, "because you don't want to have a situation which farmers fear reporting signs of HPAI out of the fear of lost income."
HUMAN HEALTH IMPACTSAt this time, chances for human-to-human transmission of the disease are low, health authorities say.
At the Tuesday meeting, Caroline County officials detailed steps they are taking to track potential mutations that could impact human health.
"So human-to-human transmission is not occurring at this time. The threat to humans is low," Cahall said. "... However, if the virus mutates that could present a problem."
The Caroline County residents with exposure to the bird flu are monitored for flu-like symptoms, and they will be tested for the disease if symptoms arise. Authorities are securing the locations where the disease is found to make sure no one comes into contact with the quarantined area.
Hunters and birders are safe to operate, but they need to take some precautions while participating in the activity, state officials warn.
According to Maryland Department of Natural Resources, people should never harvest or handle wild birds that are sick or found dead.
Washing hands with soap and water or hand sanitizer immediately after handling animals and using disposable gloves when handling animals and double-bagging animals are encouraged.
For preparation purposes, officials urge people to cook wild-caught animals to 165 degrees to kill any viruses or bacteria.

title: Maryland, Delaware officials hold session to discuss solutions for spreading avian flu
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Maryland, Delaware officials hold session to discuss solutions for spreading avian flu

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 804
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In Delaware, farmers have seen birds fall out the sky — a troubling sign for the spread of the avian flu, Delaware Secretary of Agriculture Michael Scuse said in a Zoom meeting Friday.Multiple Maryland and Delaware officials hosted a situational update on the disease for poultry farmers on Jan. 17. The bird flu epidemic in the area, which began in the last few weeks, is spreading mainly through wild flocks, they said.
"The issue for our farms really involves the fact that the snow geese that didn't die overnight while roosting on the coast are strong enough to fly," Scuse said. "These birds will move inland to forage on open spaces, including our farm fields, many of them right next to poultry houses. We've heard from you that you're seeing birds drop dead right out of the sky, it puts your birds and your whole farming operation's livelihood at risk. It also affects the entire industry."
The meeting offered information on the bird flu and gave farmers in the Delmarva area a chance to ask questions on what they should do to help curb the disease's spread.
How the bird flu spreadsThe bird flu can spread from multiple different sources besides just dead birds, the officials said. H5N1, the strain of avian influenza in question, can be transmitted from clothing, shoes, equipment and vehicles.
"If a snow goose has its waste, and you walk through it, you could carry it right into the house," Scuse said. "A dime's worth of droppings carrying HPAI on your shoes would be enough to kill one million birds. Airborne transmission is not likely, but it may occur"
Another way the bird flu can be spread is through household animals like dogs or cats. Although cases in dogs are rare, officials said cats are highly susceptible to the disease.
Farm cats are susceptible because of consuming unpasteurized milk, and all cats are susceptible by consuming raw pet food.
Letting your dog or cat walk in areas wild birds leave droppings in is very dangerous because they can contract bird flu from sick wildlife.
Human contact as a spreading agent for the disease has not been reported in either Maryland or Delaware, and officials believe that human transfer is a low possibility.
Although its unlikely for humans to get this strain of the bird flu at this time, humans can spread the disease to animals by not cleaning materials used for farming.
Cases in Maryland and DelawareAt this time, Delaware has seen the most cases of bird flu in the Delmarva area.
"By January 3, more than 850 wild birds had been reported dead in Delaware, with the majority being snow geese, but also Canada geese, other water fowl, vultures and other birds." Scuse said.
Maryland has seen some cases on the Eastern Shore area as well.
"We tested some snow geese in Dorchester County that came up positive, and also in Worcester County that came up positive," Jennifer Trout, a veterinarian from MDA stated. "After that, we had our first case in Caroline County on the 10th of January, a broiler farm that did have some high mortality, and they were 51-day-old birds.
"Our next case occurred on the 14th in Queen Anne's County —high mortality there as well, 60-day-old birds. And then the final case was on the 15th, another case in Caroline County, another broiler farm. Those birds were 58 days old as well. There was no mortality there. And then also this week, we had some positive vultures in Queen Anne's County."
How to dispose and keep from spreadingOfficials recommend disposing of dead wildlife by setting up a stock pile away from well chickens. They also say to make sure the stock pile is covered and away from wildlife.
"If you're stockpiling on the farm, if you have manure storage availability, in a manure storage structure, that's the preferred place to store litter if you have capacity," said Steve Connelly, deputy secretary of the Maryland Department of Agriculture. "If you don't have capacity, you can stockpile it, but please cover it. We're really concerned about the wildlife effect."
Maryland and Delaware officials urge farmers to clean the bottom of their shoes, as well as the floors of vehicles, with Lysol so they won't transmit the bird flu between flocks.
Kevin Sullivan, state director for USDA wildlife services for Maryland, Delaware and D.C., offered multiple solutions to scare wild animals away from healthy flocks without touching them.
"You can do whatever you want to haze and harass the birds, snow geese, geese, vultures, you don't need a permit to do that," Sullivan said. "If you see them in your field by the hundreds or the thousands, I would not let them congregate there. You have to assume that they're sick. Chase them with a vehicle, a dog noise maker, firearms, but all options out there, don't let them sit on your manure sheds."

title: Avian flu case discovered in Dorchester County
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Avian flu case discovered in Dorchester County

 January 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 552
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — A presumptive positive case of H5 avian influenza has been identified on a commercial broiler farm in Dorchester County, which would bring the total number of cases found on commercial poultry farms on Maryland's Eastern Shore to four since the beginning of the year.According to a news release from the Maryland Department of Agriculture, confirmation by the U.S. Department of Agriculture's National Veterinary Services Laboratory is pending and the results are expected "in the coming days."
If confirmed, this will be the first case of this strain avian influenza in a commercial operation Dorchester County. Wild flocks were determined to be carrying the disease in the county earlier this month.
According to the news release, state officials have quarantined all affected premises in the county. Birds on the properties are being or have been depopulated to prevent the spread of the disease, and birds from affected flocks will not enter the food system.
On Jan. 10, state officials announced a presumptive positive result was found at a commercial poultry farm in Caroline County.
In total, seven commercial operations in the Delmarva region have been confirmed to have highly pathogenic H5 avian influenza, including two in Kent County, Delaware, and one in Accomack County, Virginia.
On Jan. 17, multiple Maryland and Delaware officials hosted a situational update on the disease for poultry farmers. The bird flu epidemic in the area is spreading mainly through wild flocks, they said.
According to the state news release, avian influenza is a highly contagious airborne respiratory virus that spreads easily among birds through nasal and eye secretions, as well as manure. It can be spread in multiple ways from flock to flock, including by wild birds, through contact with infected poultry, by equipment, and on the clothing and shoes of caretakers.
The virus affects poultry, like chickens, ducks and turkeys, along with some wild bird species such as ducks, geese, shorebirds and raptors.
According to the Maryland Department of Health, the risk of transmission between birds and the general public is low. Those who work directly with poultry or dairy farms may be more at risk and should follow key biosecurity practices.
The Maryland Department of Agriculture continues to urge growers and backyard flock owners to enhance biosecurity practices and become familiar with what to do if avian influenza is suspected in a flock.
Growers and backyard flock owners should be on the lookout for signs of illness and report suspected sick birds. To report a possible case in a commercial or backyard flock, call the Maryland Department of Agriculture at 410-841-5810. Commercial chicken growers and backyard flock owners can email questions about the outbreak to MD.Birdflu@maryland.gov.
To report a sick wild bird in Maryland, call the Maryland Department of Natural Resources Wildlife Services hotline at 877-463-6497 between 8 a.m. and 4:30 p.m. Monday through Friday.
Key biosecurity practices include:
Cleaning and disinfecting transportation.
Removing loose feed.
Keeping visitors to a minimum.
Washing hands before and after coming in contact with live poultry.
Providing disposable boot covers (preferred) and/or disinfectant footbaths for anyone having contact with your flock.
Changing clothes before entering poultry areas and before exiting the property.
Having visitors wear protective outer garments or disposable coveralls, boots, and headgear when handling birds, and shower and/or change clothes when leaving the facility.
Cleaning and disinfecting tools or equipment before moving them to a new poultry facility.
For more information on avian influenza, visit: mda.maryland.gov/Pages/AvianFlu.aspx.

title: There are other options open to poultry farmers
author: DR. ASHA SUBRAMANIAN
content:
There are other options open to poultry farmers

 January 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DR. ASHA SUBRAMANIAN | Section: News 
 
 726
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As a physician, I have been following closely our country's bird flu crisis. I was saddened but not surprised to learn that, within days of each other, bird flu was detected for the first time on an Eastern Shore poultry farm and our country experienced the death of its first patient from H5N1 bird flu in Louisiana.My colleagues and I are watchful for symptoms of bird flu and are hopeful that Maryland does not join the list of states in which more than 60 human cases of bird flu have been detected. I applaud our public health officials for doing what they can to keep the bird flu from spreading but the reality is that the virus has sickened dozens of people, decimated poultry populations and infected dairy cows.
Thankfully, our state is doing a good job of monitoring for the virus. But now is the time to take a hard look at the food production system that puts farm workers in close contact with sick birds and cows, the Standard American Diet that demands it and the health ramifications of both.
From a doctor's perspective, shifting food production away from intensive animal agriculture can benefit public health. Facilities with large numbers of animals in a small amount of space are a concern for public health because they provide ideal conditions for viruses to spread, evolve and possibly acquire the ability to more easily infect people. Intensive animal agriculture was implicated when influenza viruses H1N1, H5N1 and N7N9 jumped from animals to people, according to research published in Frontiers in Microbiology.
The life of a contract chicken grower can be challenging, and some of them are repurposing their chicken houses to grow crops. I was not surprised to learn that North Carolina poultry farmers Dale and Paula Boles switched from chickens, converted their 500-foot-long poultry barn to a greenhouse and now grow organic vegetables. They are not alone. In Southwest Arkansas, farmers Jennifer and Rodney Barrett are transitioning from raising poultry and cattle to growing mushrooms.
These farm transitions aren't easy. The government should provide financial and technical support. Maryland could help its farmers with a program like the one established by lawmakers in Vermont who provide grants to farmers who wish to diversify or transition from one type of farming to another. On a broader scale, U.S. Sen. Cory Booker has introduced legislation that would require the U.S. Department of Agriculture to provide grants to livestock farmers to pay off related debt and to transition the property to alternative agriculture activities. Maryland's U.S. Sens. Van Hollen and Alsobrooks should support this legislation to help ensure that it passes.
According to the USDA, "Maryland is small, but it reaches from the Atlantic Ocean to the Appalachian Mountains, providing a suitable environment for a variety of agricultural commodities," which means lots of opportunities for farmers. Sweet corn, hazelnuts, watermelons, grapes, as well as apple, cherry and peach orchards are just a few promising options.
Shifting away from animal agriculture helps our environment and improves worker safety as well. Maryland's poultry farms are a primary source of water, air and land pollution. Improving the water quality in the Chesapeake Bay is another reason to increase acreage of fruit and nut trees. One way to keep phosphorous and other pollutants from flowing into rivers is to install riparian buffers of trees and shrubs to intercept polluted water running off of fields where chicken litter has been applied. Trees that are suitable for riparian buffers, like hazelnuts can also provide income to farmers.
I have found for myself and my patients that removing animal products from the diet improves health too. A plant-based diet focused on fruits, veggies, legumes and grains grown in Maryland can help maintain healthy weight, lower blood pressure and improve heart health.
I know this from my own personal experience and from treating patients with diet-related diseases, and the scientific literature tells the same story. A recent study with 22 pairs of identical twins found that a plant-based diet improves heart health in as little as eight weeks. The twins following a plant-based diet experienced lower LDL, or "bad" cholesterol, and they lost more weight than the omnivore twins.
Government grants and other assistance should also be available if Maryland poultry farmers or egg producers would like to switch to growing crops and planting orchards, which will also benefit human health and the environment.

title: Farming, new administration main topics of Eastern Shore Delegation meeting
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Farming, new administration main topics of Eastern Shore Delegation meeting

 January 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 671
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — On Friday morning, the Eastern Shore Delegation met over Zoom to discuss budgets, the new presidential administration and agriculture on the Eastern Shore.U.S. Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md., 1st) spoke to the state legislators on his excitement for the Trump administration that was sworn in on Monday and the changes that will be made to government spending now that Tesla CEO Elon Musk will co-lead the newly created Department of Government Efficiency.
"I do believe that we have to operate more, and the federal government has to operate more like the private sector does," Harris said. "...Elon Musk is going to do in terms of promoting government efficiency because in the end we cannot continue trillion dollar deficits into the future. We have to control federal spending. We are cursed with without a balanced budget amendment."
Several Republican delegation members at the meeting echoed these sentiments.
Many spoke on the state of Maryland and the amount of federal employees it has, some saying the state is too heavily dependent on federal employment.
Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said recent actions of some state officials in response to actions taken by the Trump administration do not align with Maryland's needs. He said the state is "trying to find $3 billion" and yet is involved in lawsuits against the federal government.
"The (Maryland) attorney general seems to have plenty of money to want to sue the federal government," Hutchinson said. "Well, at the same time, the state has their hand out to the federal government saying, 'I need money for the Key Bridge. I need more Medicaid money.'"
PRIORITIES FOR FARMERSThroughout the meeting, several representatives and supporters of farmers and agriculture policy spoke, including Tyler Hough, director of government relations for the Maryland Farm Bureau, who shared priorities for the organization for the next fiscal year.
Hough said the bureau has three policy priorities, including private property rights and eminent domain, solar energy, and agriculture education. In his presentation, he focused on the importance of education for the state.
"The opportunity to educate the youth, even get into the middle school areas, the opportunity to have education in the high schools and the FFA (agriculture education) programs and the value that FFA brings along with the 4-H programs that already exist, is just fantastic for these students," Hough said.
Later on the agenda, a presentation was made by members of the Harry R. Hughes Center for Agro-Ecology, an organization centering scientific research, policy analysis and outreach and education efforts.
Kate Everts, executive director of the Harry R. Hughes Center for Agro-Ecology, led the in-depth presentation, in which she highlighted the Maryland Climate-Smart Agriculture Project and the extensive outreach to Eastern Shore farmers that the center has done.
Everts said the farm-centered project seeks to find what agriculture needs to be adaptable and profitable for a future dictated by climate change.
"We're seeing changes in weather across the country, but here in Maryland," Everts said, "how is it impacting our farms and our forests? And again, we want to make sure that they are in a good position to stay economically viable going forward. So we're all about making sure their businesses are successful."
Everts said the research team evaluated potential impacts on local agriculture and conducted outreach with farmers and service providers.
Toward the end of the presentation, Harris shared his appreciation for the work that the Harry R. Hughes Center for Agro-Ecology does for farmers and the importance of keeping them in the forefront of policy and work done for the state.
"It's very good to hear this presentation today because so often what happens in Annapolis is we go up with a lot of emotion, a lot of heart to represent and protect the interests of Agriculture, and what you're talking about, along with other institutions, is bringing science to bear with the lens of the Eastern Shore and certainly throughout the state. The point is through the lens of agriculture, which is so important," Harris said.
The next meeting of the Eastern Shore Delegation will be held on Jan. 31 via Zoom.

title: Maryland officials hustle to contain avian flu outbreak
author: Paul Kiefer Capital News Service
content:
Maryland officials hustle to contain avian flu outbreak

 January 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Paul Kiefer Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 672
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Four flocks of chickens on Maryland's Eastern Shore have tested positive for the avian influenza virus, also known as avian flu, since early January.Maryland state agencies are now hurrying to contain the outbreak, the further spread of which could hobble one of the region's core industries and raise concerns about the virus' transfer to humans.
Maryland Secretary of Agriculture Kevin Atticks appeared alongside other state health and agriculture officials before the state House Environment and Transportation Committee on Friday to brief lawmakers on the outbreak and the state's response.
"Poultry is king on the Eastern Shore," he told the Capital News Service before the hearing. An outbreak in this important Maryland industry could hit the economy well beyond the four commercial farms with positive cases, he added.
While human health risks of the virus are low, said Deputy Secretary of Public Health Services Nilesh Kalyanaraman, "a lot of the concern here is not just on the livestock and poultry side, but also on the potential for transmission — and potentially mutations — that can make this a pandemic."
The current outbreak is the largest in Maryland since 2022, when chickens on five farms across the state tested positive for the virus. Since past outbreaks, state agencies and the Delmarva Peninsula's poultry industry have adopted strict sanitation practices to prevent the virus's spread. But the close proximity of farms may undercut those precautions, expanding the number of farmers impacted by even a small outbreak.
Wild birds, including the geese that migrate over the Delmarva Peninsula, are primary carriers of the virus. Maryland's Department of Agriculture and other government partners have worked with farmers for more than a decade to limit exposure to the disease.
When a chicken tests positive for the virus, farmers cull their entire flock and begin a decontamination process that can last well over a month. Meanwhile, growers nearby are temporarily barred from obtaining new chickens, cutting into their annual earnings. While the U.S. Department of Agriculture pays for decontamination and generally compensates the affected farmers, the department does not offer the same assistance to nearby farmers who lose income after an outbreak.
Maryland State Veterinarian Dr. Jennifer Trout told lawmakers on Friday that some 223 poultry farms and backyard flocks were close enough to this month's outbreaks to be subject to additional inspections. She did not specify how many farms were within the three-kilometer "infected zones."
Dr. Jonathan Moyle, a poultry specialist with the University of Maryland Extension's Lower Eastern Shore Research and Education Center in Salisbury, says the density of poultry farms in parts of the Eastern Shore can expand the impacts of an avian flu outbreak. "Talking to some of the farmers in the past," he told CNS, "some of the biggest stresses were, 'I got a disease on my farm, and Jim down the road can't get birds.' That stresses them because their friends are impacted.'"
But Moyle argues that density is necessary for the region's poultry industry to operate efficiently. "When this all started — the industry — it centered around feed mills and processing plants, right?" he said. "There's always been diminishing returns the farther out you get."
In 2023, Sens. Chris Coons (D-Delaware) and Roger Wicker (R-Mississippi) introduced a proposal to expand the USDA's compensation program to cover poultry growers within the control zones around viral outbreaks. Despite bipartisan backing, the proposal is currently trapped in gridlock on Capitol Hill surrounding the next iteration of the Farm Bill.
While the current avian flu outbreak is not yet under control, Atticks told state lawmakers on Friday that his agency is collaborating closely with counterparts in Delaware and Virginia, as well as with the USDA, to avoid more serious economic consequences. "We do move as one when we're dealing with this industry on the shore," he said.
So far, Deputy Secretary of Public Health Services Kalyanaraman added, none of the 67 recent cases of avian influenza across the country have been linked to human-to-human transmission. As a precaution, his agency is distributing personal protective equipment to farm workers and has stockpiled medications to treat the virus.

title: Centreville's Landon Hawkins triumphs at Northeast Poultry Congress
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
Centreville's Landon Hawkins triumphs at Northeast Poultry Congress

 January 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 415
 Words

 CENTREVILLE — Many participants dream of winning and advancing to Champion Row. Landon Hawkins of Centreville achieved an extraordinary feat this January by reaching Junior Champion Row with three different entries.Fifteen-year-old Landon, a ninth-grade student at Faith Christian School in Sudlersville, attended the Northeast Poultry Congress Poultry Show in West Springfield, MA, this past weekend. This prestigious event is the third-largest poultry show in the country, attracting top competitors from across the nation. Martha Stewart was in attendance, adding to the prestige of the event.
His outstanding accomplishments included winning Junior Champion Waterfowl with a white call duck drake, Junior Reserve Champion Waterfowl with a gray call duck pullet, and Junior Champion Turkey with a Royal Palm Tom.
Landon has been passionate about poultry for years. He started hatching chickens and turkeys four years ago, but his ambitions took flight when he decided to focus on building a foundation stock of high-quality bred Call Ducks.
Getting a bird ready for competition requires months of preparation and conditioning to ensure it meets the American Standard of Perfection — the official guideline for judging in poultry exhibitions and county/state fairs.
His first win was at the county fair level where he won Champion Waterfowl at the Queen Anne's County Fair in August with one of his Call Ducks. This victory was just the beginning of his journey in competitive poultry showing.
Inspired by his grandmother, who shows Sebastopol geese, in American Poultry Association (APA) sanctioned shows across the region. Landon turned his focus to competing in sanctioned shows.
With careful attention to breeding, grooming, and conditioning, Landon began winning at various American Poultry shows in Virginia and New Jersey, proving that his birds were top-quality contenders.
With this success, he set his sights on an even bigger stage—the Northeast Poultry Congress in Massachusetts, one of the most competitive shows in the region.
For Landon, showing poultry is about more than just competition. He says his favorite aspects of showing include traveling to new destinations, meeting experienced poultry breeders and mentors, and the thrill of anticipating how the judge will score his birds. Each show is an opportunity to learn, grow, and connect with others who share his passion.
Beyond the show ring, Landon and his grandmother are taking their dedication a step further. They are in the final stages of launching Hawkins Poultry, a specialized breeding program focusing on Call Ducks, Sebastopol Geese, and Royal Palm Turkeys. Their goal is "to raise and exhibit top-quality birds while promoting these breeds to other enthusiasts and exhibitors."

title: Delmarva Chicken Association offers update on avian influenza
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Delmarva Chicken Association offers update on avian influenza

 February 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 462
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Delmarva Chicken Association offered an update with good news on avian influenza cases in the Maryland at the Eastern Shore Delegation meeting held via Zoom Friday."As of today, we actually have four control area releases that have occurred, with the fourth one occurring today in Queen Anne's County," Holly Porter, executive director of the Delmarva Chicken Association, said.
The 10-mile radiuses restricting movement of poultry and poultry products in areas where avian influenza was detected will be lifted as a result of the releases.
According to Porter, the four control areas can go back to operating normally and can have new chickens brought to their farms.
The avian influenza was discovered at a commercial operation in Caroline County on Jan. 10, which was the first documented case in a commercial operation in Maryland this year.
Seven commercial operations in the Delmarva region were confirmed to have avian influenza, including the four in Maryland, two in Kent County, Delaware, and one in Accomack County, Virginia.
The Delmarva Chicken Association emphasized these releases happened less than a month after the avian flu was detected in commercial operations on the Eastern Shore.
"One of the greatest concerns that you probably hear from growers is, 'how long am I going to be without birds?'" Porter said. "That's the question we get most of the time. And there have been rumors out there that it could be months and months. And as you can see, this really is not true, as long as certain steps occur, which so far they have been occurring."
In the Delmarva area, there have been cases where wild birds carry avian influenza and spread the disease to farm poultry.
Sen. Johnny Mautz R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico, wanted to see if there was a way that wildlife information can be passed to the farmers from the Department of Natural Resources or Department of Agricultural so the farmers can know to look out for wild birds.
"Now that we have this avian influenza in the wild, particularly for our farmers, they need to know if there's a wild flock of birds within a half mile that have been detected with avian influenza," Mautz said.
The Delmarva Chicken Association said it has worked with both the Department of Natural Resources and the Department of Agriculture to get announcements out. But they said farmers know exactly what to look for.
"What we are telling everyone is, if you look up and you see a bird, you just anticipate there's avian influenza," Porter said. "So if you're a chicken grower, you've known for years that the waterfowl are carriers of avian influenza."
Although the four control areas have been released, the Delmarva Chicken Association urges farmers to stay safe and continue to take the precautions necessary to prevent the spread of the disease.
For more information, visit dcachicken.com/resources/HPAI.cfm.
