title: On the front lines against bird flu, egg farmers say they’re losing the battle
author: Kate Wells Michigan Public KFF Health News
content:
On the front lines against bird flu, egg farmers say they’re losing the battle

 February 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Kate Wells Michigan Public KFF Health News | Section: News 
 
 1420
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Greg Herbruck knew 6.5 million of his birds needed to die, and fast.But the CEO of Herbruck's Poultry Ranch wasn't sure how the family egg producer (one of the largest in the U.S.) was going to get through it, financially or emotionally. One staffer broke down in Herbruck's office in tears.
"The mental toll on our team of dealing with that many dead chickens is just, I mean, you can't imagine it," Herbruck said. "I didn't sleep. Our team didn't sleep."
The stress of watching tens of thousands of sick birds die of avian flu each day, while millions of others waited to be euthanized, kept everyone awake.
In April 2024, as his first hens tested positive for the highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 virus, Herbruck turned to the tried-and-true U.S. Department of Agriculture playbook, the "stamping-out" strategy that helped end the 2014-15 bird flu outbreak, which was the largest in the U.S. until now.
Within 24 to 48 hours of the first detection of the virus, state and federal animal health officials work with farms to cull infected flocks to reduce the risk of transmission. That's followed by extensive disinfection and months of surveillance and testing to make sure the virus isn't still lurking somewhere on-site.
Since then, egg farms have had to invest millions of dollars into biosecurity. But their efforts have not been enough to contain the outbreak that started three years ago.
This time, the risk to human health is only growing, experts say. Sixty-six of the 67 total human cases in the United States have been just since March, including the nation's first human death, reported last month.
"The last six months have accelerated my concern, which was already high," said Nahid Bhadelia, an infectious diseases physician and the founding director of Boston University's Center on Emerging Infectious Diseases.
Controlling this virus has become more challenging because it's so entrenched in the global environment, spilling into mammals such as dairy cows and affecting roughly 150 million birds in commercial and backyard flocks in the U.S.
Because laying hens are so susceptible to the virus, egg producers have been on the front lines in the fight against various bird flu strains for years. But this moment feels different. Egg producers and the American Egg Board, an industry group, are begging for a new prevention strategy.
"The one we're battling today is unique," said David Swayne, former director of the Southeast Poultry Research Laboratory at the USDA's Agricultural Research Service and a leading national expert in avian influenza.
"It's not saying for sure there's gonna be a pandemic" of H5N1, Swayne said, "but it's saying the more human infections, the spreading into multiple mammal species is concerning."
For Herbruck, it feels like war. Ten months after Herbruck's Poultry Ranch was hit, the company is still rebuilding its flocks and rehired most of the 400 workers it laid off.
Still, he and his counterparts in the industry live in fear, watching other farms get hit two, even three times in the past few years.
"I call this virus a terrorist," he said. "And we are in a battle and losing, at the moment."
When Biosecurity Isn't WorkingThe official message to both backyard farm enthusiasts and mega-farms has been broadly the same: Biosecurity is your best weapon against the spread of disease.
But there's a range of opinions among backyard flock owners about how seriously to take bird flu, said Katie Ockert, a Michigan State University Extension educator who specializes in biosecurity communications.
Skeptics think "we're making a mountain out of a molehill," Ockert said, or that "the media is maybe blowing it out of proportion."
This means there are two types of backyard poultry enthusiasts, Ockert said: those doing great biosecurity, and those who aren't even trying. "I see both," she said. "I don't feel like there's really any middle ground there for people."
And the challenges of biosecurity are completely different for backyard coops than massive commercial barns.
Rosemary Reams, an 82-year-old retired educator in Ionia, Michigan, grew up farming and has been helping the local 4-H poultry program for years, teaching kids how to raise poultry. Now, with the bird flu outbreak, "I just don't let people go out to my barn," she said.
Reams even swapped real birds with fake ones for kids to use while being assessed by judges at recent 4-H competitions, she said.
"We made changes to the fair last year, which I got questioned about a lot. And I said, 'No, I gotta think about the safety of the kids.'"
Reams was shocked by the news of the death of the Louisiana backyard flock owner. She even has questioned whether she should continue to keep her own flock of 20 to 30 chickens and a pair of turkeys.
"But I love 'em. At my age, I need to be doing it. I need to be outside," Reams said. "That's what life is about." She said she'll do her best to protect herself and her 4-H kids from bird flu.
Even "the best biosecurity in the world" hasn't been enough to save large commercial farms from infection, said Emily Metz, president and CEO of the American Egg Board.
The egg industry thought it learned how to outsmart this virus after the 2014-15 outbreak. Egg producers went into lockdown, she said, developing intensive biosecurity measures to try to block the routes of transmission from wild birds or other farms.
Metz said the measures egg producers are taking now are extensive.
"They have invested hundreds of millions of dollars in improvements, everything from truck washing stations — which is washing every truck from the FedEx man to the feed truck — and everything in between: busing in workers so that there's less foot traffic, laser light systems to prevent waterfowl from landing."
Lateral spread, when the virus is transmitted from farm to farm, has dropped dramatically, down from 70% of cases in the last outbreak to just 15% as of April 2023, according to the USDA.
And yet, Metz said, "all the measures we're doing are still getting beat by this virus."
Vaccinating BirdsPerhaps the most contentious debate about bird flu in the poultry industry right now is whether to vaccinate flocks.
In 2023, the World Organization for Animal Health urged nations to consider vaccination "as part of a broader disease prevention and control strategy."
Swayne, the avian influenza expert and poultry veterinarian, works with WOAH and said most of his colleagues in the animal and public health world "see vaccination of poultry as a positive tool in controlling this panzootic in animals," but also as a tool that reduces chances for human infection, and chances for additional mutations of the virus to become more human-adapted.
But vaccination could put poultry meat exporters (whose birds are genetically less susceptible to H5N1 than laying hens) at risk of losing billions of dollars in international trade deals. That's because of concerns that vaccination, which lowers the severity of disease in poultry, could mask infections and bring the virus across borders, according to John Clifford, a former chief veterinary officer of the USDA. Clifford is currently an adviser to the USA Poultry and Egg Export Council.
"If we vaccinate, we not only lose $6 billion potentially in exports a year," Clifford said. "If they shut us off, that product comes back on the U.S. market. Our economists looked at this and said we would lose $18 billion domestically."
Clifford added that would also mean the loss of "over 200,000 agricultural jobs."
Even if those trade rules changed to allow meat and eggs to be harvested from vaccinated birds, logistical hurdles remain.
"Vaccination possibly could be on the horizon in the future, but it's not going to be tomorrow or the next day, next year, or whatever," Clifford said.
No current HPAI vaccine is a perfect match for the current strain, according to the USDA. But if the virus evolves to be able to transmit efficiently from human to human, he said, "that would be a game changer for everybody, which would probably force vaccination."
Last month, the USDA announced it would "pursue a stockpile that matches current outbreak strains" in poultry.
"While deploying a vaccine for poultry would be difficult in practice and may have trade implications, in addition to uncertainty about its effectiveness, USDA has continued to support research and development in avian vaccines," the agency said.
At this point, Metz argued, the industry can't afford not to try vaccination, which has helped eradicate diseases in poultry before.
"We're desperate, and we need every possible tool," she said. "And right now, we're fighting this virus with at least one, if not two, arms tied behind our back. And the vaccine can be a huge hammer in our toolbox."

QA young farmers earn national agricultural achievement

 February 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News

 INGLESIDE — Alan and Rachel Eck of Ingleside, recently secured fourth place in the prestigious Young Farmers and Ranchers Achievement Award at the American Farm Bureau Federation's 106th Annual Convention in San Antonio, Texas.The Ecks operate a diverse farm in Queen Anne's County, where they produce grain, broiler chickens, hogs and hydroponic vegetables.
The Ecks also serve on the Maryland Farm Bureau Board of Directors and are longtime members of the local Farm Bureau and the Maryland Young Farmers and Ranchers Committee.
The achievement award recognizes young farmers and ranchers who have excelled in their farming or ranching operations and exhibited superior leadership abilities. Participants are evaluated on a combination of their agricultural operation's growth and financial progress, and leadership.
Alan Eck said he and his family are proud of the recognition against such steep competition across the country.
Growing up on his family's chicken and grain farm, Alan said he always knew he wanted to get into farming, and is proud of the networking and people that he has met through farming.
Challenges faced by young farmers across the aging industry include access to land and capital, state regulations as well as competing against other careers able to pay more.
"It has to be pure passion," he said.
Given their proximity to the Chesapeake Bay, the Ecks have long been practitioners of sustainable and precision agriculture practices that protect the environment while enhancing productivity.
Continuous improvement is the name of the game for the Eck's farm as new and routine challenges come up everyday.
Whether with animals or crops, "We're always trying to be more productive and increase yield and productivity," Eck said.
Although farming is a lot of hard work, long hours in all weather, it is extremely rewarding, according to Eck.
Farming has to be a labor of love and Eck encouraged FFA students to make the most of the opportunities presented to them and continually make connections.
"If someone wants to get into farming, they're going to do what they've got to do to make it happen," Eck said.
The Eck family is no stranger to agricultural recognition, in 2022 the family was inducted into the Governor's Agriculture Hall of Fame during the Maryland Agriculture Council's Taste of Maryland Agriculture event.

title: Eastern Shore farmers organize against proposed solar legislation
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Eastern Shore farmers organize against proposed solar legislation

 February 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 570
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RUTHSBURG — Farmers representing seven of nine Eastern Shore counties met in Ruthsburg last week to organize against Senate Bill 0931. The proposed legislation is a bill the Farmer's Alliance for Rural Maryland believes will have irreversible impacts to Maryland's farming lands and rural communities.The bill is sponsored by Sen. Brian Feldman of Montgomery County.
As written, the proposed legislation seeks to remove local zoning authority governing solar projects. Many farmers and farmland owners on the Eastern Shore believe the bill will permanently damage the future of agriculture in Maryland if passed by the legislature and signed by Gov. Wes Moore.
The Farmer's Alliance, founded by Pat Langenfelder of Kennedyville, Ed Fry of Chestertown, Bobby Hutchinson of Cordova and Rob Davis of Sassafras, held an organizational meeting in January prior to the larger meeting last week. Farmers at both meetings were concerned over how solar projects would impact productive farming lands, soils and economies in rural communities on the Eastern Shore.
"Seeing good farmland being taken over by solar projects like the one in Greensboro makes me sick," Fry said. He was referring to the recently approved project that traverses both sides of Route 313 north of Greensboro. Other large-scale solar projects are slated for Queen Anne's County, Kent County, Caroline County and Talbot County.
Senate Bill 0931 uses a legal mechanism known as "preemption" that would allow the state to override county and municipal land use plans. Instead of residents expressing concerns to their local county commissioners or municipal governments, the bill would direct citizen concerns and appeals to the Public Service Commission in Baltimore.
"We're going to fight this bill with everything we can," said Queen Anne's County Commissioner Jim Moran. "We do not want to see a proliferation of mega solar farms in Queen Anne's County."
Queen Anne's Conservation Association representative Jay Falstad described Senate Bill 0931 as "…the single greatest attack on the future of agriculture in Maryland's 247-year history. It's a land grab driven by ruthless, Wall-Street-backed solar developers eager to get farmers to sign long-term contracts and future access to their lands. Beware of what's in those contracts."
Recently, Caroline County and Queen Anne's County have advanced public notifications to the agricultural community recommending farm owners be cautious in signing any solar leases consulting attorneys.
The Maryland Energy Administration has a goal of converting up to 5% of Eastern Shore farmland for solar projects — the equivalent of over 55,000 acres on the Eastern Shore and nearly 200,000 acres across the state.
The Farmer's Alliance believes that level of conversion will have irreversible impacts to Maryland's agricultural growing capacity. According to the Maryland Department of Agriculture website, "Agriculture is Maryland's largest commercial industry employing thousands of citizens across the State and contributing billions of dollars to the Maryland economy."
Farm owner Scott MacGlashan of Church Hill expressed concern for the future of farming if the bill were to pass. "These solar companies are offering unfair leases that young farmers cannot compete with. Big Solar is subsidized with a combination of federal and state subsidies, that are so disproportionate as to create an uneven playing field that will kill farming," he said.
The Farmer's Alliance for Rural Maryland isn't the only organization to oppose Senate Bill 0931. The Maryland Association of Counties, the Maryland Farm Bureau and the Eastern Shore Land Conservancy are also opposed.
Mark Sultenfuss of Ruthsburg said, "Defeating Senate Bill 0931 isn't just a battle, it's a war, and we must win it."

title: Farmers testify against state solar legislation
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
Farmers testify against state solar legislation

 March 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 720
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Lawmakers, renewable energy advocates and local farmers clashed last week before the Education, Energy and the Environment Committee as testimony on Senate Bill 931 — the Renewable Energy Certainty Act — focused on preserving productive farmland for food security amid growing solar developments.Testimony in the Maryland General Assembly opened with concerns that renewable energy installations are encroaching on Maryland's limited agricultural lands. Caroline County Commissioner Travis Breeding noted that solar projects now cover nearly 2% of the county's farmland — "double the state's estimate that 1% of the state's agricultural land will be consumed."
"This isn't just about renewable energy — it's about safeguarding our food supply for future generations," another citizen said.
Speakers from across the region detailed the complex trade-offs at stake. Judy Gifford, a dairy farmer from Kent County, explained that while her farm has successfully integrated rooftop solar on several outbuildings since 2015, she warned that no solar project has ever returned land to farming.
"We won't know where the tipping point is until we've reached it," Gifford asserted, adding that once decommissioned, solar panels are likely to be replaced by other developments — data centers or nuclear reactors, for example. She decried the state's disregard for its "400-year-old cultural landscape" and the lack of local input on sweeping amendments.
Renee Hamidi, executive director of the Values Planning Council in Baltimore County, urged an unfavorable vote on the legislation. She argued that stripping counties of their authority to regulate solar siting would undo years of hard-won land use protections.
"Counties know from sad experience that once farmland is lost, it's gone forever," Hamidi said, noting that alternative sites — such as rooftops, parking lots and brownfields — could be leveraged instead of sacrificing productive land.
"When you put a farm in solar, you're taking opportunity away from young farmers," Rob Davis, a seventh-generation grain and poultry farmer from the Eastern Shore and board member of the Maryland Grain Producers, contended, emphasizing that Maryland's world-class agriculture is essential for local food security.
Caroline County farmer Matthew Jones expressed personal concern for his family's future. "My daughter's going to speak in a little while about what our farm faces," Jones said, pleading with the panel to ease her worries about eminent domain. His remarks underscored the broader anxiety among farmers about losing hard-won land amid rapid development.
Representing interests from Queen Anne's and St. Mary's counties, Bruce Berriano urged the panel to study the longstanding local statutes in Caroline and Queen Anne's counties. "What's working there really works," he said, calling on legislators to craft amendments that reflect local histories rather than impose a one-size-fits-all mandate.
Donna Landis Smith, a Queen Anne's County land preservation specialist with 20 years of experience, echoed those local concerns. She described Senate Bill 931 and House Bill 1036 as "bad bills," contending that state agencies should never override local county decisions regarding renewable energy siting. "There are no circumstances in which the state, including the Public Service Commission, should override local decisions without the county's input," she asserted.
The proposed legislation, which outlines the permitting, siting and development of generating stations — including solar arrays — is available in full on the Maryland General Assembly website.
As the committee continues its review of SB 931, lawmakers pledged to weigh local zoning measures alongside environmental and economic imperatives. "We must find a middle ground that supports sustainable energy development while protecting our agricultural roots," one committee member said.
The debate over SB 931 reflects a broader national conversation about reconciling environmental progress with food security and local economies. With Maryland poised to expand its renewable energy footprint, Friday's hearing underscored the urgency of developing a balanced approach that honors both technological advancement and the state's agricultural heritage.
In a spirited call to arms, Jay Falstad, executive director of the Queen Anne's Conservation Association, wrote members of the Farmers Alliance for Rural Maryland rallied supporters after the hearing.
"Yesterday was a momentous day. Farmers from multiple counties came to Annapolis, rallied in front of the Statehouse and testified on the need to protect our rural areas against solar sprawl," Falstad said.
He acknowledged the challenges posed by dismissive remarks from committee leadership but stressed that key legislators had revealed their positions. "We now know where the soft spots are," he added, urging stakeholders to "roll up our sleeves" and continue the fight for responsible land use.

title: Safer, more humane egg production
author: Staff Writer
content:
Safer, more humane egg production

 March 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 316
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Eggs are a hot topic across the country and in our community, as prices rise and worries about bird flu are becoming more concerning. Something else to consider is a bill that is currently in front of the Maryland Legislature, SB 806/HB 0834, that could make a huge improvement for our state's animal welfare and food safety, regarding the sale of eggs.SB 806/HB 0834 would ban the sale of eggs coming from hens housed in battery cages and extreme confinement. Many other states and countries have outlawed this practice, and Maryland has the opportunity to keep up with the industry by implementing this bill into effect.
Supporting this bill has the possibility to improve food safety. The cramped, unsanitary conditions in battery cages have been linked to higher rates of salmonella, making cage-free systems a safer alternative for egg eaters. The cost difference between cage and cage-free systems is minimal, estimated at less than a couple of pennies per egg. As cage-free eggs become the standard, retail prices are expected to decrease, benefiting consumers without compromising quality or safety. Even McDonald's went 100% cage-free last year without putting an increased cost of eggs on customers.
Many of us have seen the poor chickens crammed into trucks while driving down the highway on the Eastern Shore, and it's hard to turn an eye to the cruelty. This bill would help improve the lives of these animals, so that they aren't cramped in tiny cages where they can't open their wings or perform any natural behaviors. Getting them out of these cages is a huge step in the right direction, allowing them freedom to dust bathe, perch, spread their wings and more.
I ask lawmakers and residents to uplift SB 806/HB 0834, as it provides a hopeful solution to support farmers, consumers and animals alike. It's time for Maryland to take a stand for safer, more humane egg production.
JENNIFER HEIMERT
Cordova

 The 30-acre tract known as Annmarie Sculpture Garden and Arts Center continues to undergo value-adds, thanks to its many devotees providing stewardship.On March 18, the Solomons facility hosted a groundbreaking ceremony for its greenhouse project.
Annmarie Garden officials stated in a release that the greenhouse "is being built adjacent to our community garden and will be used extensively by the master gardeners and our own horticulture and grounds team."
The community garden is located on a 20-acre tract owned by the Koenig Private Foundation. Last year, Stacey Hann-Ruff, the director of arts center, announced during a presentation to the Calvert County commissioners that Annmarie Garden officials plan to expand the existing sculpture garden to include the 20-acres.
In 1991, Francis and Ann Marie Koenig donated the land where the facility is located. The expansion plans include a 15,000-square foot welcome center.
The Calvert County Master Gardeners program trains volunteer horticulture educators to support the University of Maryland Extension's initiative to educate locals about best horticulture practices.
Noting that the greenhouse project is being supported by state grant money from the Maryland General Assembly, the Rural Maryland Council and the Cove Point Natural Heritage Trust, Edward Goodman, the local master gardener specialist, called the effort "an amazing collaboration."
Goodman told Southern Maryland News there are about 50 active master gardeners. The training course takes about three to four months to complete and is culminated by a final exam. Then, the master gardener candidate must complete 40 hours of community service.
"There are lots of opportunities," Goodman said.
The fledgling master gardeners share their knowledge at such venues as the North Beach Nature Center, Calvert Marine Museum and numerous other locations.
"The biggest thing of the mater gardener program is to educate others on sustainable horticulture practices," Goodman said.
While he couldn't provide a timeline for when the greenhouse would be completed, Goodman said "the project has crossed the hurdle of permitting and processing."
"This is the first step in the [expansion] plan," Cari DeSantis of Ann's Circle, the nonprofit organization that supports many programs and activities at Annmarie Garden.
In briefly addressing the gathering, Bruce Fall of the Cove Point Natural Heritage Trust commended the garden's staff and volunteers "for bringing people in to our area with events."
Fall said the visitors, who come to the garden for such traffic-jamming events as Artsfest and Halloween in the Garden, spend their cash at local restaurants and other businesses, which bolsters the area's economy.
Before grabbing shovels for some fun in the patch of dirt where the new greenhouse will stand, plastic glasses of champagne and cider were distributed to attendees. Everyone drank a toast.
DeSantis said the toast was "to celebrate the public-private partnerships that make Calvert County such a beautiful place."

title: On Gardening: Three-part harmony container design for beginners
author: Norman Winter
content:
On Gardening: Three-part harmony container design for beginners

 March 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Norman Winter | Section: Entertainment 
 
 560
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As spring approaches at jet speed and you start thinking about planting mixed containers (but perhaps with a little fear of the partnerships) keep in mind three-part harmony. It certainly works in church music, and it is perfect for gardeners too!In the world of garden color, we call it triadic harmony. Simply put, triadic harmony is three colors spread equal distance apart on the color wheel. So in the mixed container or basket, this would be three colors of flowers to create pleasing harmony.
Rowe Farms is not only one of my favorite growers of seasonal flower color, but their Facebook page is a textbook on design ideas. Though they are in Jacksonville, a small city in east Texas, their product is found in Dallas, Fort Worth, Oklahoma City, Houston and Shreveport and locations in between.
Recently they featured some recipes that would soon be hitting garden centers. One was called Prime Time, and the other was Santa Belle. Of course, if you find ready-made baskets or planters, you've got your design creation. If you find the individual plants for sale you can copy the recipe. But Prime Time and Santa Belle, though created with different plants, have one thing the same, and that is color. They each have red, blue and yellow in a perfect triadic or three-part harmony.
The PrimeTime recipe features three Supertunia Mini Vista petunias, Yellow, Indigo and Scarlet that will dazzle all summer. Superbells Grape Punch, Pomegranate Punch and Yellow calibrachoas could have accomplished a similar look or recipe. This is what the Santa Belle recipe did but using Laguna Dark Blue lobelia, Superbells Yellow calibrachoa and Superbena Scarlet Eye verbena.
The red, blue and yellow scheme is one of the easiest for gardeners to put together. I used Superbena Violet Ice verbena, Supertunia Mini Vista Scarlet petunia and Superbells Yellow calibrachoa. Triadic harmony with red, blue and yellow delivers a lot of dazzle in quick and easy fashion.
Last spring I did another container with some of this year's new flowers, Virtuoso Classy Carmine dahlia, Stardiva Blue scaevola and Supertunia Saffron Finch petunia with cheerful yellow flowers. The colors were perfect!
If you have noticed, the rules in triadic harmony, particularly when using flowers, are not exacting or mandatory in color, but approximations. Some of our blues were violets and indigo, and even Superbells Grape Punch is purple with blackeye but looks blue throughout the day with changing light angles.
Always remember substitutes are allowed. One of my favorite containers from a couple of years ago featured Superbells Grape Punch calibrachoa, Supertunia Mini Vista Scarlet petunia and since I did not have a yellow flower available, I used Snow Princess sweet alyssum with white flowers as the perfect substitute. They say white is the absence of color, but I am not sure I buy that when it comes to flowers.
Red, blue and yellow is like harmony for beginners. Look at color wheels online and pick out your favorite color. Then you can see which colors are equal distances apart. I like orange so one of its colors is green, which of course will come from leaves.
You may have heard an old saying that close only works with horseshoes and hand grenades, but I assure you it works in picking harmonious flower colors too.
Start planning for spring and follow me on my Facebook page @NormanWinterTheGardenGuy for more photos and garden inspiration.

title: Chestertown Farmers Market puts spotlight on sprouts
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Chestertown Farmers Market puts spotlight on sprouts

 March 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Life 
 
 506
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Each Saturday morning at the Chestertown Farmers Market on High Street, customers can find a refreshing variety of items from produce, to baked goodies and handwoven crafts.For those who are looking for healthy, green items to add to their diet, Fat & Happy Farms sells microgreens, which are early-stage versions of familiar fruit and vegetable plants, harvested just as the plants have turned green and developed their cotyledon leaves.
Microgreens, also referred to as "sprouts" have become increasingly popular in the past handful of years, with much research exploring the health benefits of these tiny plants.
These little shoots "sprout" from the ground and before they fully mature, are packed with flavor and nutrients for a sensational taste. They are good for a healthy snack, or to add to a meal, promoting healthy living.
Owners Jessica and Brien Jackson got the name Fat & Happy Farms, from their beloved rabbit, Buck Bunny, who was "lovingly referred to as being fat and happy when he was eating his veggies." And like how a bunny jumps from spot to spot, finding the right mix of nutrients, visitors to Jessica and Brien's table are treated to a variety of sprouts, featuring 60 mixes Jessica made herself.
Mixes like Spicy Salad mix, consist of broccoli, kale, purple kohlrabi, arugula, Red Acres cabbage, and southern giant mustard. Feeling low energy? They have a mix for that, using specific microgreens loaded with B vitamins, fiber, magnesium and iron, which all help restore daily energy levels.
Jessica says a lot of her customers ask her what kinds of microgreens are good for specific medical conditions like diabetes or even attention deficit disorder.
"Because food is medicine," she pointed out.
Jessica commits her extra energy in growing the company, expanding to markets in Kent Island, St. Michaels, and maybe soon, nearby Centreville. She's also aiming to get their creative blends of healthy greens into more restaurants.
Unlike the growing cycle of plants, from seed, to sprout, to full grown plant, Fat & Happy Farms kinda reversed that operation.
They started selling produce, and now are mainly selling sprouts.
In 2020, Brien found he had more free time and more vegetables in his garden than he could consume. They started going to the farmer's market to sell their produce.
However Jessica was deathly afraid of snakes, and living in Grasonville near the Chesapeake Bay Environmental Center next to a marsh, did not inspire her to grow (or go) outside.
But they did have a nice big garage, she said, and soon sprouts took up that entire space.
When Brien got a job requiring more time and dedication, Jessica took over the sprout business. She said there are often times when she puts in 60+ hours into it, marketing, looking for ways to expand. They not only sell sprouts but sell sprout kits and seeds as well, inspiring people to grow their own.
They encourage the public to reach out to them when they see them at their table or here at fatandhappyfarms.com.
"It's locally grown with love — from our family to yours," Jessica and Brien adds.

title: Queenstown Bank holds lunch for farmers, shares trade predictions
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Queenstown Bank holds lunch for farmers, shares trade predictions

 March 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 503
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — During Queenstown Bank's third annual Farmers Appreciation Lunch Thursday, keynote speaker Chad Nagel talked about the resilience of farmers."The thing that I love about farmers that I think is unique is we're naturally wired to expect hard times," he said. "The average person shows up, the go to a job, they expect good times. They expect a cost of living increase in their salary year after year. And when hard times come, they're a little bit shaken."
Nagel, who is the vice president of Nagel Farm Service, said farmers are different.
"We're wired for the challenges and the difficulties," he said, later adding this brings out hope in farmers.
Throughout much of his presentation, Nagel shared his corn and soybean price predictions for the upcoming season. After warning his predictions aren't always right, Nagel reminded farmers not to be afraid to sell early.
"Because you don't always get to exactly where you thought it would be," he said.
When it comes to corn, Nagel estimated the trading range this year will be between $5 and $5.30 per bushel.
Looking at long-term weather predictions, Nagel said there is a chance that target price for corn could increase. He said while it is looking like the Mid-Atlantic will have normal temperatures and precipitation this season, the "western corn belt," which includes Missouri, Iowa, Wisconsin and Minnesota, could see hotter and drier conditions than usual.
"These are big production states, and to take a hit in that area would be meaningful for price," Nagel said.
For soybeans, Nagel estimated the trading range this year will be $11 to $11.50 per bushel.
Although there are multiple reasons to be concerned about soybean prices, from a vessel tax to large soybean production in Brazil, Nagel said he thinks farmers can stop worrying about how much lower soybeans are going to go in terms of price per bushel.
"I'm going to say I think the bottom is in on beans," he said, later adding that once the country gets "some tariff business out of the way," it should be over the hump with soybean prices.
Before Nagel spoke, Dorchester County farmer Philip Jackson said he was doubtful the markets would be looking good this year.
"It's just things cost too much, and the price of grain is down," he said. "So it's going to be hard on people this year."
But like Nagel said about farmers having hope, Jackson acknowledged things could change.
"It's just starting," Jackson said about the season. "It's not ending. And that's the way you've got to look at it."
Put on by Queenstown Bank, the lunch was held at American Legion Post 91 in Cambridge. Queenstown Bank Chief Risk Officer and Chief Administrative Officer Tracy Whitby-Fairall said the lunch is put on in an effort to reach the community's farm and agriculture businesses so they know Queenstown Bank is a "friend of this community."
"Big banks talk about ag lending portfolios," Whitby-Fairall said. "We talk about your farm, we talk about your family and we talk about your future. That's how we want to partner with you."

title: Country Cooking: The egg basket and the hen house
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: The egg basket and the hen house

 April 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1273
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Yes — we had a special basket just for the eggs.This basket was deep with a heavy-duty handle, and the bottom of the basket was slightly raised in the center. The eggs would sit in the basket perfectly without moving around.
This basket was always stored in the large kitchen closet, not exposed to weather, and was stored each morning after the egg pick-up.
When the eggs were brought in the kitchen, Mom would remove the eggs, placing them in a big white rectangular shaped basin to be wiped individually and placed in cartons or another lighter basket for storage. The number of eggs varied each morning from a dozen to maybe three dozen or more.
Each morning, Mom would place leftover eggs from the day before on top of the fresh eggs. When there was an overabundance of eggs, they were given to family members or sold very cheap to neighbors who did not have "laying hens."
The egg basket was retired forever in November 1997 with the farm wife who proudly wore her country bonnet while doing her chores for over 70 years.
The hen house was a special small building on the farm behind the storage shed. This house was just for the hens, with their boxes mounted in rows on the wall with small ladders going up for the hens to climb in and out.
Keeping the boxes off the floor kept the eggs safe from intruders. These "hen boxes" were partially filled with clean straw when needed. There was a set of three windows across the front covered with wire and one side door that opened to a wired poultry yard to keep the hens safe from predators.
First, I got the eggs from the empty nests, and then there were about five more nests with hens still sitting on them, but mom said I had to get them all. Have you ever heard of the saying "madder than a wet hen?" Well, I proceeded to lift the hen up to get the eggs, and she pecked at my hand, and the party was on — hens squawking and me screaming.
I reach over and get the old broom I kept in the chicken house and start trying to get her off the nest. Sometimes it worked, and sometimes it did not work. When I thought I had enough eggs, I went into the house looking "madder than a wet hen."
BRUSSELS SPROUTS HASH
6 slices bacon (cut into 1-inch pieces), 1/2 onion (chopped), 1 lb Brussels sprouts (trimmed and quartered), Kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper, 1/4 tsp crushed red pepper flakes, 2 cloves garlic (minced), 4 large eggs.
In a large skillet over medium heat, cook bacon until crispy. Turn off heat and transfer bacon to a paper towel-lined plate. Drain all but about 1 tbsp bacon fat. Turn heat back to medium and add onion and Brussels sprouts to the skillet. Cook, stirring occasionally, until vegetables begin to soften and turn golden. Season with salt, pepper and red pepper flakes. Add 2 tbsps of water and cover the skillet. Cook until Brussels sprouts are tender and water has evaporated, about 5 minutes. (If all the water evaporates before the Brussels sprouts are tender, add more water to the skillet and cover for a couple minutes more.) Add garlic to the skillet and cook until fragrant, 1 minute. Using a wooden spoon, make four holes in the hash to reveal the bottom of the skillet. Crack an egg into each hole and season each egg with salt and pepper. Replace lid and cook until eggs are cooked to your liking, about 5 minutes for a just-runny egg. Sprinkle cooked bacon bits over the entire skillet and serve warm.
COWBOY BREAKFAST BOWL
8 slices bacon, 2 medium russet potatoes (cubed), 1/4 cup sliced green onions plus more for garnish, 3 cloves garlic (minced), 1 tbsp paprika, Kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper, 2 cups shredded Cheddar, 10 eggs (scrambled), 1 avocado (sliced), hot sauce for serving.
In a large cast-iron skillet over medium heat, cook bacon until crispy, 8 minutes. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate and let cool, then chop. Add potatoes to bacon fat and cook undisturbed for 10 minutes, then flip and move around to get all sides golden. Add green onions and cook until potatoes are tender, 10 minutes more. Once tender, add garlic, paprika, salt and pepper. Add cheddar to potatoes and cover to melt. Build bowls: Top cheesy potatoes with scrambled eggs, sliced avocado, cooked bacon, more scallions and a drizzle of hot sauce.
HAM AND CHEESE EGG CUPS
Cooking spray for pan, 12 slices ham, 1 cup shredded cheddar, 12 large eggs, Kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper.
Preheat the oven to 400 degrees and grease a 12-cup muffin tin with cooking spray. Line each cup with a slice of ham and sprinkle with cheddar. Crack an egg into each ham cup and season with salt and pepper. Bake until eggs are cooked through, 12 to 15 minutes (depending on how runny you like your yolks).
PHILLY CHEESESTEAK OMELET
2 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil, 1 onion (thinly sliced), 2 bell peppers (thinly sliced), 8 oz button mushrooms (thinly sliced), Kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper, 1/2 lb sirloin steak (thinly sliced), 6 large eggs, 3 tbsps milk, 1 cup shredded provolone, 1 tbsp butter.
In a large skillet over medium heat, heat 1 tbsp of olive oil. Add onions, peppers and mushrooms and season with salt and pepper, then cook until softened, about 10 minutes. Move veggies to one side of the skillet and heat the remaining tablespoon of oil. Add steak to the empty side of the skillet and season with salt and pepper. Cook until undersides develop a crust, about 2 minutes, then flip steak and cook 1 minute more for medium. Stir steak together with vegetables, then transfer to a plate.
Make omelet: In the same skillet over medium heat, melt butter. In a small bowl, beat eggs and milk and season with salt and pepper, then pour half the egg mixture into the skillet. Cook until eggs begin to set around edges, about 30 seconds, then use a spatula to gently lift around edges, allowing uncooked egg to flow to center. Once set, add a layer of provolone to one side of the omelet, then top cheese with half the steak mixture. Top with another layer of provolone, then cover the skillet with a lid and cook until melted, 1 minute. Use a spatula to flip the untopped side over to cover. Repeat with remaining ingredients for the second omelet.
EGG CUSTARD
5 eggs, ½ cup sugar, 1 1/2 tsps vanilla, ½ tsp salt, 4 cups 2% or whole milk, Nutmeg for topping.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees and lightly grease an 8-by-8-inch baking dish. In a large bowl, beat together the eggs, sugar, vanilla, and salt. In a small saucepan, heat the milk to about 180 degrees or just before it starts to simmer (do not boil). Very slowly pour a stream of the hot milk into the egg mixture while continuously whisking until fully combined. Whisk the final mixture for one additional minute. Pour into the prepared baking dish and sprinkle nutmeg over the top if desired. Fill a larger baking dish with water until it is about 1 inch deep. Place the dish of custard into the larger dish of water, careful not to splash. Place the doubled dishes in the oven and bake for 45-50 minutes or until an inserted knife comes out clean, custard will still jiggle. Be careful not to overbake as the custard will curdle. Serve warm or chilled, and top with whipped cream, fruit, or additional spices. Refrigerate any leftovers.

title: Farmers Alliance For Rural Maryland pushes for veto of solar bills
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Farmers Alliance For Rural Maryland pushes for veto of solar bills

 April 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 627
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Farmers Alliance For Rural Maryland's position on farm land is the reason it will ask Gov. Wes Moore to veto Senate Bill 931 and House Bill 1036."The position of Farmers Alliance is no agricultural acre ought to be taken up for solar projects when you have other surface options available," said Jay Falstad, executive director of the Queen Anne's Conservation Association and member of the farm alliance. "If we're going to hold true that principle that no acres should be taken up at all, then why would we be accepting of 5% and many tens of thousands of acres?"
The renewable energy bills the alliance plans to oppose are aimed at increasing generation of energy within the state by promoting solar energy production. The bills were passed by both chambers of the state legislature during the General Assembly, which ended last week.
The farm alliance largely draws its criticism of the bills from a provision instituting a 5% cap for solar development on a county's priority preservation areas, or agricultural land.
"So we're going to be asking the governor to veto 931," Falstad said. "Concurrent with that, we're going to be asking him to advance an executive order that protects Eastern Shore counties from being disproportionately targeted for solar projects."
The farmers alliance came before the Caroline County commissioners on Tuesday to discuss the passed solar bill and its plan to ask for a veto.
According to its website, the alliance is "a grassroots organization of Maryland farmers and agriculture advocates working to protect and preserve Maryland's rural landscapes."
One of the biggest concerns for Mid-Shore lawmakers and the farm alliance this legislative session was solar energy.
Shore lawmakers advocated against inclusions such as the 5% cap, arguing it superseded county authority to limit solar development. In several counties, including Caroline County, stricter moratoriums for solar development had already been enacted.
"So for instance, in Caroline County, at 5%, that could be up to 4,500 acres on projects over 2 megawatts," Falstad said. "That does not include the community solar projects for which you all have a few already in your pipeline, I think."
"So the overall number of acres of farmland consumed for solar projects on the Eastern Shore alone is tens of thousands of acres. In Kent, Queen Anne's, Caroline, Talbot County, it's well over 10,000 acres alone, and that type of impact will surely have implications to our agricultural community and the ancillary businesses that they support."
The alliance believes there are options in the western part of the state that should be looked at before the Eastern Shore.
"If solar is such a high priority for the state of Maryland, then how about we start with every single government building in Maryland including parking lots," Falstad said.
"Let's start there first, and once we've exhausted all those opportunities, then we can start looking at other options, but not before we start utilizing brownfields or old mining sites in western Maryland. Any one of these places could be used for solar, and we really ought to be starting there, and the governor can show some leadership."
In the presentation at the Caroline County meeting, the alliance asked the commissioners to send a letter requesting the governor veto the bill.
The commissioners unanimously agreed to send the letter.
If the governor does veto the bill, Caroline County Commissioners President Travis Breeding said there is still work to be done on renewable energy in the state.
"I will add, though, that the fight is not over," Breeding said. "If he does veto it, it reverts back to this existing process that we have right now. We're preempted by the ruling of a public utility law judge, so that's what needs to be fixed somehow.
"If it can be addressed through executive order, ultimately it needs to be done legislatively."

title: Tariffs jeopardize $300M in Shore ag exports
author: JIM BRUCE
content:
Tariffs jeopardize $300M in Shore ag exports

 April 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JIM BRUCE | Section: Columns 
 
 386
 Words 

 Read News Document

 President Trump's abrupt announcement of tariffs of 145% on Chinese imports provoked them to impose retaliatory tariffs of 125% on U.S. goods exported to China. This jeopardizes our $300 million in exports to China from Maryland's 1st Congressional District, including from all of Talbot County and the rest of the Eastern Shore.Yet the tariff negotiations with China are bogged down in a childish game of who will blink and telephone first. China is hardly blameless on tariffs, but the tragedy for our farmers and businessmen is that our president and our congressman brought on themselves this latest threat to the future exports of Talbot County and the Eastern Shore.
Recall that just after President Trump levied a massive 104% import tariff on Chinese goods, he bragged on April 9, at a mega-fundraiser, "These countries are calling us up, kissing my ass to negotiate deals on tariffs. They are dying to make a deal … [saying] 'Please, Sir, make a deal. I'll do anything, Sir.'"
Trump thus portrayed initiating a call to the U.S. to negotiate tariffs as a demeaning, obscene act by our trading partner. This mocking and senseless incivility to all our trading partners, including China, explains why China's commerce ministry said on the next day that China is open to dialogue with the U.S. on tariffs, but it must be based on "mutual respect." Doubling down on the insult, Trump then insisted that the Chinese president must call first for negotiations to begin.
You need not be an expert in tariffs to know that for 3,000 years, the importance of respect, saving face, is deeply embedded in Chinese culture. Any real U.S. negotiator on any subject would know this. It further confirms that Trump hatched his chaotic and amateurish tariff plan on the fly without careful planning. Soon afterward, China did make the call, not to urge the U.S. to negotiate the tariffs, but for the U.S to capitulate and "completely cancel" Trump's reciprocal tariffs.
The standoff remains.
What's at stake is no small matter. In 2022 our farmers and businesses in Maryland's 1st Congressional District exported over $300 million in goods and services to China. China's retaliatory tariffs of 125% now imperil our exports. Yet our Congressman Andy Harris simply endorses Trump's turbulent tariffs, despite the threat to agriculture, e.g., soybeans, and other businesses in his district.

title: Country Cooking: Fresh asparagus
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Fresh asparagus

 April 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1230
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Fresh asparagus is a sure sign that spring has arrived.My mom did not plant asparagus, as not many in the family liked this vegetable. Years later, when I had a garden of my own, I learned how to grow asparagus that would continue coming back each year for at least 18 to 20 years.
Some rules I learned were to find a space in the garden that had direct sunshine for at least six hours each day. This spot also needs to be well-drained with rich, deep soil. I added compost to ensure the soil was rich and lots of it to have a nice tall row.
A very important factor: do not plant onions, potatoes, garlic, leeks, shallots or beans near the asparagus, as they seek the sun and overpower with growth to overcome the asparagus sprouts. Properly planted, this delicious vegetable produces many sprouts.
One of my first recipes was fried asparagus, given to me by a true southern lady, Ms. Lillie Mae. She has been gone for many years, but the recipe lives on with me.
FRIED ASPARAGUS
Prepare about a pound of fresh cut asparagus for cooking. In a skillet over medium heat melt 1/2 cup butter, add 2 tbsps olive oil, 1 tsp coarse salt and 3 minced garlic cloves. Stir and cook until the garlic is strongly fragrant. Place asparagus stalks in the pan and continue cooking and turning with a fork until tender. Drain on paper towels and serve warm.
ASPARAGUS CASSEROLE
This goes great with baked ham. In a buttered casserole dish, place a layer of asparagus, then a layer of crumbled cheese nips crackers. Wet with cream of mushroom soup mixed with water according to directions on the can. Finish the casserole with a few more crushed cheese nips. Bake in a 350-degree oven until asparagus is tender.
ROASTED ASPARAGUS
1 large bunch fresh asparagus, 1 to 2 tsps olive oil, salt, freshly ground black pepper.
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees and line a large, rimmed baking sheet with parchment paper for easy cleanup. Cut off the woody ends of the asparagus, usually about an inch or so is taken off. Place the asparagus on the sheet and drizzle with olive oil, just enough to lightly coat. Sprinkle salt and pepper over the asparagus and toss until the spears are lightly coated in oil. Arrange the spears in a single layer on the pan. Thin asparagus will take as little as nine to 12 minutes, whereas thicker asparagus will need 15 to 20 minutes. Roasted asparagus is best served when it's fresh out of the oven, but it will keep at room temperature for up to one hour or up to two days in the refrigerator.
ASPARAGUS FRITTATA WITH HAM, SPINACH AND CHEESE
6 eggs, kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper, 4 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil, 4 stalks asparagus (sliced on a into 1-inch pieces), 1 green bell pepper (diced), 1/2 medium red onion (sliced), 3 medium cloves garlic (sliced), 1 cup packed spinach leaves (roughly chopped), 3 ounces sliced ham (cut into 1/2-inch pieces), 4 ounces medium-firm cheese such as cheddar or Jack (cut into 1/2-inch cubes).
Lightly beat eggs with a large pinch of salt and a few grinds of black pepper in a large bowl. Set aside. Heat 1 tbsp olive oil in a 10-inch nonstick, cast iron or carbon steel skillet over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add asparagus and peppers, season with salt and pepper, and cook, tossing and stirring frequently, until asparagus is tender-crisp, about two minutes. Transfer to the bowl with the eggs. Heat 1 tbsp oil in the now-empty skillet over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add onions and cook, stirring, until starting to brown around the edges, about two minutes. Add garlic and cook, stirring, until onions and garlic are lightly browned, about a minute longer. Add spinach and cook, stirring, until wilted, about a minute. Transfer to the bowl with the eggs. Add ham (if using) and cheese to the eggs and stir the mixture until everything is evenly combined. Wipe out the skillet. Add remaining 2 tbsps oil to skillet and set over medium-high heat until shimmering. Scrape egg mixture into skillet and cook, swirling and shaking pan rapidly, until bottom and sides begin to set, about three minutes. Using a heat proof spatula, press the edges in to begin to form the frittata's puck shape. Continue to cook, adjusting heat to prevent bottom of frittata from burning, until beginning to set around edges, about three minutes longer. Working over a sink or garbage can, place a large overturned flat plate or lid on top of skillet, set hand on top (using a dish towel if you are sensitive to heat), and, in one very quick motion, invert frittata onto it. Carefully slide the frittata back into the skillet and continue to cook until the second side is beginning to firm up, about two minutes. Use a rubber spatula to again press the sides all around to form a rounded puck shape. Continue to cook the frittata until lightly browned on the second side but still tender in the center when pressed with a finger, about two minutes longer. If desired, you can flip frittata two to three more times during these last minutes of cooking, which helps to cook the center more evenly and reinforce the shape. Carefully slide frittata out of the skillet onto a clean plate and serve.
CHEESY BAKED ASPARAGUS
1 bunch of asparagus, 3/4 cup mozzarella (shredded), 1/4 cup parmesan (finely grated), 2 cloves of garlic (minced/finely diced), 1 tbsp olive oil, 1/4 tsp salt, 1/8 tsp black pepper.
Trim the woody parts of your asparagus and toss will 1 tbsp olive oil, garlic cloves, salt and pepper. Lay out flat on a baking tray. Place in the oven at 390 degrees for eight to 10 minutes, or until it just starts to wrinkle and soften. Take out the oven, sprinkle over mozzarella then top with parmesan. Put back in the oven and broil until the cheese turn golden and bubbly, with the asparagus fork tender. Serve up right away.
LEMON ASPARAGUS SALAD
1 pound penne pasta, 1 pound thin asparagus (trimmed and cut into 2-inch pieces), 3 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil, 1 small onion (diced), 2 cloves garlic (thinly sliced), 1/2 cup heavy cream, 1 lemon (zested and juiced), 1 tsp kosher salt, 1/2 cup freshly grated parmesan plus more for serving, 1/2 tsp freshly ground black pepper plus more for serving, 1/4 cup fresh parsley (finely chopped), 1/2 tsp crushed red pepper flakes.
Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Add penne and cook according to package directions until al dente. Reserve ½ cup pasta water, then drain. Set aside. Meanwhile, in a large skillet over medium-high heat, heat 1 tbsp of oil. Cook asparagus until crispy, then season with a pinch of salt. Transfer to a plate and set aside. Heat remaining 2 tbsps of oil over medium heat. Cook onions and garlic until softened, about five minutes. Add heavy cream, lemon juice and zest. Bring mixture to a boil, then simmer for five minutes. Add in salt, parmesan and black pepper. Reduce heat to low and mix until well combined. Turn off heat and mix in pasta, asparagus, and parsley until well coated. Add small amounts of pasta water until you reach desired consistency. Serve with more grated parmesan, cracked black pepper and red pepper flakes.

 A coalition of agricultural educators, professionals and 4-H and FFA youth once again joined together to host an educational experience for students across the county for the eighth Agricultural Awareness Day at the 4-H Park in Centreville April 9 and 10."The long-term success of the agriculture industry depends on engaging and educating the next generation," said University of Maryland Extension Agriculture and Natural Resources Educator Jenny Rhodes.

We are dedicated to providing an increasingly interactive and hands-on educational experience each year. The support of University of Maryland Extension educators statewide highlights the collective commitment to this program, and it's inspiring to see our community unite for this vital goal."
Introducing more hands-on activities and student immersion than ever before, experts facilitated stations on the diversity of agriculture across the Delmarva Peninsula, including agriculture's ever-changing technology, food safety, pollinators, grains, aquaculture, animal production and countless career opportunities.
At the career readiness station, Connie Dean, Workforce Development administrator with the county's Economic and Tourism Development welcomed 15 representatives of industries for student interaction.
"It is hands-on experiences like these, as well as this direct connection between students and our workforce/businesses that make such an impact on career awareness of our youth. and their career decision making journey," Dean said.
Over 100 volunteers and partners made the event possible.

title: Growing goodness — Sandy's Garden gives back to community
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Growing goodness — Sandy's Garden gives back to community

 April 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 584
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Sandy Zappia owner of Sandy's Garden donates her produce to the food pantries in Kent County, including the Maryland Food Bank.Fresh fruits and veggies are delivered to those in need, grown using no pesticides or herbicides with natural compost on 3.5 acres on Annie Crow Road. There, a small but dedicated operation of 20-25 volunteers build their organization aiming to make fresh and healthy food available each week.
On Saturday, a week before Easter, Zappia delivered a little bit of that joy to the farmers market on High Street, introducing the community to 25 of her baby chicks, the hardworking future egg providers for the community.
Although it was a little cold out, the chicks weren't, warmed by heaters. The chicks greeted children, teens and adults who held and petted them — a friendly Chestertown welcome. Believe it or not, some have never held a baby chick, Zappia said.
The recent arrivals, coming from Murray McMurray hatchery are a rainbow assortment which will offer a variety of different colored eggs.
Zappia loved introducing her little feathered friends while teaching lessons on rural life.
"Today was exactly what I was hoping for, just spreading joy to people. What a great way to spend a Saturday."
Zappia encouraged people to add to their volunteer number as they prepare for summer planting season.
For Zappia, gardening is a passion, first discovered through her late husband while raising their three children on a West Virginian farm. When she moved back to Maryland to stay close to her immediate family, she put farming on hold, and had a fulfilling career as a preschool teacher at Friendship Montessori School.
After her husband passed away, and her children were grown, going separate ways, that farming desire was restored. In Rock Hall, there were plans for a garden restaurant and for her to run the garden. Those plans fell through, and attempts for Zappia to purchase the garden did not take root.
However, another opportunity arose, and she purchased 3.5 acres of cornfield, which would become the future home of her own operation.
"The idea for Sandy's Garden came about when the restaurant garden where I was working had more produce than we could use- so we donated it to the local food pantry. What an eye-opener! I had no idea of the need for fresh fruit and vegetables in the county. I realized at that moment that I wanted to help meet that need."
Sandy's Garden was established, and today there is a garden, a chicken coop to house her newest, adorable arrivals, a beehive to pollinate those plants and a greenhouse so they can grow crops year-round.
Although they are not a 40-acre farm, they can grow a lot with what they have, Zappia exclaimed. With a goal to provide food to the pantry every week, with heart, hard work and dedication they have been doing just that.
For example, the date of the interview, April 18, they dropped off 38 pounds of spring crops, lettuce, spinach and kale. In May, they will add warmer weather crops, like tomatoes, green beans and peppers to the mix.
Zappia showed appreciation to all her volunteers, hoping for many others.
"I love to teach people but even if you want to just hang out with the chickens, you're welcome to do that too," Zappia said.
Sandy's Garden is a non-profit dedicated to nurturing our community by making sure everyone has access to wholesome food. Scope it out at at sandysgarden.org or 304-761-0286 or contact her at sandysgardeninc@gmail.com.
'We are a happy little self-sustaining area," Zappia said, laughing.

title: Ag Education Day teaches students about careers in farming
author: Erik Halberg ehalberg@chespub.com
content:
Ag Education Day teaches students about careers in farming

 May 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Erik Halberg ehalberg@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 604
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Over a thousand Cecil County middle schoolers journeyed to the Cecil County Fairgrounds in Fair Hill last week to learn about agriculture in and around the county as part of the second annual Ag Education Day."Ag education and literacy are two top priorities of our government and agency," said Maryland Secretary of Agriculture Kevin Atticks, who attended the event on Wednesday. "Everything starts and ends with food."
Held from Tuesday through Thursday, with two of the county's six middle schools attending each day, the event was a joint effort between Cecil County Public Schools, Cecil Soil Conservation District, Horizon Farm Credit, Maryland Agricultural Education Foundation, Department of Natural Resources and University of Maryland Extension.
Throughout the day, students rotated in groups between twelve different stations spaced throughout the fairgrounds. At each station, volunteers talked to students about various aspects of the agricultural field, from animal sciences to land and water safety to farm drones. Organizers said that approximately 80 professionals volunteered their services during the event.
"It's giving these seventh graders insight to all the careers available in agriculture, not just working in a field," Atticks said.
Based on feedback after last year's Ag Education Day, organizers set out to make this year's event even better. Mel Bacon, Cecil County Farm Museum's executive director and an Ag Education Day board member, said that surveys and an essay contest given to students who attended the event last year helped them hone in on what made the event shine.
He also noted that CCPS has been a huge help in pulling the event off and raising funds
"CCPS has been very supportive," Bacon said.
According to CCPS Instructional Coordinator Day Mashongamhende, CCPS incorporated Ag Education Day as part of its curriculum for the 1,042 middle schoolers in the county this year, which allowed them to embed the event in the schedule and organize lessons around it.
"We teach kids fundamentals," Mashongamhende said. "We see how everything connects."
Mashongamhende also noted that CCPS officials took a trip to the Ag Education Day held in Queen Anne's County earlier this year to incorporate ideas from that event into Cecil's own.
One of the major goals of the event, organizers stressed, is to interest students in the ag industry and show them that there are a wide range of career options available within ag.
Following the event, there are options for students whose interest has been piqued.
"Search out a local 4-H club," recommended Paul Rickert with University of Maryland Extension, one of the event's organizers.
Another option is to enroll in the Ag Sciences programs that the Cecil County School of Technology offers once the students reach high school.
Alongside the adult volunteers staffing the event, a number of CCST Ag Sciences students manned stations and worked with the students at Ag Education Day. The CCST students spoke to kids about the programs they are a part of, giving them a preview into things they could be studying in a few short years.
Students from non-ag programs at CCST also came at lunchtime to speak with students about their own programs, according to Rachel Coffey, an Agricultural Sciences teacher at CCST.
CCST juniors Kaitlynne Harrigan and DeAnna Parker were part of the staff at the beekeeping station on Wednesday. The pair plan to do their capstone project on beekeeping together.
They enjoyed sharing their knowledge with the younger students and watching them get engaged with the subject.
"They're learning a bit of everything," said Harrigan. "It's amazing and I get really happy when the kids ask a question."
Harrigan noted that she didn't know much about ag before beginning at CCST, but finds the field fascinating.
"If I could recommend it to others, I would," Harrigan said.

title: Country Cooking: June is National Dairy month
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: June is National Dairy month

 June 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1453
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Dairy played an important part in my life, even though we never had more than two cows.Mom always took care of the cows because she said the boys were in a big hurry to finish and get "out cruising." The easy part may have been "milking" because that was just the beginning. We had a cement building called the "milk" house, which had a small processing center where the fresh milk was poured into a long cylinder-shaped container on long legs called the separator (sounds like a WWE Wrestler).
There was a small glass window on the side that showed the cream separating from the milk as the hours passed. Mom monitored this carefully. Eventually, the cream was drained off and put in those two contraptions called "hand cranked butter churns."
Welcome Saturday morning — cartoons on the black and white, the sloshing sound of cream being churned and occasional groaning. This turned into a "race," which led into hard lumps of butter being formed — finally.
Mom was prepared for the hard clumps to mix with salt, form into balls and press into her butter press. The butter was a beautiful shade of yellow-orange, and she pressed it into a beautiful cornflower design.
Mom wrapped each individually in wax paper and kept refrigerating. Usually by the next week, before we start all over, Mom sold some, gave some away to those in need or froze some.
Oh, we are not done yet. What about the milk portion of the separator?
Well, this was strained well and put in pint, quart or gallon jars and kept refrigerated. We drank it, cooked with it, made ice cream, puddings, cakes, biscuits and much more — all in a day's work on the Hitchens Family Farm.
How our arms aren't the size of oak trees I'll never know.
"OLD WAY" HOMEMADE BUTTER
Raw milk sits out overnight. The following day, a wooden or brass skimmer is used to collect the cream that had risen to the top. The cream is then poured into a wooden butter churn. Churning separates the water from the fat particles in the cream. These particles fuse with each other and form larger fat globules, while the air is forced out of the mixture. Eventually the butter separates from the buttermilk. An outdoor temperature of 65 degrees is optimal; butter formed in about 20 minutes. On hot days, the butter churned is soft and keeps poorly, but on cold days it takes much longer to form. Once the buttermilk is poured off, the butter is rinsed with cold water and squeezed with wooden paddles to remove any extra moisture. At this point salt can be added, and then the butter is pressed into a wooden mold and stored for use.
"NEW WAY" HOMEMADE BUTTER
2 cups heavy whipping cream at room temperature; 1/8 — 1/4 tsp salt; a hand mixer, food processor or blender; fine mesh strainer.
Pour cream into a mixing bowl. If the cream fills the bowl more than halfway, make the butter in batches to reduce overflow and splatter. Starting with the mixer on low, gradually increase the speed to medium and continue mixing for 5 to 15 minutes. The variation in time is due to the amount and temperature of the cream. After a few minutes, you will have whipped cream. Keep mixing until it separates into small clumps of butter and buttermilk. Pour out the buttermilk through the mesh strainer into a separate mixing bowl (can be saved for baking) and squeeze out extra with the wooden spoon. Cover the butter with clean, cold water and continue to work with the spoon to remove any remaining buttermilk. Drain and repeat this process several times until the water runs clear. The more buttermilk you separate from the butter, the longer it will last. Add salt and work into the butter. Store the butter in a tightly sealed jar, plastic wrap, or wax paper in the fridge for up to two weeks. For honey butter add ¼ cup honey in the beginning.
OLD FASHIONED HOMEMADE VANILLA ICE CREAM
6 large eggs, 1 1/4 cups cane sugar, 4 tsps vanilla extract, 14 ounces sweetened condensed milk, 24 ounces evaporated milk, 1 tsp salt, 6 cups whole milk, 16 pounds ice, 3 cups rock salt.
Start by creaming the eggs and the sugar together using a mixer. Then add the vanilla extract. Next, mix in the sweetened condensed milk, scraping all the ooey gooey liquid out of the can with a spatula. Add both cans of evaporated milk. Add in a good-sized dash of salt, which equals out to about a teaspoon, and mix everything together well. Pour the mixture into the metal canister of your ice cream maker. Finish topping off the canister with whole milk, making sure to fill it about 3/4 of the way full, leaving room for expansion as it freezes. Your metal canister should have a fill line. Put the lid on and place the metal canister down into the bucket of your ice cream maker. Crush a big bag of ice, gradually pouring ice around the canister. Tip: You can add up to a gallon of water if needed, as well. We sometimes do this because our motor will seize up. Adding a bit of water will help it keep turning.
Add 2-3 cups of rock salt as you add the ice, making sure to top it off with rock salt. Let the motor run until it stops. Once the ice cream is frozen, the motor on your ice cream maker will stop churning. Unplug it immediately. Wipe any excess ice or rock salt off the lid and out from around the top of the canister. Then remove the lid. Carefully remove the churning paddle. Serve the ice cream immediately. If you're not ready to serve it up just yet, you can always leave the lid on, remove the motor, top the canister off with ice, and place a towel or two over it to insulate it and keep it cold.
HOMEMADE CHEESECAKE
Crust: 1 1/2 cups graham cracker crumbs (about 10 whole graham crackers, crushed), 1/4 cup confectioners' sugar, 6 tbsps (85g) melted butter, 1/8 tsp salt. Filling: two 8-ounce packages cream cheese at room temperature, 2/3 cup granulated sugar, 2 large eggs at room temperature, 1 tsp pure vanilla extract.
Select a pie pan whose inside top dimension is at least nine inches and whose height is at least 1 1/4 inches. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. To make the crust: Stir together all the crust ingredients, mixing until thoroughly combined. Press the crumbs into the bottom and up the sides of the pie pan, making a thicker layer on the bottom than on the sides. To make the filling: Mix the room-temperature cream cheese and sugar until smooth. Mix in the eggs and vanilla, again mix until smooth. To avoid beating too much air into the batter, use a mixer set at low-medium speed. To avoid lumps, make sure the cream cheese is softened, and/or at room temperature.
HOMEMADE PEACH FROZEN YOGURT
1 ¼ pound frozen peach slices, 1 cup sugar, ¾ cups heavy cream, 1 ¾ cups Greek yogurt, ¼ tsp salt + some extra, fresh peach slices from the bag.
In a medium saucepan, combine peaches and sugar. Cook over medium heat until peaches are softened, for about 10 to 15 minutes. Add the cream and simmer for 5 minutes. Remove from heat and carefully transfer to a blender. Puree mixture until smooth. Pour mixture into a large bowl and chill in the refrigerator until cold, about 4 hours or overnight. Once chilled, whisk in yogurt and salt until smooth. Pour into the base of an ice cream maker and churn according to the manufacturer's instructions until thick and frozen. Transfer to an airtight container and freeze for about 6 hours or until solid. Garnish with fresh peach slices just before serving, if desired.
ICE CREAM SANDWICH SUNDAES
1 ½ — 2 cup vanilla or desired-flavor ice cream, 32 1.5 inches shortbread cookies, 2 small ripe pears or apples (peeled, cored, and finely chopped), 1 cup caramel ice cream topping, ⅓ cup chopped pecans or walnuts (toasted), whipped cream or frozen whipped dessert topping.
Place a small scoop of ice cream on the bottoms of half of the cookies. Top with remaining cookies, bottom sides down, pressing together lightly. Place it in an airtight container and freeze until ready to serve, up to 1 week. To serve, combine pears and caramel topping in a small saucepan. Heat over medium-low heat until pears start to soften, 5 to 8 minutes. Remove ice cream sandwiches from the freezer. Let's stand for about 5 minutes. Place 2 sandwiches in each of the 8 serving bowls. Top with caramel mixture, nuts, and whipped cream, if you like.

 STEVENSVILLE — The Kent Island Community Garden opened its gates to the public June 14 for its first open house, welcoming about 60 garden enthusiasts to explore the site and its mission of promoting locally grown food and environmental education.Formerly known as the Galilee Community Garden, the new location sits off White Pine Lane in Stevensville, adjacent to the Cross Island Trail and Island Dog Park. The site is fully built and ready for the growing season.
The garden features 18 raised beds for community use, one charity bed for food bank donations, and three specialty education beds planted with native pollinators, flowers, and herbs.
In addition to offering residents a place to grow their own food and contribute fresh produce to local food banks, the garden serves as a hands-on learning space. Through partnerships with the Maryland Department of Agriculture and the University of Maryland Master Gardener Extension Program, it supports educational programs on native plants, beneficial insects, and land management practices that protect the Chesapeake Bay.
"There are life science hands-on opportunities available locally," said organizer John McKnight.
County officials, residents, and Bill Tharpe from the Maryland Department of Agriculture joined the open house to show their support for the project.

author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com

Garden party brings neighbors together in Ridgley
