 Read News Document

 RIDGLEY — Lisa Calloway has a garden at her home, but not just an ordinary garden. Calloway's garden almost covers her whole front yard.On Saturday, June 28, from 9 a.m. to noon, Calloway will welcome Caroline County residents to her home for a garden party with over 300 registered daylilies. She also has thousands of hybridized daylily seedlings, herbs, bulbs, asiatic lilies, poppies and more.
The gathering has become something of an annual tradition, Calloway said, giving her an opportunity to connect with her neighbors.
"This is the second time that I've advertised it, but I've done it I think four times," Calloway said. "Last year was after two years of drought, and I decided not to do it anymore. But it rained so much this spring and it looks so wonderful, and I am so happy that I'm going to do it again."
Calloway is a cafeteria worker at Greensboro Elementary School. When she is not putting smiles on children's faces, she is in the garden she has been developing for eight years.
"It started very small in 2017, and I had just started getting into daylilies. I went to a daylily farm in Clayton, Delaware, and she has over 5,000 registered plants," Calloway said.
Calloway plans to register plants and name them in her family members' honors.
While Calloway enjoys the event, she does say it's a bit overwhelming having a lot of people near her home, but this doesn't stop her from inviting them. Just two weeks ago, Calloway welcomed a group of students to her garden.
"One of my students dug a potato, made friends with a worm. It was all over the place, and I don't mind kids coming out here. It's great," Calloway said."
Calloway will be selling items from her garden for prices between $5 and $15. She said the prices are low because she knows what it's like to be a single mother and get something very cheap.
"If I don't sell anything on Saturday, I don't care," Calloway said. "This is more of a community thing, get to see a couple friends that I haven't seen in a while, and I'm very introverted and nerdy, but it's like this is the only time that I feel comfortable talking to people."
In addition to items for sale, Calloway will have free chocolate chip cookies and free daffodil bulbs.
Calloway's garden is located on Cherry Lane about a mile past the Tuckahoe State Park camping entrance. Those looking to attend the event should look for a black and white plant sale sign.

title: Indy celebrates 10th birthday on July 4th
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Indy celebrates 10th birthday on July 4th

 July 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 739
 Words 

 Read News Document

 What do you get a 10-year for their birthday?There are many options. Cellphone? Nah. Concert tickets? Nope. Baseball glove? Waste of money. Gift card? Try again.
What Indy — short for Independence — really wants for the birthday party on July 4 is a bunch of bread, apples and carrots. Besides, the bison might just eat all of the above mentioned gifts.
"He'll be getting plenty of that," said Indy's owner, 83-year-old Dick Wildes of Hollywood, on the birthday treats the bison will receive.
Indy declined to be interviewed for this story, instead choosing to munch corn.
Indy was born July 4, 2015, at Summerseat Farm in Mechanicsville and was just three days old when its mother died.
"I'd never had that happen before," Wildes said, adding he never figured out why the mother died.
Then there was the question about what to do with the newborn.
"I'd heard horror stories from people out west who had raised them [from birth]," he said, "They said, 'You never want to do that,' but when that baby came to me for help, what was I going to do? It was either put it down so it wouldn't suffer or try, and the result was good."
The bison was bottle-fed about four to six times a day by farm staff and Wildes, who had several bison at the farm for pasture management.
"Thankfully, we had the volunteers up there who pitched in to bottle feed as well," he said, adding Indy would follow people around everywhere, even into the feed room.
Summerseat Farm held an open house about a month after Indy was born for the bison and other animals.
"I love animals so I wanted to go out there and see what the farm was about and meet the animals," said Tonya Freed of California, who added that Indy "was adorable."
That same day, Freed inquired about volunteering at the farm and after her training, she helped with one of Indy's bottle feedings.
"Indy is very special," said Freed, who has been volunteering at the farm ever since.
Indy's first birthday was a big event as well with balloons up and down the driveway and a homemade vegetable cake by Wildes.
Indy shares the expansive Hollywood pasture, which includes a forest, pond, fresh water and a daily all-you-can-eat grass buffet, with Dozer, a dominant male.
And the pair are a draw for the Land 'O Lake community walkers, golf carts and passing vehicles, many of whom stop to watch.
Wildes, who said he is "very attached" to Indy, will feed the bison grain and will follow Wildes wherever he goes.
It's an above-humid day and Indy is resting in a small, covered, shaded section of the farm to escape the incessant heat and biting insects, and it looks like the animal is in no mood to move.
But carrying a long loaf of crusty bread — Indy's favorite — Wildes softly repeats "Come on ... come on … come on" and soon enough, Indy trots over to the fence and even gives Wildes a kiss.
Wildes keeps both bison in the pasture, and across the road is another pasture with three cows, two of whom are a cross between bison and Hereford while the third is a cross between a bison and Angus. None of the animals are in danger of being harvested.
"They're just pets," he said of Fuzzy, Toro and Mamma Cow. "But they don't follow me around like Indy does."
Wildes grew up in southern Prince George's County on a farm that produced corn, strawberries and other vegetables as well as tobacco.
After graduating from Surrattsville High School in 1960, he enlisted in the U.S. Navy. Later, he worked for a printing company and, after eight years, he bought a printing company of his own in La Plata that he built into a "good-sized facility" with 30 employees, along with another in White Plains.
He retired after the 2002 tornado ripped through La Plata and destroyed the plant.
Prior to that, he had bought the 20-acre Hollywood farm in 1971.
It was during a trip to Colorado decades ago that he first laid eyes on bison and was smitten instantly.
"They're majestic animals," he said of bison, which can reach speeds of up to 35 miles an hour and, according to an Internet search, typically live 15 to 20 years or even longer when in captivity.
And, as America celebrates its own birthday, Indy will celebrate as well with its favorite foods, although Wildes said the bison will most certainly not wear a birthday hat.

 An ambitious, though some would suggest an unrealistic, "green energy" agenda for Maryland has been and is a top priority of a majority of the members in the Maryland General Assembly and Gov. Moore.During the final days of the 2025 General Assembly session, that agenda was advanced when Senate Bill 931, a bill with only one Senate sponsor from Montgomery County, was approved.
Understanding the serious negative impact of this proposed new law on the Eastern Shore, every member of the General Assembly representing the Eastern Shore voted no on final passage of SB 931 in a bipartisan display of unity and solidarity.
Their efforts were thwarted by a super majority in both the Senate and House of Delegates where, as always, a minority may have their say, but the majority will always have their way.
SB 931 was signed into law by Gov. Moore in late May and took effect on July 1.
In response to the final version of SB 931, a new advocacy group was launched.
The Farmers Alliance for Rural Maryland (FARM) is a grassroots organization of Maryland farmers and agriculture advocates committed to protecting and preserving Maryland's rural landscapes and way of life.
According to its website, FARM intends to oppose eminent domain initiatives, state preemption of local zoning laws and any proposals that threaten the future of Maryland agriculture, such as commercial solar fields, data centers, battery storage, power lines and warehouse centers on zoned agricultural lands.
Even before Gov. Moore signed SB 931 into law, FARM launched a petition drive using the provisions of Article XVI, Section 1, of the Maryland Constitution.
That article states: "The people reserve to themselves power known as The Referendum, by petition to have submitted to the registered voters of the State, to approve or reject at the polls, any Act, or part of any Act of the General Assembly, if approved by the Governor, or, if passed by the General Assembly over the veto of the Governor."
The first step for SB 931 to be on a referendum on the next statewide general election ballot required FARM filing at least 20,053 validated petition signatures to the state Board of Elections by May 31.
Despite best efforts by FARM leaders and volunteers, FARM narrowly missed meeting that required number by that deadline.
This matter is far from over.
Following the failed petition drive, the leaders of FARM said they are not giving up the fight.
Some will say any future FARM efforts on this matter, especially in the legislature, to repeal all or parts on this new law will be an exercise in futility.
I strongly disagree.
It will not be easy. It can be done.
A grassroots advocacy initiative, focused on the General Assembly and Gov. Moore to adjust the new law, could succeed especially when FARM already has a key grassroots resource in place.
That resource is the sizable number of voters who signed FARM's petition on SB 931.
These voters have already demonstrated support for and a commitment to FARM's views.
They can be mobilized in a grassroots campaign to deliver FARM's messages to legislators and the governor before and during the 2026 General Assembly session that is only seven months from now.
There are key positive messages FARM grassroots advocates can deliver early and often.
FARM supports the concept of solar energy panels to generate electricity.
FARM supports placing solar energy panels on sites other than agricultural land, e.g., brownfields, parking lots, rooftops, industrial sites, airport fields and median strips.
FARM supports returning all land use planning decisions, including approvals of solar power infrastructure sitting back to their historic and proper place with local governments
A 2016 decision by Chesapeake College to install solar panels over a parking lot on their campus Following that installation the college reported the solar panels produced enough power in one year to offset approximately 45 percent of the college's energy demand.
Chesapeake College's interim president at that time said, "Solar energy has propelled our renewable energy production. In the first year, the array produced 2.25 million kilowatts of electricity at a cost of $106,000. This represents a savings of $85,000 off of grid prices. We anticipate similar savings on utility bills over the next 19 years, which doesn't include any additional solar installations constructed."
Last but not least, the Baltimore based Abell Foundation offers the following thought in their report Getting Solar Siting Right: "Maryland has a once-in-a-generation opportunity to increase its renewable energy capacity and protect vital agricultural land."
Next year, with "out of the box" thinking, the General Assembly and the governor can do both.

title: 'An amazing turnout' — Talbot County Fair back once again
author: Lily Tierney
content:
'An amazing turnout' — Talbot County Fair back once again

 July 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 451
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Fair came back this past weekend for its 42nd year of showcasing Maryland's state sport of jousting, providing games galore, highlighting many food vendors, and hosting a multitude of animal shows and exhibits.The fair ran from Thursday, July 10, to Saturday, July 12. Each day offered something different and exciting, like the pygmy goat show on Friday and the annual watermelon eating contest on Saturday.
Chairman of the Talbot County Fair Michelle McCulley said the watermelon eating contest was her favorite part of the weekend.
"That was so much fun to watch," McCulley said.
Young farmers from 4-H manned the games booths, sold fair gear and showed off their animals each day, an opportunity for the agriculture students to test their skills.
Former 4-H member and 2025 pygmy goat show winner Stacey Thompson has been showing animals since she was 10 years old. Thompson, now 36, is a mentor to many of the young 4-Hers at the fair.
As the leader of the Just Kidding Around 4-H Club, Thompson said she enjoys returning to her roots and sharing her experiences with the younger generations.
"A lot of these little kids you see running around I've actually trained," Thompson said.
Thompson proudly watched the young farmers show their goats after she won first place in her heat.
McCulley said she was very happy with the weather conditions and turnout of this year's event.
"We really lucked out with the weather. There was no rain, and I don't know if that's the first time, but it's a miracle," she said. "So I think that really helped us. We had a really good turnout, better than we have the past couple years."
The annual watermelon eating contest drew the largest turnout of all the events of the weekend. The competition was divided by age bracket.
Everyone had one minute to eat as much of their watermelon as possible, except for the 21 and older crowd, who had 45 seconds. Juice dripped from the sides of participants' mouths as the judge yelled, "drop your watermelons."
First and second place competitors received prizes, and everyone else received purple ribbons. First time Talbot County Fair goer Gabby Hernandez came out victorious in the 21 and older category but said she was initially super nervous. "I was like, making a whole plan," Hernandez said.
Hernandez, who ate her watermelon slice down to the rind, beat her husband and all the other men at the table. "This is my first time. I've never done anything like that before," she said about the eating contest.
The fair will be back around the same time next year. "It was an amazing turnout, and all the money goes back to the 4-H and supporting youth projects and learning," McCulley said.

title: Governor's Buy Local Cookout highlights the Eastern Shore
author: Lily Tierney

Governor's Buy Local Cookout highlights the Eastern Shore

 July 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Arts 
 
 470
 Words

 ANNAPOLIS — The dramatic heat blared, live music played and tents from local vendors lined the outside corridor of the Maryland Department of Agriculture on Wednesday for Gov. Wes Moore's Buy Local Cookout to kick off Maryland Buy Local Week.The annual event celebrates the state's diverse agricultural scene by featuring restaurants that partner with Maryland farmers and watermen.
Freshly shucked oysters, spicy mala Maryland crispy blue catfish strips, a flank steak with blue cheese and watermelon, and so many more mouth watering bites were up for grabs at the evening's cookout.
The Eastern Shore was represented well, with dishes ranging from delicious pan fried local soft shell crab from Bistro St. Michaels, to a beautiful and tasty Maryland Memela from Modern Stone Age Kitchen in Chestertown and a refreshing blue catfish ceviche from Quarter Acre Farm Eats, whose farm is located in Greensboro but can also be found at Easton's farmers market on Saturdays.
Andrea Davis-Cetina with Quarter-Acre Farms said they were told two days prior to the event that Moore does not like raw tomatoes or cilantro, the main components of their dish, but Moore tried the blue catfish ceviche anyway and loved it. "He even made a comment that he could eat a big bowl of it," Davis-Cetina said.
Royal Oak Catering Company, based out of Talbot County, partnered with Bistro St. Michaels for the event. Director of Royal Oak Catering Laura Poole said the event was a huge success and the governor enjoyed the soft shell crab the team served.
"I think it's a great way to get the Eastern Shore recognized and to have people pulled to come over to the restaurants there," Poole said.
On the opposite side of the food stations, the Department of Agriculture set up educational booths on spaying and neutering pets, a booth of animal facts called "true or poo," and other agricultural resources.
"I thought it was very well organized, and I felt like everybody rallied in the heat," Poole said.
Moore and attendees had the opportunity to visit each stall to try the local fare. Guests were given a small red festival ticket to vote for their favorite dish, and at the end of the night, Faidley's Seafood of Baltimore came out on top with their crispy Maryland catfish sliders.
Maryland's Buy Local Week takes place from Thursday, July 17, to Sunday, July 27. Marylanders are encouraged to buy at least one local food product a day during this week.
"You buy your local food, and you snap a picture, and then send it (to the Department of Agriculture) or post it on social media and use the hashtag '#localchallenge.' I think participants are going to be entered into some prizes," said Maryland Department of Agriculture Communications Director Jessica Hackett.
Visit the MDA website for further information on Buy Local Week. For recipes showcasing Maryland's local offerings, visit Marylandsbest.net.

title: Kent County 4-H Fair celebrates youth, farming and fun
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Kent County 4-H Fair celebrates youth, farming and fun

 July 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 721
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TOLCHESTER, Md. — The Kent County 4-H Fair drew crowds July 16-19 with animals, contests, food and fun, showcasing the dedication and spirit of local 4-H youth.The fair officially opened to the public Wednesday evening with a prayer from Pastor Josh Rendulic of Hope Fellowship Church, honoring the late Pastor Bill Carroll of Still Pond United Methodist Church.
The ceremony also introduced the county's 4-H clubs, including Bits and Bridles, Kent Clover Calf, Fuzzy Tales and Shiny Scales, Kent Puppy Pals, and Kent 4-H Triple Shots.
The fair is a time for 4-H members to present the hard work they've invested throughout the year, judged by experts across a variety of categories. Livestock competitions — featuring cows, pigs, goats, rabbits, horses, ducks, dogs and chickens — continued into the weekend.
"It's hard work," said Beth Hill, principal agent associate for 4-H Youth Development in Kent County, "but it's also fun for participants and spectators alike. Our 4-H really shined in their project work and in all the other things we look for: teamwork, cooperation, responsibility, sportsmanship, character — even empathy and joy for others."
The 2025 fair theme was "Blue Jeans and 4-H Dreams." New to the lineup this year was a 4-H alumni showmanship event hosted by Kent County Young Farmers, along with the return of the lawn tractor contest.
Animals were a major highlight. Livestock were shown in the main staging arena, while rabbits and poultry had their own exhibition space. Glossy coats, straight backs, brushed fur — even moody horses — were all on display as handlers aimed to show their animals in peak form.
Thursday afternoon brought out tractor enthusiasts for the lawn tractor obstacle course. Under the direction of instructors Mitch and Drew Debnam, youth demonstrated their ability to maneuver a tractor pulling a two-wheel trailer through a series of challenges. The event even drew a visit from vintage tractor puller and former winner.
"I took off work just to come out and support these young fellas," he said.
On Friday, volunteer Jaime Orndorff hosted the fourth Youth Goose and Duck Call competition, judged by bird outfitter Steve Goss. Plaques for winners were provided by Mark Kwiatkowski of All For A Bird. Orndorff expressed gratitude for the support of her sponsors and contributors.
Inside the exhibit hall, judges evaluated everything from cakes to houseplants, herb arrangements, artwork, photography and even corn stalks. Select baked goods were auctioned off Saturday evening, with proceeds benefiting Kent County 4-H and the Kent Ag Center.
Throughout the week, fairgoers enjoyed police K-9 demonstrations, archery, turkey call contests, a cornhole tournament, fashion shows and a carnival of rides and games. Youth from programs like Horizons of Kent and Queen Anne's, as well as local parks and recreation camps, attended as part of their summer activities.
Each night featured live music from performers including Robert MacFarland, Quinn Arnold, Kevin Kemp and the Del-Mar Band. Wednesday night brought out dancers for a session led by local line dance instructor Minnie Maloney.
Food and refreshments were a big draw, with vendors offering fried treats, funnel cake, kettle corn and ice cream. Each evening also featured a full meal sponsored by local businesses, including crab cakes, barbecue beef and grilled chicken.
One of the most anticipated events came Friday night: the greased pig contest. About 200 people surrounded the fence to watch children — from toddlers to teens — chase and try to catch squirming piglets sponsored by local businesses. The event was emceed by Sherrie Spray, who kept the crowd entertained with lively commentary.
Saturday featured the return of the Power Wheels Demolition Derby for children ages 3 to 5. Toddlers, seated in 12-volt toy cars, delighted the crowd as they popped balloons in a playful smash-up competition.
"As always, we ended with the tug-of-war," Orndorff said. "It really is something for everyone."
Hill said the fair went smoothly overall.
"I will say we have the highest 4-H membership in over a decade, and it's very exciting going forward," she said.
Volunteer coordinator Valerie Mason estimated attendance at over 3,000 — slightly down from last year, likely due to the heat. She noted that gate proceeds support the Kent Ag Center and help reinvest in the fairgrounds.
Competition results will be posted online and published in a future edition of the Kent County News.
Hill thanked the community for their support. "We're grateful to everyone who helped make this fair a wonderful experience." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'Keeping history alive': Eastern Shore threshing and steam show marks 65 years
author: Konner Metz
content:
'Keeping history alive': Eastern Shore threshing and steam show marks 65 years

 August 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Caroline 
 
 481
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — In 1961, Jim Layton and some neighbors gathered off of Route 313 to thresh wheat using one steam engine. That modest demonstration of farm work quickly gained popularity. It's taken a life of its own for the last 65 years.The Eastern Shore Threshermen & Collectors Association hosted the 65th annual Wheat Threshing, Steam & Gas Engine Show over the weekend, drawing hundreds to the showgrounds outside Federalsburg.
Trish Layton Todd, Jim Layton's daughter and the association's president, reflected on the original gathering in 1961. Farming technology has modernized the process in the decades since, but every year, the Threshermen Association puts on the threshing show for locals and visitors.
"Keeping history alive," Layton Todd said of the event's purpose. "We try to do it with working demonstrations, to show the wheat threshing. Now we have the modern combine. Before you had that, it was labor-intensive work because you had to do a lot of it by hand. And then of course the threshing, you had threshing days, where that's all you did.
" ... (We are) hoping to teach people about it because it's good to know where you come from."
Classic steam engines, tractors and other farm equipment were on display Friday, Saturday and Sunday. Misty conditions halted the wheat threshing demonstrations Friday, but not the rest of the weekend.
Attendees enjoyed live music, food, a flea market, lawn and tractor games and more. Layton Todd pointed out how vendors and tent operators were more than happy to show event-goers the history of different traditional techniques, such as blacksmithing.
"Most of the people, if they're here and they have something they're exhibiting and showing, they like for you to show interest and stop and talk," she said.
Mark Williams, a blacksmith from Snow Hill, has been coming to the steam show since the mid-1990s. He first did it as a favor to a friend, but it's since become tradition.
As he finished up his blacksmithing on Friday and packed up, Williams said some of his creations take hours or days.
"Things that are a challenge for me to design and make are the ones I like the most," Williams said.
"I make hearts out of horseshoes," he added.
Elsewhere, some attendees took to miniature tractors to race in a friendly competition.
Each day, the association hosted a parade in the evening, showcasing classic steam engines from around the country, as well as tractors and other farm equipment. Many kids and teenagers rode on the tractors during the parade.
Layton Todd said a key aspect of the event is getting the youth involved and understanding the history and evolution of farming.
She noted that the Eastern Shore Thresherman & Collectors Association is 100% volunteer-based. The group has forged ahead to organize the annual show — this year's shirts for volunteers proclaimed, "65 years ... and still steaming."
The 66th annual Wheat Threshing, Steam & Gas Engine Show is slated for Aug. 7-9, 2026.

title: Farmers gain boost from grant funding through USRC and MARBIDCO partnership
author: Staff Writer
content:
Farmers gain boost from grant funding through USRC and MARBIDCO partnership

 August 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 366
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Following this year's recently awarded grant round, the Upper Shore Regional Council proudly announces that its Upper Shore Agricultural Equity Incentive Matching Fund (the Incentive Fund) has now awarded 13 grants totaling $121,985 to agricultural projects across Kent, Queen Anne's, and Cecil Counties since the program's launch in 2018.These investments help bridge funding gaps for local farmers and reflect a growing commitment to preserving farmland, strengthening rural economies, and ensuring the long-term viability of agriculture in the Upper Shore region. Combined, over 1,400 farms make up the agricultural economy and generate more than $294 million in revenue annually in Cecil, Kent, and Queen Anne's Counties.
"Agriculture has always played a significant role in our local economy," said Susan O'Neill, executive director of the USRC. "Through targeted programs and strong partnerships, the USRC is dedicated to supporting local farms and agribusinesses as they plant roots, grow, and thrive, ensuring a strong future for our region."
Developed in partnership with the Maryland Agricultural and Resource-Based Industry Development Corporation, the Incentive Fund supports food and fiber-producing farms in the Upper Shore region by providing access to capital. Through the program, USRC provides a 5% equity contribution toward eligible projects that are financed through MARBIDCO loan programs, giving farmers in Cecil, Kent, and Queen Anne's County a greater chance of securing financial support.
"This partnership with the Upper Shore Regional Council has proven to be an effective way to increase access to capital for farmers in the region," said MARBIDCO Executive Director Steve McHenry. "By combining our loan programs with the Upper Shore Agricultural Equity Incentive Matching Fund, we've been able to leverage an additional $4.5 million in commercial lending, which gives more producers, especially young and beginning farmers, a stronger chance to succeed in the Upper Shore Region."
MARBIDCO's loan programs are tailored to meet the diverse needs of Maryland's agricultural industry. With USRC's assistance, farmers and agricultural entrepreneurs in the Upper Shore can access a range of financing programs that support everything from equipment purchases and working capital to aquaculture, energy efficiency, and specialty crop production.
For more information about the Upper Shore Agricultural Equity Incentive Matching Fund and how to apply, visit the program page on the USRC website.

title: Hog heaven: Gracie's pigs are top tier at local fair
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Hog heaven: Gracie's pigs are top tier at local fair

 August 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Life 
 
 354
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Congratulations go out to 18-year-old Constance "Gracie" Troyer for a successful performance at the Kent County Fair last month. Her swine Novalee was awarded grand champion among market hogs.Novalee started out winning first among heavyweights. Then Randy, Troyer's other hog, was awarded first among middleweights. At the final showdown, it was between Novalee, Randy, and Laurel Clarke's lightweight champion hog, Diva.
Judge Kelsey Zepp's decision was Novalee, exclaiming one hog stood out among the others throughout the competition.
Troyer's mother, Stacie was among her daughter's cheering campaign and beamed, "Proud momma here! She has worked so hard."
Troyer exclaimed she always did well in past competitions but was shocked that both Randy and Novalee went home winners.
The mixed breed hogs can hold their snouts up high as the best there is in 2025.
Troyer pointed out the judge looks for a specific musculature among heavy weights and for middle weight Randy, the same kind of structure just slightly leaner. Zepp also looks for how clean they are and basically the potential of a quality market pig.
Having prize-winning hogs requires dedication. For Novalee and Randy, training started around January. Troyer walked them every day to build stamina, washed their coats making sure there were no yellow circles and ensured they had clean water.
Recently they have found a quality feed that works for them too — Sunglow — which provides a balance of carbohydrates, amino acids, innovative ingredients, active nutrient supply, and show micronutrients.
All this prepared before under the bright lights of the fair, the swine were led by their handlers around the ring with pig sticks to encourage their utmost cooperation.
The prize was taken back home to Harmony Acres in Kennedyville, where Novalee and Randy and the Troyer family could get a little rest.
Troyer, a graduate of Queen Anne's County High School, enjoys learning, competing and making friends in 4-H. She has one more year at the fair and will be attending Chesapeake College in the fall pursuing an early childhood teaching degree.
"This was a very cool experience," she remarked.
So what rewards do the grand champion hogs get?
"Just some street-cred around here," Stacie joked. "No...correction on that...some fair-cred."

 Local farmers have started picking pumpkins and preparing a section of the farm for the annual pumpkin and cornfield maze.Kids of all ages love this maze, decorated with scarecrows, cornrows leading to dead ends until the correct path is selected. In different areas set aside are many sizes of fall plants and flowers for sale, along with your choice of pumpkins. Fall has always been my favorite season because of the beautiful decorations available from the farms.
My grandson works part time on a pumpkin farm and enjoys meeting the kids and adults who visit. Both young and older folks enjoy the games, the walks and picking those pumpkins for decorating the yard and home.
The pumpkin is a Fall staple in North America for both cooking and decorating. Growing pumpkins involves growing the seeds in warm soil and nurturing the vines. Picking the pumpkins requires very carefully cutting at the vines stem for longer storage.
A farmer friend of mine said he makes sure his workers leave at least two to four inches of stem on each one and handle the pumpkins very carefully to avoid bruising as the bruised pumpkin has a very short shelf life.
In the kitchen, the pumpkin is versatile — used in everything from pies and soup to preserves. The nutritional values include low calorie, high fiber and rich in vitamins.
PUMPKIN BREAD PUDDING
1 lb French bread, 1 1/2 cups sugar, 3 eggs, 2 cups half and half, 1/2 tsp ground cinnamon, 1/4 tsp nutmeg, 1 tsp allspice, 1 15-oz can unsweetened pumpkin, 1/2 cup golden raisins, 1/2 cup chopped pecans.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees and lightly butter a casserole dish — set aside. In a large mixing bowl gently tear apart French bread into small pieces. Sprinkle sugar over the bread. In a separate bowl lightly beat the eggs, add half and half with ground cinnamon, nutmeg, and allspice. Mix in pumpkin. Combine with bread. In a small bowl, mix together raisins with pecans — set aside. In the prepared casserole dish pour only half of the bread mixture. Dump half of the raisin-pecan mixture on top. Pour the remaining bread mixture over the raisin/nut mixture. Smooth out the top and dump the remaining raisin mixture on top. Bake in a preheated oven for 25 to 35 minutes or until firm and lightly browned. Best if served warm with whipped cream.
PUMPKIN CAKE
This cake is easy to make, and you can make your own favorite frosting, buy one at the store or serve without frosting using whipped cream or ice cream instead.
4 eggs, 2 cups sugar, 1 cup vegetable oil, 1 can pumpkin, 2 cups flour, 2 tsps baking powder, 2 tsps ground cinnamon, 1 tsp baking soda, 1/2 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp ground ginger.
Preheat the oven to 360 degrees. In a mixing bowl place eggs, mix well and add sugar. Beat while adding vegetable oil, pumpkin, flour, baking powder, cinnamon, baking soda, salt and ginger. Pour into a jelly roll pan or loaf pan and bake for 25 to 30 minutes. Frost when cooled.
FOOLPROOF PIE CRUST
4 cups flour, 1 1/2 cups shortening, 1 tbsp sugar, dash of salt, 1 beaten egg, 1/2 cup cold water, 1 tbsp vinegar.
Blend flour, shortening, sugar, and salt. Then mix together egg, cold water and vinegar. Mix both sets of ingredients together until you have a smooth dough. This recipe will make at least six single crusts. You can use the amount of crust you need today and the remaining dough can be frozen, wrapped tightly. Freeze the dough into single rolls. I never freeze the rolls any longer than 30 to 40 days.
PUMPKIN PIE
Now for my mom's favorite pumpkin pie recipe ,but I must share a story with you beforehand.
You see, my mom had nine sons. Each year, when pumpkin picking time came, Mom would get my oldest brother to stop at the "liquor store" to get a very small bottle of whiskey for making mincemeat pie filling and to make her pumpkin pies. No one was to know this but my sister, myself, Mom and the brother who purchased the bottle. He did not consume alcohol, so he did not disclose the location. My sister and I also did not drink, so no problem.
Alright here we go.
2 cups pumpkin pulp, 1 1/2 cups milk, 1 tsp salt, 1 tsp ginger, 1/2 tsp allspice, 1 tbsp melted butter, 2 well-beaten eggs, 1/2 cup sugar, 1 tsp cinnamon, 1 tbsp molasses, 2 tbsps whiskey.
Mix together thoroughly pumpkin pulp, milk, salt, ginger, allspice, butter, eggs, sugar, cinnamon and molasses. Mix in whiskey. Pour into a single nine-inch unbaked pie shell and bake in the preheated oven for 45 to 50 minutes. Enjoy.
CRUSTLESS PUMPKIN PIE
I have made this pie many times in the past years. Not only does it taste great, but it is so easy to make.
1 15-oz can pumpkin puree, 1 14-oz can sweetened condensed milk, 2 beaten eggs, 2 tsps pumpkin pie spice, 1/2 tsp salt.
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees. Mix together pumpkin puree with sweetened condensed milk, eggs, pumpkin pie spice and salt. Mix well and pour into a greased nine-inch pie plate. Bake for 15 minutes, turn oven to 350 degrees and bake another 30 to 35 minutes or until the inserted knife comes out clean. Serve plain or with your favorite topping.
PUMPKIN PANCAKES
1 3/4 cups flour, 1 tsp baking soda, 1 1/2 tsps ground cinnamon, 1/4 tsp ground ginger, 1/2 tsp salt, 1/2 cup vegetable oil, 1/2 cup sugar, 1/2 cup packed brown sugar, 1 1/2 cups canned pumpkin puree, 2 large eggs, 1/2 cup milk.
Mix dry ingredients together in a large bowl. In a separate bowl whisk wet ingredients together and then mix them together. In lined muffin tins, fill mixture to the top. Bake in a preheated 425-degree oven for 5 minutes and turn heat back to 350 degrees and bake another 16 to 17 minutes longer until an inserted toothpick comes out clean. Frosting is optional.
BAKED PUMPKIN DONUTS
2 cups all-purpose flour, 2 tsps pumpkin pie spice, 2 tsps baking powder, 1 tsp kosher salt, 1 15-oz can pumpkin puree, 1 1/2 cups sugar, 1/3 cup vegetable oil, 4 tbsps (1/2 stick) melted unsalted butter, 1 tsp vanilla extract, 3 large eggs. TOPPING: 3/4 cup sugar, 2 tsps ground cinnamon, 3 tbsps unsalted butter melted.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Whisk the flour, pumpkin pie spice, baking powder and salt together in a medium bowl. Beat the pumpkin puree, sugar, vegetable oil, butter, vanilla and eggs and together in another large bowl until smooth. Add the flour mixture to the pumpkin mixture and beat until just combined. Fill three 6-cup nonstick doughnut pans with the batter so that each mold is almost full. Smooth the tops with a moistened finger. Bake the doughnuts until a wooden pick inserted into the center comes out clean, about 15 minutes. Invert the doughnuts onto a cooling rack.
For the topping: Stir the sugar and cinnamon together in a shallow bowl. Working one at a time, brush the doughnuts all over with butter, then dip them in the cinnamon sugar to coat. Serve warm or at room temperature.
PUMPKIN SPICE PROTEIN MUFFINS WITH BUTTERSCOTCH CHIPS
This next recipe is one of my daughter in law Shannon, and has become one our families favorites, plus it is healthy.
1 cup old-fashioned rolled oats, 1 cup pumpkin puree, 1 cup Greek yogurt, 2 large eggs, 1/2 packed cup vanilla flavored protein powder, 1 tbsp pumpkin pie spice, 1 tsp cinnamon, 1 tsp baking powder, 1/2 tsp baking soda, pinch of sea salt, 1/2 cup butterscotch chips.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Add the oats to a blender or food processor and process until a flour forms (15-20 seconds). Add the pumpkin, Greek yogurt, eggs, protein powder, pumpkin pie spice, cinnamon, baking powder, baking soda and salt and blend again until well combined. Stir in the butterscotch chips. Pour into 12 greased muffin liners. Bake for 25-30 minutes or until a toothpick comes out clean. 25 minutes will be a little moist while 30 minutes won't be as moist. Enjoy.
PUMPKIN CHEESECAKE
This cheesecake is absolutely delicious. You can buy a premade crust or use the easy recipe included here.
1 cup pumpkin puree, 3 beaten eggs, 1/2 cup sugar, 1/4 cup sour cream, 2 tbsps cornstarch, 1/2 tsp pumpkin pie spice, 8 oz cream cheese.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Mix together one cup pumpkin puree with beaten eggs, sugar, sour cream, cornstarch, pumpkin pie spice and cream cheese. Pour into the prepared crust, leaving about 1/4 inch space at the top. Bake for 45 minutes. Remove and let cool for four hours. Top with whipped cream.

title: Country Cooking: Sweet Potato Day on the farm
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Sweet Potato Day on the farm

 October 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1484
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It was usually a cool, crisp morning as the rule of the farmers was "dig the sweet potatoes after the first frost."Days before, the baskets would be pulled out and the space in the shed prepared for storage. Mom would make a large pot of vegetable beef soup and have freshly made biscuits ready.
The tractor had the flat trailer attached, and the boys climbed on board. Off to the field they would go. No music to listen to or cell phones to talk on — just country folks doing the seasonal Saturday morning "thang."
As the tractor returned to the shed the filled baskets were lifted off next to piles of empty baskets, the sorting began — the sweet potatoes were placed in the empty baskets by their size.
The large ones for steaming for pies and bread, the medium ones for baking and the small ones for a quick pan of biscuits and to give to families smaller than ours who only wanted "enough for a taste."
When the work was done, and the delicious smells of freshly made soup filled the air, we all stepped into the kitchen where the big table was set with bowls, soup spoons and dishes of homemade butter. The hungry crowd quickly filled the seats.
Grace was said, biscuits taken out of the oven, bowls of soup passed around — Mom standing, watching with a smile on her face.
However, my sister and I would stand with scowls on our faces at the number of dishes to be washed, dried and put away. Saturdays on the farm, folks.
As we get closer to Thanksgiving, I will include Mom's sweet potato pie recipe.
For this first one today, we are taking a trip to Memphis. One of Elvis's favorite dishes is what's called Red hot Southern sweet potatoes.
RED HOT SOUTHERN SWEET POTATOES
3 ½ pounds sweet potatoes (peeled and cubed), ¼ cup butter or margarine (melted), ½ cup packed brown sugar, 1 ¼ cups cinnamon red hot candies, ¾ cup water, 1 package miniature marshmallows.
Place the sweet potatoes into a large saucepan with enough water to cover. Bring to a boil, and cook over medium heat until tender, about 25 minutes. Drain water, and place potatoes in a large casserole dish. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. In a medium bowl, stir together the butter, brown sugar, red hot candies and water. Pour over the sweet potatoes in the dish. Bake for 1 hour in the preheated oven, until sweet potatoes are soft, and the candies are melted. After this, you may top with marshmallows and return the dish to the oven for 10 minutes to toast them.
TOASTED SWEET POTATOES
2 pounds sweet potatoes (about 4 medium), 2 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil, 1 tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp salt, black pepper.
Preheat the oven to 450 degrees. Dice the sweet potatoes into 3/4-inch cubes, leaving the skin on. In a large bowl, mix together the sweet potatoes with the olive oil, garlic powder, and salt. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper and place the sweet potatoes on top in an even layer. Bake for about 25 minutes, until the cubes are tender and browned on the bottom. Serve warm. Store leftovers refrigerated. Make ahead instructions: Make up to three days in advance and reheat in a 350-degree oven.
SWEET POTATO SALAD
3 large sweet potatoes (peeled and cubed), 1 small red onion (thinly sliced into half moons), 2 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil, salt, freshly ground black pepper, 1/2 cup dried cranberries, 1/2 cup crumbled feta, 1/4 cup freshly chopped parsley. FOR THE DRESSING: 2 tbsps apple cider vinegar, 1 tbsp Dijon mustard, 1 tbsp honey, 1/2 tsp ground cumin, 1/4 tsp ground paprika, 1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil.
Preheat oven to 400 degrees. On a large rimmed baking sheet, toss sweet potatoes and red onion in oil then season with salt and pepper. Distribute them evenly on a sheet in a single layer. Bake until tender, about 20 minutes. Let cool for 10 minutes then transfer to a large bowl. Meanwhile, make dressing: In a small bowl or in a medium liquid measuring cup, whisk together vinegar, mustard, honey and spices. Gradually pour in oil, whisking constantly until emulsified. Season with salt and pepper. Toss sweet potatoes with dressing, cranberries, feta and parsley. Serve warm or at room temperature.
INSTANT POT SWEET POTATO CASSEROLE
3 pounds sweet potatoes (peeled, cut into three-inch cubes), 1/4 cup dark brown sugar, 3 tbsps maple syrup, 1/4 cup unsalted butter, 1/2 tsp salt, 1 tsp vanilla, 2 1/2 cups pecans (chopped), 2 cups mini marshmallows.
Place the cubed sweet potatoes into the cooking vessel and pour in enough water to cover the potatoes. Select Manuel/Mode at 400 degrees, and set the time to 30 minutes. Bring to a boil. Using the handle grips remove the pot from the heat, drain the excess water and place it on the countertop protector. Add the sugar, salt, vanilla extract and butter. Using a masher, mix until smooth. Using a spatula spread the mashed potato, making sure you have an even layer, top with a layer of pecan and on top a layer of mini marshmallows. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. When the preheating time is done, place the cooking vessel into the oven and bake uncovered for 30-35 minutes or until the marshmallows are golden brown. Remove the cooking vessel using the handle grips and place it on the countertop protector. Serve and enjoy.
CRISPY SWEET POTATO FRIES
1 tsp salt, 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper, 1/4 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 3 large sweet potatoes.
In a bowl combine salt, cayenne pepper, garlic powder and cinnamon. Set this dry mixture aside to use at the end. Wash sweet potatoes and halve each potato lengthwise. Slice into 1/4 inch sticks. In a large pot, heat canola oil. In batches, cook fries in oil for 5 minutes or until crisp. Drain on paper towels. Sprinkle with the cinnamon, cayenne mixture. My grandson Mason loves to dip his in maple syrup.
SWEET POTATO BISCUITS
Cook sweet potatoes, cool, peel and mash well. To 1 cup of the potatoes, add 2 1/2 cups biscuit mix, 1/3 cup softened butter and 1/2 cup milk. Mix until a soft dough is obtained. Turn dough out on a lightly floured surface and shape into a ball; knead three or four times — do not over-knead. Press out to a flatten circle and cut into two-inch rounds. Arrange biscuits with edges touching on an ungreased baking sheet. Bake in a pre-heated 450-degree oven for 10 — 12 minutes or until golden.
SWEET POTATO CHIPS
2 large sweet potatoes, 2 tbsps olive oil, 1/4 tsp sea salt.
Preheat the oven to 250 degrees and position the oven rack in the center of the oven. Rinse and dry your sweet potatoes thoroughly and slice them as uniformly thin as possible (1/8 inch thick slices). If you have a mandolin, use it. Otherwise, use a very sharp knife to get these uniformly thin. Know that chips that are too thick in parts won't crisp up all the way. Still delicious, just not "chip" crispiness. Toss slices in a touch of olive oil to lightly coat, then sprinkle with salt. Lay out in a single layer on a parchment-lined baking sheet and bake for about 1 hour 30 minutes to 1 hour 45 minutes, flipping chips once at halfway point to ensure even cooking. Thickness of slices will impact cooking time. Check at 10 minute intervals during the second hour of cooking to ensure they aren't burning. Remove once crisp and golden brown. Some may feel a little tender in the middle but take them out and let them rest for 10 minutes or so to crisp up before sampling. Serve immediately.
TWICE BAKED SWEET POTATO WITH GROUND TURKEY
Here is another unconventional sweet potato recipe that my son John loves to make.
1 pound ground turkey, 2 large sweet potatoes, 1/4 cup hot sauce (John uses Buffalo Wild Wings Mild sauce), 1 yellow onion (diced), 1 garlic clove (minced), 2 tsps chipotle chili powder, 1 tsp ground red pepper, 1 tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp onion powder, 1/2 tsp paprika, olive oil, salt and pepper.
Preheat your oven to 425 degrees. Cut your sweet potatoes in half lengthwise and put them face down on a cookie sheet. Put in the oven to cook for about 25-30 minutes depending how thick they are. You will know when they are done if they are easy to push on, on the skin side. If you pull them out early and the inside doesn't come out easily with a spoon, you'll need to cook them a bit longer. While your sweet potatoes cook, start a skillet over medium-high heat. Add a bit of olive oil to the hot pan then add your garlic and onions to start cooking down. Once the onions are translucent, add the ground turkey and use a large spoon to break it up to help cook it a bit quicker.

title: Spotted lanternflies are everywhere — what you can do
author: MARY BURKE Capital News Service
content:
Spotted lanternflies are everywhere — what you can do

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARY BURKE Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 776
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Over the past few months, invasive spotted lanternflies have emerged in massive numbers across Maryland.Originating in Asia, the spotted lanternfly is an invasive pest that feeds on a variety of plants. The lanternfly was first detected in the United States in Berks County, Pennsylvania, in 2014. It is suspected that the species was accidentally carried into the United States through an international shipment of stone.
Although the insect first appeared in the United States over a decade ago, it has only been seen in Maryland since 2018. Since then, the species has spread throughout 20 out of 23 counties in the state, according to the Maryland Department of Agriculture.
What harm do they pose?
Spotted lanternflies are not directly dangerous to humans. Although their flitting around can be irritating, the insects do not sting or bite. There also has not been evidence of spotted lanternflies being poisonous to eat or being dangerous to pets.
However, because they feed on plant sap, spotted lanternflies pose a threat to the well-being of a number of plant species in Maryland. Grapes are particularly at risk of harm: their feeding risks killing off grapevines. They also enjoy feeding on maple and willow trees.
When feeding, lanternflies excrete honeydew, a substance which is known to grow fungus. This "sooty mold" fungus will not directly kill a plant, but in large quantities, may stifle photosynthesis by blocking its access to sunlight. The fungal growth may also prevent crops from being sold.
"They're seeing damage, almost permanent damage, to things underneath of the trees," Jessica Boyles, the coordinator for the Maryland Department of Agriculture's spotted lanternfly response program, told Capital News Service.
Boyles mentioned that she has heard reports of damage to landscaping, siding, and outdoor equipment such as grills and furniture due to honeydew and sooty mold.
Excess honeydew may also pose another threat: attracting unpopular stinging insects, such as wasps, hornets and honeybees.
Why are they everywhere?
Spotted lanternflies are notorious for hitchhiking to new places on cars and trains.
Because each female typically lays between 30 and 50 eggs, lanternfly populations can explode in just a few years. These egg masses can be hard to spot, closely resembling mud splotches.
Without native natural predators, lanternfly populations can develop under the radar over several years until they emerge in unignorable numbers.
"It really wasn't all of the sudden," Dr. Michael Raupp, a professor of entomology at the University of Maryland, said.
"They were really here for several years, but at low levels," Raupp stated. "Now, because they've had time for their populations to increase, we're seeing them everywhere."
What can you do?
Contrary to popular belief, some experts say that killing an individual spotted lanternfly does little to curb the insect's population growth.
"The thing that regulates their population are predators, parasites and diseases," Raupp said. "So, by stepping on some spotted lanternflies, it's kind of like spitting in the ocean and thinking you've turned back the tide."
Instead, Maryland's Department of Agriculture recommends installing circle traps, which capture spotted lanternflies without using chemicals that may put other insect populations at risk.
These traps wrap around trees to funnel spotted lanternflies into a dead-end container, and can be either purchased or made at home. It may also be helpful to dispose of egg masses if you see them.
Spotted lanternflies prefer to feast on the Tree of Heaven plant, which is another invasive species from Asia. Removing a Tree of Heaven (roots and all) from your yard can help avoid attracting the insect.
Lastly, checking your vehicles before traveling can also help to prevent the spread.
"Make sure that you don't bring spotted lanternfly with you on your daily commute," Boyles said.
Ultimately, however, experts forecast that spotted lanternfly populations will eventually subside once they begin to face more predation and disease.
"Eventually, Mother Nature will take care of this, as she does with many of our invasive species," Raupp said.
Some areas have already begun to see population declines due to an increase in predators and disease.
"We now have more than 1,000 observations of indigenous vertebrates and invertebrates eating spotted lanternflies," Raupp said.
Some of these predators include spiders, mantises, chickens and pheasants.
This is not to say, however, that stomping lanternflies is futile.
"If you're killing one…you are making sure that that spotted lanternfly can't essentially quadruple its numbers," Boyles said.
As lanternflies continue to lay eggs up until the first frost, often in December, it can still be worth it to squash the pests, experts say.
Why bother reporting?
Currently, the state's Department of Agriculture is still accepting reports of spotted lanternfly sightings across Maryland.
Although officials acknowledge that total eradication of the species is unlikely, reporting helps the agency to allocate resources to areas experiencing large populations of lanternflies.
"That information is vital," Boyles said. "It does help us."
